title: Overview
body: Unravel provides full stack coverage and a unified, end-to-end view of everything going on in your environment. Unravel helps you to understand and optimize performance across every application and business unit both in the cloud and on-premises. It provides visibility across the entire data stack, collecting data from every pipeline, every job, wherever those workloads are running.

title: Overview
body: Unravel creates a correlated data model that provides the full context you need on your apps and resources to properly plan, manage, and improve performance.

title: Overview
body: Uncover: See how your data pipelines are performing from end to end. Get a unified view of your entire stack. Unravel collects performance data from every platform, system, and application, then uses agentless technologies and machine learning to model your data pipelines from end to end.

title: Overview
body: Understand: Correlate and analyze all your applications, users and resource data. Explore, correlate, and analyze everything in your big data environment. Unravel's data model reveals dependencies, issues, and opportunities, how data and resources are being used, what's working and what's not.

title: Overview
body: Unravel: Troubleshoot, tune, and optimize your ecosystem with AI-powered insights and recommendations. Don't just monitor performance – quickly troubleshoot and rapidly remediate issues. Leverage AI-powered recommendations to automate performance improvements, lower costs, and prepare for what's next

title: Overview
body: Unravel goes beyond raw visibility to provide concrete, providing AI-driven advice such as:

title: Overview
body: Recommendations you can immediately implement or automate to fix issues and optimize performance.

title: Overview
body: The Unravel Data Operations Platform helps operations engineers, application developers, and enterprise architects reduce the complexity of delivering reliable application performance – providing unified visibility and operational intelligence to optimize your entire ecosystem.

title: Overview
body: In summary, problems solved by Unravel:

title: Where Does Unravel Reside
body: Unravel Server is positioned in a Hadoop cluster on its own Gateway/Edge node to communicate with HDFS and TaskTracker nodes, and to enable client access to Unravel Web UI. A basic deployment takes two hours or less.

title: Where Does Unravel Reside
body: Once deployed, Unravel Server begins to collect information from relevant services like YARN, Hive, Oozie, Spark, Pig, and MapReduce jobs via HDFS. Unravel analyzes this information and store its analyses in its database. Unravel Web UI displays information from the database, as well as real-time event streams it receives directly from Unravel Server.

title: Where Does Unravel Reside
body: After basic deployment, advanced setup steps are optional, but may include:

title: Where Does Unravel Reside
body: Deploying Unravel Sensors for Hive and Spark, which can push additional metadata to Unravel Server.

title: Where Does Unravel Reside
body: In Oozie, pushing information via the Oozie REST API.

title: Features
body: Unravel provides a unified "single pane of glass" for the monitoring and management of your cluster whether on-premises, running in the cloud, or a hybrid of both.

title: Features
body: Dashboards - provide an overall picture of your cluster's resources, usage, and activities.

title: Features
body: Application Program Manager (APM) - organize and display your application's information allowing you to analyze and locate problems from a single interface and allows you to compare data between various runs.

title: Features
body: Auto-Actions & Alerts - define automatic actions to be taken based upon your criteria, anyway from an alert/notification to killing a rogue app.

title: Features
body: Reporting - a wide variety of reports analyzing everything from your file structure to cluster optimization to migrating to the cloud.

title: Features
body: Insights and Recommendations - Unravel AI's engine helps you fine tune your cluster, applications, and tables to help you optimize for reliability and performance.

title: Features
body: Support Role Based Access Control - you can control the access/visibility users have within the Unravel UI based on their role.

title: Features
body: See here for a video giving an overview of Unravel.

title: v4.5.x - Updates to Unravel Properties
body: This page lists Unravel configuration properties added, renamed, removed, and deprecated in 4.5.x. For a complete list of all current properties, see Unravel Properties.

title: New
body: Enables the ability of users to kill or move apps. This does not affect autoactions.

title: New
body: false: only admins can kill or move apps.

title: New
body: The number of days to look back. The look-back days can be specified as a positive or negative number. For instance -5 or 5 sets the look back number of days to 5.

title: New
body: The look-back time window in hours, which can be either a positive or negative integer. If present, it takes precedence over airflow.look.back.num.days to have finer granularity. Suggested value for large clusters: 2

title: New
body: Controls whether to parse the Airflow Task logs. These logs are used to populate the Workflow Instance entities in the "Jobs - Workflows" page.

title: New
body: Controls the Task logs to parse based on the Operator that produced it. Since Unravel only derives insights for Hive, Spark, and MR applications, it is set to only analyze operators that can launch those types of jobs.

title: New
body: The values are delimited using a "," and it treats "*" as a wildcard to many any or no characters. Any special characters like "\" or "." will be removed.

title: New
body: Controls whether to process the Airflow Task logs sequentially or in parallel. Process the logs in parallel improves performance. This config takes effect only if airflow.task.log.parsing.enabled=true.

title: New
body: Possible values are 1-16. If one (1), logs are processed sequentially. If greater than one (1), logs are processed in parallel using a Thread Pool with of the size specified value.

title: New
body: If set to true Spark sessions will recommend dynamic allocation to true. If users don't want that they need to explicitly set it to false.

title: New
body: The command to use for Spark1 applications while applying the session run.

title: New
body: The command to use for Spark2 applications while applying the session run.

title: New
body: A shutdown delay so that last messages are processed (allows btrace sensor to send all the data before the spark driver exits).

title: New
body: Running MR jobs are linked to corresponding Hive app if Hive-on-MR app.

title: New

body: Roles has been expanded to allow the Admin to limit the Endusers to the Applications tab. Admin can further restrict their access to applications based upon tags, i.e., projects, departments. See Role Based Access. ADD LINK.

title: New Features
body: Running Unravel daemons as a single user that is changeable after install. (UNRAVEL-2449)Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User

title: New Features
body: Added support for Application Master job counters in Auto Action v2 rules. (UNRAVEL-2621)

title: New Features
body: Added container level aggregation in Auto Action v2. (UNRAVEL-2612)

title: New Features
body: Added support for "sustained" violation detection in Auto Action v2. (UNRAVEL-1084)

title: New Features
body: Link to Unravel Documentation on title bar.

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Improved Auto Action email / Slack message subject, removed misleading “only for <state>” phrase and make message more readable. (UNRAVEL-3021)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: All emails and Slack messages sent from Unravel server now include the organization information as set in Unravel server settings. (UNRAVEL-2509)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Split "kill_app" and "move_to_queue" action in conditional and non-conditional. (UNRAVEL-2110)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Fixed very rare but possible ConcurrentModificationException in Auto Action internal metric stream. (UNRAVEL-3173)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Fixed aggregates metrics tracking bug caused by aggregator sharing in Auto Action v2 backend. (UNRAVEL-2903)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Fixed exception when trying to read Auto Action v1 rule. (UNRAVEL-2891)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Fixed “aggregate.Aggregator: found and removed orphan aggregate” error in Auto Action v2 backend. (UNRAVEL-2467)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Fixed a bug that caused non-Oozie workflows metrics to be ignored by Auto Action v2 backend. (UNRAVEL-2515)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Allow slowing down metrics collection in sensor agent. (UNRAVEL-2858)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Properly close connections when using HttpUrlConnection. (UNRAVEL-2749)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Pre-resolve and cache IP address of Unravel server. (UNRAVEL-2015)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Sensor support for bringing in job annotations live. (UNRAVEL-2977)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Backend support for streaming applications. Changes have been implemented to the StreamingProbe. (UNRAVEL-2819)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: Probes initialization when profiling apps in trace and debug modes. (UNRAVEL-3182)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: When upgrading from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, you need to be cognizant of the run-as user for Unravel server daemons. Unravel Server 4.2.x and earlier runs daemons with 2 different local users (usually 'unravel' and 'hdfs' or 'mapr'). In 4.3.x, Unravel server simplifies this to run-as the single user 'unravel' by default. During an upgrade from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, all the daemons are converted over to user 'unravel'. Other changes that occur because of this:

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: /srv/unravel/tmp_hdfs/ is no longer needed, so it is removed (/srv/unravel/tmp/ is used instead)

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: env vars HDFS_KEYTAB_PATH and HDFS_KERBEROS_PRINCIPAL in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh no longer used

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: For kerberos, com.unraveldata.kerberos.principal and com.unraveldata.kerberos.keytab.path are used instead

title: Improvements and Bug Fixes
body: After the 4.3.x RPM upgrade, you need to evaluate whether the switch_to_user.sh must be run in order for Unravel Server to load logs via HDFS and to access kerberos-spnego protected REST endpoints. If MapReduce or Spark jobs stop loading after upgrade, that is a strong indication that you need to switch users. This script need only be run once. See Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User for moreRun Unravel Daemons with Custom User

body: Support for showing the program for SparkSQL applications. SQL queries can be easily mapped to the corresponding line of code of the program.

title: v4.3.1.1 Release Notes
body: Backend support for Spark application badges. The application level annotation contains meta-information about each input data source (event log, executor log, resource manager information). If one of the data sources has not been loaded for any reason (e.g., permission issues to download the logs from HDFS), the error message will be present in the application badge.

You can monitor or wait for these with /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/await_fixups.sh which prints "Done" when it finishes. The script waits and prints ps of the background process. It might take 2-5 min. depending on your data size.

title: v4.3.1.2 Release Notes
body: In Hive events for tuning the number of map and reduce tasks, the recommended values could sometimes result in apps using too few tasks and having a longer duration instead. The new version will not sacrifice duration while improving resource utilization.

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: Upgrading 4.2.x to 4.3.x, One-Time Potential Must-Do Steps

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: When upgrading from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, you need to be cognizant of the run-as user for Unravel server daemons. Unravel Server 4.2.x and earlier runs daemons with 2 different local users (usually 'unravel' and 'hdfs' or 'mapr'). In 4.3.x, Unravel server simplifies this to run-as the single user 'unravel' by default. During an upgrade from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, all the daemons are converted over to user 'unravel'. Other changes that occur because of this:/srv/unravel/log_hdfs/* logs are moved to /usr/local/unravel/logs

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: /srv/unravel/tmp_hdfs/ is no longer needed, so it is removed (/srv/unravel/tmp/ is used instead)

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: env vars HDFS_KEYTAB_PATH and HDFS_KERBEROS_PRINCIPAL in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh no longer used

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: For kerberos, com.unraveldata.kerberos.principal and com.unraveldata.kerberos.keytab.path are used instead.

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: After the first 4.3.x RPM upgrade, you MUST evaluate whether the switch_to_user.sh must be run in order for Unravel Server to load logs via HDFS and to access kerberos-spnego protected REST endpoints. If MapReduce or Spark jobs stop loading after upgrade, that is a strong indication that you need to switch users. This script need only be run once. See Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User for more details. Subsequent upgrades 4.3.x to 4.3.y will not need to run switch_to_user.sh script.Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User

title: v4.3.1.3 Release Notes
body: An RPM upgrade will trigger a temporary background process so changes can take effect. You can monitor or wait for these with /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/await_fixups.sh which prints "Done" when it finishes. The script waits and prints ps of the background process. It might take 2-5 min. depending on your data size.

title: v4.3.1.4 Release Notes
body: Upgrading from 4.2.6 or 4.2.7 with this RPM causes a background process to run for about 15 minutes. During which data is migrated in the unravel_s_1 daemon. To see status of this migration, see /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.out and /usr/local/unravel/logs/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.log ; this migration can be re-run using/usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.sh(download from here) in the background with nohup. When the migration finishes successfully, disk space can be saved by running /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42_cleanup.sh (download here).

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: Upgrading from 4.2.6 or 4.2.7 with this RPM causes a background process to run for about 15 minutes. During which data is migrated in the unravel_s_1 daemon. To see status of this migration, see /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.out and /usr/local/unravel/logs/es_ migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.log ; this migration can be re-run using/usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42.sh(download from here) in the background with nohup. When the migration finishes successfully, disk space can be saved by running /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/es_migrate_4.3.1.0_from42_cleanup.sh (download here).

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: An RPM upgrade triggers a temporary background process so changes can take effect. You can monitor it or wait for these with /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/await_fixups.sh which prints DONE when it finishes. Tt takes anywhere from 2-15 minutes depending on your data size.

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: Run /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/await_fixups.shand wait for it to finish. It can take up to 15 minutes. If shell is terminated, it can be run again at any time.

body: Upgrade to 4.2.6 or later before Upgrade to 4.3.x

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: Upgrading 4.2.x to 4.3.x, One-Time Potential Must-Do Steps

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: When upgrading from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, you need to be cognizant of the run-as user for Unravel server daemons. Unravel Server 4.2.x and earlier runs daemons with 2 different local users (usually 'unravel' and 'hdfs' or 'mapr'). In 4.3.x, Unravel server simplifies this to run-as the single user 'unravel' by default. During an upgrade from 4.2.x to 4.3.x, all the daemons are converted over to user 'unravel'. Other changes that occur because of this:/srv/unravel/log_hdfs/* logs are moved to /usr/local/unravel/logs

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: /srv/unravel/tmp_hdfs/ is no longer needed, so it is removed (/srv/unravel/tmp/ is used instead)

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: env vars HDFS_KEYTAB_PATH and HDFS_KERBEROS_PRINCIPAL in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh no longer used

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: For kerberos, com.unraveldata.kerberos.principal and com.unraveldata.kerberos.keytab.path are used instead.

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: After the first 4.3.x RPM upgrade, you MUST evaluate whether the switch_to_user.sh must be run in order for Unravel Server to load logs via HDFS and to access kerberos-spnego protected REST endpoints. If MapReduce or Spark jobs stop loading after upgrade, that is a strong indication that you need to switch users. This script need only be run once. See Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User for more details. Subsequent upgrades 4.3.x to 4.3.y will not need to run switch_to_user.sh script.Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User

title: v4.3.1.6 Release Notes
body: An RPM upgrade will trigger a temporary background process so changes can take effect. You can monitor or wait for these with /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/await_fixups.sh which prints "Done" when it finishes. The script waits and prints ps of the background process. It might take 2-5 min. depending on your data size.

title: New Features
body: Impala APM 1.0 (Beta): This release supports application performance management (APM) for Impala queries on CDH clusters.

title: New Features
body: Kafka APM 1.0 (Beta): This release supports application performance management (APM) for Kafka queries.

title: New Features
body: This release supports the monitoring of applications run within the Tez framework. This includes:

title: New Features
body: The Tez application performance manager (APM) in Unravel Web UI provides a detailed view into the behavior of "Tez framework" queries as a directed acyclic graph (DAG). DAG details include query text, DAG graphs, and information on vertices, tasks, and attempts. For more information, see the User Guide.User Guide

title: New Features
body: This release includes an improved pipeline for collecting data from Spark applications. The pipeline provides:

title: New Features
body: Stage level updates: Previously, the Spark APM in Unravel Web UI updated the application's page only once, when the application was finished. With this release, as soon as a stage completes, the Spark APM in Unravel Web UI shows stage level information. This improvement allows you to interact with the Spark APM more often.

title: New Features
body: Smarter events: The event generation algorithm has been updated with additional triggers. Events are generated only if an application's original settings are significantly different from Unravel's suggested settings.

title: New Features
body: Workflow tagging: Unravel Web UI now displays tagged workflows identically, irrespective of the mode in which the Spark applications were loaded. Supported loading modes remain the same: OPS mode (loading through Unravel Sensor for Spark), and BATCH mode (loaded outside of Unravel Sensor).

title: New Features
body: Applications are tagged even when the event log files are unavailable.

title: New Features
body: Consistent display of information about each Spark application, even if the event log file is not available. At a minimum, a Spark application's page displays the application metadata, taken from the resource manager.

title: New Features
body: This release supports data collection for multi-cluster Kafka topics, and Kafka application performance management through Unravel Web UI. Kafka support includes:

title: New Features
body: Single view for CG status/stats across topics it consumes

title: Cloudera Distribution of Apache Hadoop (CDH)
body: CDH is Cloudera's distribution of Apache Hadoop and related process, management, storage, and security components (Spark, Hive, Pig, MapReduce, Impala, HBase, Kafka, Sentry, and so on).

title: Cloudera Distribution of Apache Hadoop (CDH)
body: This section explains how to deploy Unravel Server and Sensors on the Cloudera distribution of Apache Hadoop (CDH), with Cloudera Manager (CM).

title: 4. Install Unravel Server on the Host
body: Unravel Server uses two separate disks: one for binaries (/usr/local/unravel) and one for data (/srv/unravel). The separate disk /srv/unravel is beneficial for performance. If either disk doesn't have the minimum space required, create symbolic links for them to another disk drive.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: For quick initial installation, you can use the hdfs principal and its keytab, but for production use, you might want to create an alternate principal that has restricted access to specific areas, and use its corresponding keytab. This topic explains how to do this.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: You can name the alternate principal whatever you prefer; these steps name it unravel. Its name doesn't need to be the same as the local username.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: The steps apply only to CDH and have been tested using Cloudera Manager with the recommended Sentry configuration.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: For access via ACL, the group part of the HDFS default umask needs to have read and execute access. This allows Unravel to see subdirectories and read files. The default umask setting on HDFS for both CDH and HDP is 022. The middle digit controls the group mask and ACLs are masked using this default group mode.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: You can check the HDFS umask setting from either Cloudera Manager or in hdfs-site.xml:

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: In Cloudera Manager, check the value of dfs.umaskmode and make sure the middle digit is 2 or 0.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: In hdfs-site.xml file search for fs.permissions.umask-mode and make sure the middle digit is 2 or 0.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: In Cloudera Manager's HDFS configuration, search for namenode advanced configuration snippet, and set its dfs.namenode.posix.acl.inheritance.enabled property to true in hdfs-site.xml. This is a workaround for an issue where HDFS was not compliant with the Posix standard for ACL inheritance. For details, see Apache JIRA HDFS-6962. Cloudera backported the fix for this issue into CDH5.8.4, CDH5.9.1, and later, setting dfs.namenode.posix.acl.inheritance.enabled to false in Hadoop 2.x and true in Hadoop 3.x.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Restart the cluster to effect the change of dfs.namenode.posix.acl.inheritance.enabled to true.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Change the ACLs of the target HDFS directories.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Run the following commands as global hdfs to change the ACLs of the following HDFS directories. Run these in the order presented.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Set the ACL for future directories.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Be sure to set the permissions at the /user/history level. Files are first written to an intermediate_done folder under /user/history and then moved to /user/history/done.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body:
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m default:user:unravel:r-x /user/spark/applicationHistory
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m default:user:unravel:r-x /user/history
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m default:user:unravel:r-x /tmp/logs
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m default:user:unravel:r-x /user/hive/warehouse

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: If you have Spark2 installed, set the ACL of the Spark2 application history folder:

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body:
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m user:unravel:r-x /user/spark/applicationHistory
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m user:unravel:r-x /user/history
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m user:unravel:r-x /tmp/logs
hadoop fs -setfacl -R -m user:unravel:r-x /user/hive/warehouse

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: If you have Spark2 installed, set the ACL of the Spark2 application history folder:

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: Verify the ACL of the target HDFS directories.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body:
hdfs dfs -getfacl /user/spark/applicationHistory
hdfs dfs -getfacl /user/spark/spark2ApplicationHistory
hdfs dfs -getfacl /user/history
hdfs dfs -getfacl /tmp/logs
hdfs dfs -getfacl /user/hive/warehouse

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body: On the Unravel Server, verify HDFS permission on folders as the target user (unravel, hdfs, mapr, or custom) with a valid kerberos ticket corresponding to the keytab principal.

title: Creating an Alternate Principal
body:
sudo -u unravel kdestroy
sudo -u unravel kinit -kt keytab-file principal
sudo -u unravel hadoop fs -ls /user/history
sudo -u unravel hadoop fs -ls /tmp/logs
sudo -u unravel hadoop fs -ls /user/hive/warehouse

title: Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP)
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel on Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP). Deploying Unravel on HDP involves the following steps, at a high level:

title: Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP)

title: Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP)

title: Prerequisites
body: To deploy Unravel, first ensure that your environment meets these requirements.

title: Platform
body: Each version of Unravel has specific platform requirements. Confirm that your HDP meets the requirements for the version of Unravel that you're installing.

title: Hardware
body: RAM: 64GB minimum, 128GB for medium volume (>25,000 jobs per day), 256GB for high volume (>50,000 jobs per day)

title: Hardware
body: /usr/local/unravel (can be a symbolic link) with minimum 8GB free

title: Hardware
body: /srv/unravel (can be a symbolic link) with minimum 500GB free

title: Hardware
body: You can remount /tmp with executable permissions with the command

title: Hardware
body: For 60,000+ MR jobs per day, two or more gateway/edge nodes are recommended ("multi-host Unravel")

title: Software
body: If you're running Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 6.x, you must set the following property in your elasticsearch.yml:

title: Software
body: In /etc/selinux/config, SELINUX is set to permissive or disabled

title: Software
body: PATH includes the path to the HDFS+Hive+YARN+Spark client/gateway, Hadoop commands, and Hive commands

title: Software
body: If Spark is in use, Spark client gateway

title: Software
body: Verify that all clients are installed by checking that RPMs are installed; Unravel utilizes clients and associated libraries

title: Software
body: The Unravel edge node is registered with Ambari

title: Software
body: LDAP (AD or Open LDAP) compatible for Unravel Web UI user authentication (Open signup by default)

title: Software
body: Zookeeper is not installed on the same host as the Unravel host

title: Access Permissions
body: If Kerberos is in use, a keytab for principal hdfs (or read-only equivalent) is required for access to:

title: Access Permissions

title: Access Permissions

title: Access Permissions

title: Access Permissions
body: If you plan to use the Auto Actions feature (move / kill), you've added the Unravel username to YARN's yarn.admin.acl property.

title: Network
body: The following ports must be open on Unravel's host(s):

title: Network
body: Traffic to and from Unravel UI

title: Network
body: Host monitoring of JMX on localhost

title: Network
body: UDP and TCP ingest traffic from the entire cluster to Unravel Server(s)

title: Network

title: Network

title: Network

title: Modify Unravel Server for HDP
body: Unravel daemons run under the local user unravel by default. However, if you have Kerberos or Ranger enabled, or a non-Kerberos cluster with simple Unix security, or a different username for the Unravel user, you need these daemons to run under a different user. The switch_to_user.sh script changes the owner and group of the Unravel daemons.

title: MapR
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel Server and Sensors on the MapR converged data platform.

title: Prerequisites
body: Ensure that your environment meets these requirements.

title: Platform
body: Each version of Unravel has specific platform requirements. Confirm that your MapR meets the requirements for the version of Unravel that you're installing.

title: Hardware
body: RAM: 64GB minimum, 128GB for medium volume (>25,000 jobs per day), 256GB for high volume (>50,000 jobs per day)

title: Hardware
body: /usr/local/unravel (can be a symbolic link) with minimum 8GB free

title: Hardware
body: /srv/unravel (can be a symbolic link) with minimum 500GB free

title: Hardware
body: You can remount /tmp with executable permissions with the command

title: Hardware
body: For 60,000+ MR jobs per day, two or more gateway/edge nodes are recommended ("multi-host Unravel")

title: Software
body: If you're running Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 6.x, you must set the following property in your elasticsearch.yml:

title: Software
body: In /etc/selinux/config, SELINUX is set to permissive or disabled

title: Software
body: PATH includes the path to the HDFS+Hive+YARN+Spark client/gateway, Hadoop commands, and Hive commands

title: Software
body: LDAP (AD or Open LDAP) compatible for Unravel Web UI user authentication (Open signup by default)

title: Software
body: Zookeeper is not installed on the same host as the Unravel host

title: Part 1: Installing Unravel Server on MapR
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel Server on the MapR converged data platform.

title: Confirm that Your MapR Meets the Platform Requirements

title: Configure the Host

title: Configure the Host
body: For more information about the MapR client configuration, see https://maprdocs.mapr.com/52/ReferenceGuide/configure.sh.html

title: Configure the Host
body: Run the following commands this gateway/edge/client host as root, substituting your site-specific values for name, cldb-list, and history-server.

title: Configure the Host
body:
sudo yum install mapr-client.x86_64
sudo /opt/mapr/server/configure.sh -N name -c -C cldb-list -HS history-server
sudo yum install mapr-hive.noarch
sudo yum install mapr-spark.noarch

title: Configure the Host

sudo useradd -g mapr unravel
hadoop fs -mkdir /user/unravel
hadoop fs -chown unravel:mapr /user/unravel

title: Enable Instrumentation Manually
body: Append the contents of /usr/local/unravel/hive-hook/hive-site.xml.snip to /opt/mapr/hive/hive-hive-version/conf/hive-site.xml right before </configuration>.

body:
<property>
<name>com.unraveldata.host</name>
<value>unravel-host</value>
<description>Unravel hive-hook processing host</description>
</property>
<property>
<name>com.unraveldata.hive.hook.tcp</name>
<value>true</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>com.unraveldata.hive.hdfs.dir</name>
<value>/user/unravel/HOOK_RESULT_DIR</value>
<description>destination for hive-hook, Unravel log processing</description>
</property>
<property>
<name>hive.exec.driver.run.hooks</name>
<value>com.unraveldata.dataflow.hive.hook.UnravelHiveHook</value>
<description>for Unravel, from unraveldata.com</description>
</property>
<property>
<name>hive.exec.pre.hooks</name>
<value>com.unraveldata.dataflow.hive.hook.UnravelHiveHook</value>
<description>for Unravel, from unraveldata.com</description>
</property>
<property>
<name>hive.exec.post.hooks</name>
<value>com.unraveldata.dataflow.hive.hook.UnravelHiveHook</value>
<description>for Unravel, from unraveldata.com</description>
</property>
<property>
<name>hive.exec.failure.hooks</name>
<value>com.unraveldata.dataflow.hive.hook.UnravelHiveHook</value>
<description>for Unravel, from unraveldata.com</description>
</property>
</configuration>

title: Amazon Elastic MapReduce (EMR)
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel on Amazon Elastic MapReduce (EMR).

title: Amazon Elastic MapReduce (EMR)
body: Unravel deployment involves creating a new EC2 instance and setting up RDS (optionally), installing Unravel Server on the new EC2 instance, configuring Unravel Server, and connecting it to the EMR cluster you want to monitor.

title: Amazon Elastic MapReduce (EMR)
body: A typical deployment and configuration takes less than an hour in most environments. In some environments, deployment takes longer due to the complexity of security/VPC settings, various permissions setup, and so on.

title: Hardware
body: In a PoC or evaluation, the minimum root disk space should be sufficient.

title: Hardware
body: When monitoring more EMR clusters or lots of jobs, we recommend a 300-500GB Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1) volume with 3000 IOPS.

title: Hardware
body: For production use, we recommend a 200GB Provisioned IOPS EBS and RDS volume.

title: Hardware
body: The Baseline IOPS (3 IOPS per GiB with a minimum of 100 IOPS, burstable to 3000 IOPS) is sufficient for Unravel

title: Hardware
body: DB instance class: db.r3.xlarge (4 vCPU, 30.5 GiB RAM)

title: Hardware
body: Unravel Server doesn't require a heavy resources, but it's best to check your AWS Service Limits as you proceed. For example, if you provision an Unravel EC2 instance from our CloudFormation template, check Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) Limits.

title: Software
body: Recommended: CentOS 7.4 AMI. For example, ami-02e98f78 in us-east-1.

title: Access Permissions
body: The Unravel EC2 instance must have read permission on the S3 bucket used by EMR clusters.

title: Access Permissions
body: You need an AWS account. You must be able to connect to AWS for the deployment process.

title: Access Permissions
body: Create an S3 ReadAccess only IAM role and assign it to Unravel Server to READ the archive logs on the S3 bucket configured for the EMR cluster. In other words, create an IAM role that contains the policy that can only READ the specific S3 bucket used on the EMR cluster; then, create an EC2 instance profile and add the IAM role to it.

title: Access Permissions
body: Create security groups and IAM roles

title: Access Permissions
body: Update IAM roles for the EMR cluster and the corresponding S3 storage

title: Access Permissions
body: If you want to deploy Unravel for a new EMR cluster, you also need AWS permissions to create an EMR cluster and necessary S3 buckets, create and configure VPCs, etc.

title: Network
body: The following ports must be open on the Unravel EC2 instance. In addition, the Unravel EC2 instance must be able to access all ports on the EMR cluster.

title: Network
body: Settings Related to IAM Roles and Security Groups

title: Network
body: In order to manage, monitor, and optimize the modern data applications running on your EMR cluster, Unravel needs data from the cluster as well as from apps running on the cluster. This data includes metrics, configuration information, and logs. Parts of this data is pushed to Unravel, and part of it is pulled by the daemons running on Unravel Server. In order for all data to be accessible, there must be both inbound and outbound access between Unravel Server (on the EC2 instance) and the EMR cluster.

title: Network
body: The Unravel Server must be in the same region as the target EMR cluster(s) it will be monitoring. There are two possible scenarios:

title: Network
body: Both the EMR cluster and the Unravel Server are created on the same VPC, same subnet; and the security group allows all traffic from the same subnet.

title: Network
body: The EMR cluster is located on a different VPC than Unravel Server. In this case you must configure VPC peering, route table creation, and update the security policy; for instructions, see .

title: Network
body: The Unravel Server needs a TCP and UDP connection to the EMR master node. To implement this, do either of the following:

title: Network
body: Create a security group that allows port 3000 and port 4043 from the EMR cluster node's IP address. Configure the security group on Unravel Server to allow TCP traffic on ports 3000 for EMR cluster nodes.

title: Network
body: Put the member of security group used on the EMR cluster in this rule.

title: Network
body: The Unravel Server and EMR cluster(s) must allow all outbound traffic.

title: Network
body: EMR cluster nodes must allow all traffic from Unravel Server. If you can't allow Unravel Server to access all traffic, you must minimally allow Unravel Server to access cluster nodes' TCP port 8020, 50010, and 50020.

title: Network
body: Non- HTTPS traffic to and from Unravel UI

title: Network
body: UDP and TCP ingest traffic from the entire cluster to Unravel Server(s)

title: Skill Set
body: These instructions assume you're proficient in:

title: Skill Set
body: Provisioning EC2 instances and RDS instances

title: Skill Set
body: Creating and configuring the required IAM roles, security groups, and so on

title: Skill Set
body: Understanding AWS networking concepts such as virtual private clouds (VPCs), subnets, and so on

title: Skill Set
body: Running Ansible scripts, basic Unix commands, and AWS CLI commands

title: Skill Set
body: You don't need to create any scripts or be familiar with any specific programming/scripting language. These instructions are self-contained, and require only basic knowledge of AWS. Expert-level knowledge of AWS is not required.

title: Architecture
body: In order to manage, monitor, and optimize the modern data applications running on your EMR cluster, Unravel Server needs data corresponding to the EMR cluster as well as about the modern data apps running on the cluster. This information includes metrics, configuration information, and logs. Some of this data is pushed to Unravel, and some is pulled by the daemons in Unravel Server. In order for this to work, you must allow both inbound and outbound traffic between Unravel Server (on the EC2 instance) and the EMR cluster. For details, see .

title: Architecture
body: Backing up Unravel amounts to RDS backup (if that is the chosen database) and backing up the state of the Unravel Server. For more information, see .

title: Planning Guidance
body: This section explains what settings you need to specify or give access to, and why.

title: Security Aspects Related to the Unravel Application Itself
body: Security Aspects Related to the Unravel Application Itself

title: Security Aspects Related to the Unravel Application Itself
body: Unravel UI and API are Unravel's user-facing components. For instructions on enabling TLS (SSL) for the Unravel UI, see Enabling TLS.

title: Risk Audit Mechanism
body: Unravel logs its actions on the same EC2 instance that hosts Unravel Server, in /usr/local/unravel/logs/unravel_ngui.log.

title: Costs
body: There are two components of the cost to the user in using Unravel:

title: Costs
body: Cost of the running Amazon EC2 instance that has the Unravel Server deployed on it + Cost of Amazon EBS storage + Cost of RDS (if applicable)

title: Costs
body: Unravel comes with a 30-day trial license. This means you can deploy and use Unravel for 30 days without any additional licenses. To obtain a license after the trial, contact us to discuss your needs and Unravel's terms and conditions.

title: Costs
body: AWS cost allocation tags can be used to track your AWS costs on a detailed level. It is recommended to enable and set both types of cost allocation tags: AWS generated tags as well as user-defined tags. For details, see Using Cost Allocation Tags.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: Email the bundle to the Unravel support team.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: If you used our CloudFormation template to create your Unravel EC2 instance, it's protected by ASG, which sets the target/maximum number of instances at 1. In the rare scenario of this instance failing, ASG will recreate it with the same configuration, and restore its prior history from a backup saved in the S3 bucket. In this case, your existing EMR clusters just need to be reconnected to the newly created Unravel EC2 node as described in Step 2: Connect the Unravel EC2 Instance to a New/Existing EMR Cluster.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: If you're done with the Unravel EC2 instance, you can delete it as follows.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: From your EC2 console (https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudformation/), select the EC2 instance you want to delete.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: In the Actions pull-down menu, select Delete Stack.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: Monitor the Status column to make sure the deletion is complete. If deletion fails, disable auto scaling via the EC2 console (menu on left), otherwise Amazon will keep re-spawning the EC2 instance.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: You may see this common error:

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: org.apache.oozie.action.ActionExecutorException: JA010: Property [fs.default.name] not allowed in action [job-xml] configuration

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: The reason behind can be older version of configuration where some properties being deprecated. The straightforward solution is to comment out the <job-xml> element in the workflow.xml file.

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: Unravel UI Displays Insufficient Historical Data

title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
body: In Manage | Core | Retention | TIME SERIES RETENTION DAYS, adjust the number of days to retain data. This corresponds to the com.unraveldata.retention.max.days property.

title: Setting Up Amazon RDS (Optional)
body: Unravel's default installation uses a bundled database for part of its storage. For better performance and ease of management, we recommend replacing the bundled database with an Amazon RDS instance.

title: Create an RDS Security Group, Subnet Group, and Parameter Group
body: Create an RDS security group on the VPC of Unravel Server and allow access from Unravel Server security group.

title: Create an RDS Security Group, Subnet Group, and Parameter Group
body: Create a new database subnet group.

title: Create an RDS Security Group, Subnet Group, and Parameter Group
body: A new database subnet group is required for "multiple availability zone" (multi-AZ) deployment. The VPC should at least contains two subnets in at least two availability zones in a given region, in the same VPC. For more information, see AWS documentation.

title: Create an RDS Security Group, Subnet Group, and Parameter Group
body: Create a new database parameter group , based on mysql 5.5, with custom MySQL settings.

key_buffer_size = 268435456 
 max_allowed_packet = 33554432

 read_buffer_size = 262144 
 read_rnd_buffer_size = 4194304 
 max_connect_errors=2000000000 
 net-read-timeout = 300 
 net-write-timeout = 600 
 open_files_limit=9000 
 innodb_open_files=9000 
 character_set_server=utf8

 innodb_autoextend_increment=100 
 innodb_additional_mem_pool_size = 20971520

title: Setting Up VPC Peering (Optional)

title: Setting Up VPC Peering (Optional)

title: Setting Up VPC Peering (Optional)

title: Setting Up VPC Peering (Optional)
body: Network ACLs on both the VPC for Unravel EC2 and the EMR cluster are the default and allow all traffic. The security group is the only security enforcement on network access.

title: Setting Up VPC Peering (Optional)

title: Reconnecting to Your EMR Cluster
body: If you used our CloudFormation template to create your Unravel EC2 instance, it's protected by ASG, which sets the target/maximum number of instances at 1. In the rare scenario of your EC2 instance failing, ASG will recreate it with the same configuration, and restore its prior history from a backup saved in an S3 bucket. In this case, your existing EMR clusters just need to be reconnected to the newly created Unravel EC2 instance as described in .

title: Deleting the Unravel EC2 Instance
body: In the Actions pull-down menu, select Delete Stack.

title: Deleting the Unravel EC2 Instance
body: Monitor the Status column to make sure the deletion is complete. If deletion fails, disable auto scaling via the EC2 console (menu on left), otherwise Amazon will keep re-spawning the EC2 instance.

title: Backup and Recovery
body: Best practice is to prepare in advance for disaster like instance failure by backing up and restoring your deployment.

title: Backup and Recovery
body: It is required for the Unravel EC2 instance to be in the same region with the target EMR clusters which Unravel EC2 node will be monitoring. So the region recovery does not apply for Unravel. Unravel is designed to maintain business continuity and does not support complete/true high availability (HA).

title: Routine Maintenance

title: Routine Maintenance

title: Emergency Maintenance
body: In the event of fault conditions, such as a transient failure of an AWS Service such that the availability of EC2 in a particular availability zone (AZ) is degraded, or a more permanent failure of an AWS service such that EC2 instance has faulted, or an EC2 Scheduled Maintenance Event is received, the best course of action to take in such situations is to have followed the process of backing-up and disaster recovery as described in . Unravel is designed to maintain business continuity and does not support complete/true High Availability (HA).

title: Microsoft Azure HDInsight
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel on Microsoft Azure HDInsight.

title: Microsoft Azure HDInsight
body: Installing Unravel as a separate Azure VM allows you to connect to ephemeral Hadoop clusters on the same virtual network.

title: Installing Unravel on a Separate Azure VM
body: This option involves the following steps:

title: Installing Unravel on a Separate Azure VM
Installing Unravel on a Separate Azure VM
Installing Unravel on a Separate Azure VM
Create Azure Storage
body: This topic explains how to create Azure storage appropriate for your Hadoop cluster, which could be Kafka or Spark.

title: Create Azure Storage
body: First, you need to determine which storage type is appropriate for your cluster and supported by Unravel. You have the following options:

title: Create Azure Storage
body: By default HDInsight 3.6 uses Blob storage, which is a general-purpose storage type for Big Data. Blob storage is a key-value store with a flat namespace. It has full support for:

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Analytics workloads; batch, interactive, streaming analytics

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Machine learning data such as log files, IoT data, click streams, large datasets

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Unravel doesn't support encryption (SSL) with Blob storage (WASB).

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Azure Data Lake Storage generation 1 (ADLS v1)

title: Create Azure Storage
body: The other major option for Hadoop clusters is ADLS v1. ADLS is a hierarchical file system. It has full support for

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Analytics workloads; batch, interactive, streaming analytics

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Machine learning data such as log files, IoT data, click streams, large datasets

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Azure Data Lake Storage generation 2 (ADLS v2) (Preview mode)

title: Create Azure Storage
body: ADLS generation 2 combines the features of Blob storage andADLS generation 1.

title: Create Azure Storage
body: Unravel has not been tested with ADLS v2 since it is still in preview mode.

title: Create Azure Storage
body: The rest of this document refers to these storage types as Blob and ADLS.

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have an Azure account and able to log into https://portal.azure.com

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have a resource group assigned to a region in order to group your policies, VMs, and storage blobs/lakes/drives.

title: Prerequisites
body: A resource group is a container that holds related resources for an Azure solution. In Azure, you logically group related resources such as storage accounts, virtual networks, and virtual machines (VMs) to deploy, manage, and maintain them as a single entity.

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have a virtual network for your resource group. This virtual network will be shared by your Hadoop cluster and the Unravel VM.

title: Steps
body: On the Basics tab, enter values for the following fields:

title: Steps
body: Resource Group: Select the resource group to associate with this storage instance.

title: Steps
body: Storage Account Name: Enter a name, using lowercase letters and numbers.

title: Steps
body: Location: Select a data center region.

title: Steps
body: Standard storage uses magnetic disks and is cheaper. Premium storage uses SSDs, so it has higher performance and is recommended for Spark and Kafka clusters.

title: Steps
body: Account kind: Select your storage type: Blob or Storage (ADLS v1)

title: Steps
body: StorageV2 (ADLS v2) is still in preview mode and is not currently supported by Unravel.

title: Steps
body: Replication: Select your desired replication to either be local, or always available in the same zone, region, or replicated geographically. See more choices in the Advanced section.

title: Steps
body: Locally redundant storage (LRS): Only handles failures within the data-center. Durability guarantee is 11 9's.

title: Steps
body: Zone-redundant storage (ZRS): Handles failures in the data-center and zone, but not region. Durability guarantee is 12 9's. Only supported on ADLS v2.

title: Steps
body: Geo-redundant storage (GRS): Handles failures in the data-center, zone, and region, but does not allow read-access in another region in a failure scenario. Durability guarantee is 16 9's.

title: Steps
body: Read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS) FIXLINK: Handles failures in the data-center, zone, region, and allows read-access in another region. Durability guarantee is 16 9's.

title: Steps
body: Access Tier: Only available for Blob storage & ADLS v2 (which is not currently supported by Unravel). If you pick this option, select hot storage.

title: Steps
body: Set Secure transfer required to Disabled or Enabled.

title: Steps
body: Unravel doesn't support encryption (SSL) with Blob storage (WASB).

title: Steps
body: For Virtual Networks,select whether to allow traffic from all networks or only from within the virtual network and subnet(s) you specify.

title: Steps
body: If your settings are correct, click Create. To edit your settings, click Previous.

title: Related Resources
body: Finding Unravel Properties' Values in Microsoft Azure

title: Creating and Configuring the Azure VM

title: Prerequisites

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have a resource group assigned to a region in order to group your policies, VMs, and storage blobs/lakes/drives.

title: Prerequisites
body: A resource group is a container that holds related resources for an Azure solution. In Azure, you logically group related resources such as storage accounts, virtual networks, and virtual machines (VMs) to deploy, manage, and maintain them as a single entity.

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have a virtual network and network security group set up for your resource group. Your virtual network and subnet(s) must be big enough to be shared by the Unravel VM and the target HDInsight cluster(s).

title: Prerequisites
body: You must already have created a storage system. For instructions, see Create Azure Storage.

title: Prerequisites
body: You must have an SSH key pair.

title: Prerequisites
body: Your VM host must meet the requirements below.

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Storage type: Blob (WASB) or ADLS v1

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Limitations: Unravel currently only works with Blob (WASB) or ADLS v1. It does not support multiple Azure Data Lake Storage accounts or ADLS v2 (preview).

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Limitations: Spark relies on the yarn-site configuration property yarn.log-aggregation.file-formats, whose only supported value is TFile. In other words:

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Image (underlying operating system for the VM)

body: Note that the actual HDInsight Kafka/Spark cluster can run another OS.

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Minimum VM type suggested: Medium memory optimized such as Standard_E8s_v3

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: min 100GB for /srv on 2nd disk (recommended at least 500 GB SSD disk for /srv volume)

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Unravel VM should be located in the same VNET and VSNET as the HDInsight cluster

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Port 443 open on Hadoop cluster for Azure HDInsight to monitor applications

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Port 3000 (or 4020) for Unravel Web UI access

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: UDP and TCP ports 4041-4043 open from Hadoop cluster to Unravel Server

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: HDFS ports open from Hadoop cluster to Unravel Server

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Hive MetaStore DB port open to Unravel Server for partition reporting

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: For Oozie, port 11000 open to Unravel Server

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Allows inbound ssh to the unravel VM

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Allows outbound Internet access and all traffic within the subnet (VSNET).

title: Support Chart and VM Requirements
body: Allows TCP port 3000 and 4043 to Unravel VM from HDInsight cluster

body: Install ntpd, start it at boot time, and check whether time is accurate. This is necessary in order to synchronize your VM's clock. For more information about ntpd, see https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Network_Time_Protocol_daemon.

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body:
sudo su -
yum install ntp
ntpd -u ntp:ntp

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body: Disable Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux) permanently. This is important because HDFS maintains replication in different nodes/racks, so setting firewall rules in SELinux will lead to performance degradation.

title: Configure the VM at First Login

body: Libaio has a huge performance benefit over the standard POSIX asynchronous I/O facility because the operations are performed in the Linux kernel instead of as a separate user process.

body: Disable the firewall and check your iptable rules.

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body:
sudo systemctl disable firewalld
sudo systemctl stop firewalld
sudo iptables -F
sudo iptables -L

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body: Prepare the second disk (for example, /dev/sdc) with at least 500 GB that was configured previously on Azure portal. Use fdisk -l to check any 500GB disk without partition. This step requires root privilege.

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body:
sudo su -
 
 
# List all disks and partitions
# You should see one called "sdc" if you attached a 500-1000 GB disk.
fdisk -l
fdisk /dev/sdc
# p (list current partitions)
# n (new partition)
# p (primary)
# Keep accepting rest of default configs.
# w (save)
 
# Format the disk
/usr/sbin/mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdc
 
 
mkdir -p /srv
 
DISKUUID=`/usr/sbin/blkid |grep ext4 |grep sdc | awk '{ print $2}' |sed -e 's/"//g'`
echo $DISKUUID
 
# Mount the disk on /srv
echo "${DISKUUID} /srv ext4 defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab
mount /dev/sdc1 /srv
 
# Verify the disk space
df -hT /srv
 
Filesystem Type Size Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sdc1 ext4 197G 61M 187G 1% /srv
 
 
# Set permissions for Unravel and symlink Unravel's directories to the /srv mount
mkdir -p /srv/local/unravel
chmod -R 755 /srv/local
ln -s /srv/local/unravel /usr/local/unravel
chmod 755 /usr/local/unravel

title: Configure the VM at First Login
body: Create the hdfs user and the hadoop group.

title: Configure the VM at First Login

sudo useradd hdfs
sudo groupadd hadoop
sudo usermod -a -G hadoop hdfs

title: Connecting Unravel to the HDInsight Cluster
body: This topic explains how to spin up a Hadoop, HBase, Spark, or Kafka cluster, configure the cluster with a script action, and connect it to Unravel Server.

title: Connecting Unravel to the HDInsight Cluster
body: Before Unravel can analyze any job running on your HDInsight cluster, the Unravel server and sensors must be deployed on the cluster nodes through an Azure "script action".

title: Connecting Unravel to the HDInsight Cluster
body: For HDInsight clusters without Internet access, you can download these scripts and store them in your Azure blob storage and use the blob storage URI on the script action's Bash script URI field.

title: Connecting Unravel to the HDInsight Cluster
body: Unravel provides two types of "script actions" depending on the type of cluster.

Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body: After the Kafka script action script completed successfully, open an SSH session to the Kafka cluster's "head node" and append the contents of /tmp/unravel/unravel.ext.properties to /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties on your Unravel VM.

title: Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body: In a multi-cluster deployment, com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.clusters is a comma-separated list of clusters and the set of properties prefixed with com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name are repeated for each cluster.

title: Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body: For example, for two Kafka clusters, /tmp/unravel/unravel.ext.properties looks like this:

title: Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body:
# Adding Kafka properties
Adding Kafka properties
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.clusters=cluster_name1, cluster_name2
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.bootstrap_servers=wn0-cluster_name1:9092,wn1-cluster_name1:9092
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.jmx_servers=broker1,broker2
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.jmx.broker1.host=wn0-cluster_name1
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.jmx.broker1.port=9999
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.jmx.broker2.host=wn1-cluster_name1
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name1.jmx.broker2.port=9999

com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.bootstrap_servers=wn0-cluster_name2:9092,wn1-cluster_name2:9092
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.jmx_servers=broker1,broker2
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.jmx.broker1.host=wn0-cluster_name2
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.jmx.broker1.port=9999
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.jmx.broker2.host=wn1-cluster_name2
com.unraveldata.ext.kafka.cluster_name2.jmx.broker2.port=9999

title: Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body: Unravel VM must have access to the Kafka worker nodes' broker port 9092 and Kafka JMX port 9999

title: Option C: Connecting to Existing Kafka Cluster(s)
body: After updating the Kafka properties, restart Unravel Server.

title: Troubleshooting Tips
body: From the Azure portal, you can check if a script action finished successfully by checking the SCRIPT ACTION HISTORY:

title: Troubleshooting Tips
body: If script action process fails, you can check the error messages from the HDInsight cluster's Ambari dashboard, which has a balloon next to the cluster name on the top menu bar with the recent operations.

title: Troubleshooting Tips
body: Click Ops and search for the most recent run_customscriptaction command and inspect the log messages. You may see multiple entries of run_customscriptaction which were created by previous runs.

title: Troubleshooting Tips
body: The Unravel script action cannot be rerun. If you need to redeploy the Unravel script action, you must submit a new "script action" script with a different name.

title: Upgrading the Unravel VM
body: To check for new releases of Unravel's VM, see Download Unravel Software Versions. To upgrade your existing Unravel Azure VM, download the new unravel VM package and install it.

title: Upgrading the Unravel VM
body: Upgrading the Unravel VM or app should not affect operations on the connected HDInsight cluster and can be done at any time. However, in some cases you'll also need to upgrade your Unravel Sensor(s) as well, and this requires you to re-submit the Unravel action scripts to head, worker, and edge nodes.

title: Using Azure HDInsight APIs
body: This section explains how to use the Azure CLI for common actions.

title: Using Azure HDInsight APIs
body: Best practice is to install the Azure CLI on a docker container.

title: Submit a Script Action
body: To sign in, use a web browser to open the page https://microsoft.com/devicelogin and enter the code ######### to authenticate.

title: Submit a Script Action

title: Submit a Script Action
body: -p is a list of input paramaters for the script

title: Submit a Script Action

title: Submit a Script Action
body: azure hdinsight script-action create DEVCLUSTER -g UNRAVEL01 -n unravel-script-action -u https://raw.githubusercontent.com/unravel-data/public/master/hdi/hdinsight-unravel-spark-script-action/unravel_hdi_spark_bootstrap_3.0.sh -p 'unravel-server 128.164.0.1:3000 --spark-version 2.3.0' -t "headnode;workernode;edgenode"

title: Create an Edge Node
body: An Edge Node is a VM on an HDInsight cluster that only has the Hadoop client installed instead of any servers or daemons.

title: Create an Edge Node

title: Create an Edge Node

title: Create an Edge Node
body: Option B: An edge node that only runs a simple script, emptynode-setup.sh

title: Create an Edge Node

title: Create an Edge Node

title: Create an Edge Node
body: az group deployment validate --resource-group "$RESOURCEGROUP" --template- file azuredeploy.json --parameters azuredeploy.parameters.json { "error": null, ... "provisioningState": "Succeeded", ... }

title: Create an Edge Node
body: This should take 10-15 minutes to run since it has to provision a VM and install the Hadoop binaries.

title: Create an Edge Node

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: HDInsight allows you to resize your cluster up/down to meet your current demands.

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: From the Azure portal, navigate to HDInsight Clusters | your-cluster | Cluster Size.

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: Enter your desired number of workers and validate that you have enough resources for your resource group and region (based on any quotas).

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: For downsizing, HDInsight runs the Decommission command some number of workers on the DataNode, NodeManager, and HBase RegionServer processes (if it exists). Once drained, it removes the VM from Ambari and then from the cluster.

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: For upsizing, HDInsight provisions new VM, installs the Hadoop bits, and adds the worker components (DataNode, NodeManager, and potentially HBase RegionServer).

title: Auto-Scale the Cluster
body: If the Unravel script action was also "persisted" to run on "worker nodes", then new VMs will automatically run a custom command for the Unravel bootstrap script.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: Amazon Athena is a serverless query service that lets you interact with data directly in place on AWS S3 using ANSI standard SQL. You pay only for the queries you run, based on how much data the queries scan. Failed queries cost $0. For cancelled or killed queries, you're charged only for the data that was scanned before the queries were cancelled. For more information on Athena pricing, see Amazon's Athena pricing. Since you’re charged per scan per query, you can use Unravel to show you the cost per Athena query.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: This feature is in beta/preview mode. Currently, Unravel UI doesn't display insights and recommendations on Athena queries.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: Preview features are in beta and are subject to change. The design and code is less mature than official GA features and is being provided as-is with no warranties. Preview features are not subject to the support SLA of official GA features. We do not recommend you deploy Preview features in a production environment.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: This feature is available only in releases that include updates to our Amazon EMR support, such as 4.5.0.5. To determine which release includes Amazon Athena support, check the Unravel Compatibility Matrix.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: Amazon Athena is well suited to structured data such as logs.

title: Amazon Athena (Preview Only)
body: You send Unravel information about your Athena queries through an AWS Lambda function which monitors your AWS CloudTrail trail for Athena events.

body: This topic explains how to install and use your own MySQL with Unravel.

title: Install and Configure MySQL for Unravel
body: To use MySQL with Unravel, follow these steps.

title: Before Installing the Unravel RPM
body: Do the following steps before installing the Unravel RPM.

title: Before Installing the Unravel RPM
body:
wget https://dev.mysql.com/get/mysql80-community-release-el6-1.noarch.rpm
sudo yum install yum-utils
sudo rpm -ivh mysql80-community-release-el6-1.noarch.rpm
sudo yum-config-manager --disable mysql80-community
sudo yum-config-manager --enable mysql57-community
sudo yum install mysql-community-server

title: Before Installing the Unravel RPM
body:
wget https://dev.mysql.com/get/mysql80-community-release-el7-1.noarch.rpm
sudo rpm -ivh mysql80-community-release-el7-1.noarch.rpm
sudo yum-config-manager --disable mysql80-community
sudo yum-config-manager --enable mysql57-community
sudo yum install mysql-community-server

title: Before Installing the Unravel RPM
body: If you are installing MySQL on an SELinux host and are not using the default datadir, see .

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: Stop MySQL server if it is running.

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: Backup old InnoDB log files to a directory of your choosing, backup-path. If there is no need to backup any data, you must delete the /var/lib/mysql/ib_logfile* files:

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: Append the following properties at the end of the [mysqld] section in the MySQL configuration file (/etc/my.cnf by default), and set datadir to the directory your choice. This directory must have a minimum capacity of 500GB.

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body:
key_buffer_size = 256M
max_allowed_packet = 32M
sort_buffer_size = 32M
query_cache_size = 64M
max_connections = 500
max_connect_errors = 2000000000
open_files_limit = 10000
port-open-timeout = 121
expire-logs-days = 1
character_set_server = utf8
collation_server = utf8_unicode_ci
innodb_open_files = 2000
innodb_file_per_table = 1
innodb_data_file_path = ibdata1:100M:autoextend
# The innodb_buffer_pool_size depends on load and cluster size.
# On a dedicated machine, it can be 50% of the RAM size.
# Using 1G is the absolute minimum. For a large cluster, we use 48G.
innodb_buffer_pool_size = 4G
innodb_flush_method = O_DIRECT
innodb_log_file_size = 256M
innodb_log_buffer_size = 64M
innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit = 2
innodb_lock_wait_timeout = 50
innodb_thread_concurrency = 20
innodb_read_io_threads = 16
innodb_write_io_threads = 4
binlog_format = mixed
# if SSD disk is used uncomment the line below
#innodb_io_capacity = 4000

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: Ensure MySQL server starts at boot time.

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: In the MySQL configuration file (typically /etc/my.cnf), check the following items:

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: sudo grep "^datadir=" /etc/my.cnf | awk -F"[=]" '{print $2}' | sudo xargs du -sh

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: Available file system disk space for MySQL's "datadir":

title: Configure and Start MySQL Server
body: sudo grep "^datadir=" /etc/my.cnf | awk -F"[=]" '{print $2}' | sudo xargs df -h

title: Install MySQL JDBC Driver
body: Download the JDBC driver for MySQL to /tmp.

title: Install MySQL JDBC Driver
body: Navigate to /tmp and extract the driver.

title: After Installing the Unravel RPM
body: Copy the MySQL JDBC JAR to /usr/local/unravel/share/java/.

title: After Installing the Unravel RPM
body:
sudo mkdir -p /usr/local/unravel/share/java
sudo cp /tmp/mysql-connector-java-5.1.47/mysql-connector-java-5.1.47.jar /usr/local/unravel/share/java
sudo cp /tmp/mysql-connector-java-5.1.47/mysql-connector-java-5.1.47.jar /usr/local/unravel/dlib/unravel

title: After Installing the Unravel RPM
body: Configure Unravel to connect to the MySQL server.

title: After Installing the Unravel RPM
body: Create the default admin user for Unravel UI.

title: Disable PostgreSQL
body: Once you have successfully configured Unravel to use the MySQL database, ensure that the unravel_pg PostgreSQL database is turned off and the service deactivated for all run levels. In other words, run this command on the Unravel host(s):

title: Disable PostgreSQL
body: service unravel_pg stop; chkconfig unravel_pg off

title: Move MySQL to a Custom Location
body: Depending on your deployment, follow the steps in one of the sections below.

title: Move MySQL to a Custom Location
body: If you're using Unravel bundled MySQL, see Move a Bundled MySQL.

title: Move MySQL to a Custom Location
body: If you're using an external MySQL, see Move an External MySQL.

title: Move MySQL to a Custom Location
body: Whichever move you perform, you must do a slow shutdown () which increases the time to stop MySQL.

title: Move MySQL to a Custom Location
body: If you need to move MySQL to another host, you need to install MySQL first on the new host. For instructions, see here.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: The daemon user must have read/write access to the new path.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: Perform a slow shutdown () of the MySQL server and make sure that it stops without errors.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: Get DB root password from /root/unravel.install.include or /root/unravel.install.include.prev.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: Run the following commands to set MySQL clean shutdown.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: Restore MySQL datadir to the custom path. Replace NEW_DB_LOCATION with the fully qualified path to the directory you want to place MySQL data base.

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body:
cp unravel_db_data.tar NEW_DB_LOCATION
cd NEW_DB_LOCATION # tar xvf unravel_db_data.tar

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: Update unravel.install.include and the MySQL .cnf file:

title: Move a Bundled MySQL
body: In /usr/local/unravel/mysql/unravel_mysql.cnf set both innodb_data_home_dir and innodb_log_group_home_dir to NEW_DB_LOCATION .

title: Move an External MySQL
body: The MySQL user must have read/write access to the new path.

title: Move an External MySQL
body: Perform a slow shutdown () of the MySQL server and make sure that it stops without errors.

title: Move an External MySQL
body: Run the following commands to set MySQL clean shutdown.

title: Move an External MySQL
body: Restore MySQL datadir to the custom path. Replace NEW_DB_LOCATION with the fully qualified path to the directory you want to place MySQL data base.

title: Move an External MySQL
body: cp unravel_db_data.tar NEW_DB_LOCATION # cd {NEW_DB_LOCATION} # tar xvf unravel_db_data.tar

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: MySQL is not bundled with Unravel and you must manually migrate Unravel's tables for its use. The time for the data migration varies by machine and MySQL configuration.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: Unravel uses the following partitioned tables:

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: For external MySQL servers you might need to change the chunk size to 100 or 1000.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: When all the tables have been successfully migrated you see:

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: During the process a temporary migration_partitioning DB table keeps track of the tables' status. You can view this table using the following MySQL query.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: The chunks field increases until the migration for the table is complete. Upon completion the table's finished column is set to 1.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: To see the oldest migrated records per each table you can use the following MySQL query.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body:
/usr/local/unravel/install_bin/db_access.sh

mysql>
select "blackboards" as "table_name", min(created_at) as "oldest_migrated_record" from blackboards
union select "event_instances", min(created_at) from event_instances
union select "hive_queries", min(created_at) from hive_queries
union select "impala_queries", min(created_at) from impala_queries
union select "jobs", min(created_at) from jobs
union select "oozie_workflow_jobs", min(created_at) from oozie_workflow_jobs;
+---------------------+------------------------+
| table_name | oldest_migrated_record |
+---------------------+------------------------+
| blackboards | 2018-08-30 00:57:45 |
| event_instances | 2018-08-30 00:57:55 |
| hive_queries | 2018-08-30 00:59:10 |
| impala_queries | NULL |
| jobs | 2018-08-30 00:57:50 |
| oozie_workflow_jobs | 2018-09-07 10:25:22 |
+---------------------+------------------------+

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: If the migration process is interrupted or killed, you can run shell script again. However, if the process has failed you must truncate and reset ID's before running the script again.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
body: During migration the original files were renamed to TableName_old. Upon completion, delete these and the migration_partitioning table.

title: MySQL Partitioning and Data Migration
Restarting a Failed Migration
body: Truncate partitioned tables, reset autoincrement ID values and truncate migration_partitioning table.

Restarting a Failed Migration

title: Start the OnDemand Daemon
body: Execute the following four commands in the order shown, replacing run-as-user and run-as-group with the username and group you used when running switch_to_user during Unravel server installation.

title: Start the OnDemand Daemon
body:
sudo systemctl stop unravel_ondemand.service
sudo chown -RL run-as-user:run-as-group /usr/local/unravel/ondemand/
sudo service unravel_all.sh restart
sudo systemctl start unravel_ondemand.service

title: Start the OnDemand Daemon
body:
sudo service unravel_ondemand stop
sudo chown -RL run-as-user:run-as-group /usr/local/unravel/ondemand/
sudo service unravel_all.sh restart
sudo service unravel_ondemand start

title: Start the OnDemand Daemon
body: Confirm that the OnDemand service is running:

title: Start the OnDemand Daemon
body: You should see output similar to the example below. Process IDs vary based on the number of processors in Unravel Server, number of current tasks, and so on.
