body: This section lists common ways you can customize Unravel for your environment, services, and apps. These steps are all optional.

title: Next Steps
body: Set com.unraveldata.customer.organization to your company name.

title: Next Steps
body: Users access Unravel through the Unravel UI. The installation process creates one administrator account.

title: Next Steps
body: To add more administrators, see Add more admins to Unravel UI.

title: Next Steps
body: To add read-only administrators, see Add read-only admins.

title: Next Steps
body: To add LDAP authentication for Unravel UI, see and modify the

title: Next Steps
body: To add SAML authentication for Unravel UI, see enable SAML authentication and modify the .

title: Next Steps
body: To use role-based access control (RBAC) to restrict the views and applications users can see when they log into Unravel UI, see Roles and Role Based Access Control.

title: Next Steps
body: To enable TLS (SSL) for the Unravel UI, see Enabling TLS.

title: Next Steps
body: Create multiple workers for high volume data.

title: Next Steps
body: Enable live monitoring of Spark streaming applications.

title: Next Steps
body: Install the OnDemand service to allow Unravel to generate the following OnDemand-based reports:

title: Next Steps
body: Sessions are enabled by default. To disable or configure them, set the sessions properties.

title: Next Steps
body: Cluster Optimization Reports are enabled by default. There are no specific properties to set.

title: Next Steps
body: Cloud Reports and Forecasting Reports require that you set the cloud and forecasting properties to enable or configure them.

title: Next Steps
body: Small Files Reports and File Reports are enabled by default. To disable or configure them, see enabling small files and file reports.

title: Next Steps
body: Queue Analysis Reports are enabled by default. To disable or configure them, set the queue analysis properties.

title: Next Steps
body: Top X Reports are enabled by default. To disable or configure them, set the Top X properties.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: Contact Unravel Support at before upgrading from Unravel 4.2.x or 4.3.x to Unravel 4.5.x

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: To determine if it's mandatory to upgrade Unravel sensors when you upgrade Unravel Server, see the release notes.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: This topic explains how to upgrade the Unravel Server RPM in a single or multi-host environment. If you have a single host for Unravel Server, run only the commands that are marked host1 in each step below.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: Copy the new RPM to each Unravel host.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body:
# host1 
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh stop 
# host1 
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh stop 
# host3
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh stop

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: Upgrade the RPM on each host simultaneously.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body:
# host1
sudo rpm -U unravel-version.rpm* 
# host2
sudo rpm -U unravel-version.rpm* 
# host3
sudo rpm -U unravel-version.rpm*

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: Add your license key to unravel.properties.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: Add your license key to unravel.properties before starting or restarting Unravel Server.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body: After all the RPM upgrades finish, restart Unravel Server on each host simultaneously.

title: Upgrade Unravel Server
body:
# host1
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh start 
# host2
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh start 
# host23
sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh start

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: Only activate the sensors when there are no Hive or Spark jobs running as the restart may affect running jobs.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: In Cloudera Manager, check for newer versions of UNRAVEL_SENSOR.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: In Cloudera Manager, click the parcel icon in the top menu bar.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: Click Check for New Parcels and look for UNRAVEL_SENSOR entries.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: If newer sensors are available, Cloudera Manager indicates this.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: Click Download | Distribute, and activate the newer version of the sensors.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: When activating the new sensors, Cloudera Manager notifies you that Hive and Spark services must be restarted.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
body: When activation is complete, Cloudera Manager automatically disables the old version.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a CDH Cluster
Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: unravel-host is the Unravel Server's fully qualified domain name or IP address.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: spark-version is the target Spark version. For example, 1.6.0, 2.0.1, 2.2.0.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: hive-version is the target Hive version For example, 1.2.0.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: Only activate the sensors when there are no Hive or Spark jobs running as the restart may affect running jobs.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: On Unravel Server and on all nodes in the cluster that have Unravel Sensors deployed, create backups of the old sensor folders and then remove the folders.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body:
cd /usr/local/
sudo tar -cvf unravel-sensors-`date +%m%d%y`.tar unravel-agent unravel_client
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/unravel-agent
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/unravel_client

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: On Unravel Server, run the sensor package script.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body:
cd /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/unraveldata-clients/
sudo ./unravel_hdp_setup.sh install -y --unravel-server unravel-host:3000 --spark-version spark-version --hive-version hive-version

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: Running the sensor package script creates the sensor packages in /usr/local/unravel-agent and /usr/local/unravel_client.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: Compress /usr/local/unravel-agent and /usr/local/unravel_client and copy the compressed file (unravel-new-sensors.tar) to all nodes in the cluster.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body:
cd /usr/local/
tar -cvf unravel-new-sensors.tar unravel-agent unravel_client
scp unravel-new-sensors.tar cluster-node:/usr/local/

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
body: On the cluster node, extract the copied unravel-new-sensors.tar file on the cluster nodes.

title: Upgrade Sensors on an HDP Cluster
Upgrade Sensors on a MapR Cluster
body: unravel-host is the Unravel Server's fully qualified domain name or IP address.

title: Upgrade Sensors on a MapR Cluster
body: spark-version is the target Spark version. For example, 1.6.0, 2.0.1, 2.2.0.

cd /opt/mapr/spark/spark-spark-version/conf/

cd /usr/local/

User Guide
body: Unravel Web UI helps you to analyze, optimize, and troubleshoot big data applications and operations.

title: How to run Spark applications reliably and optimize performance
Unravel automated root cause analysis demo
Common UI Features
body: Every page has the Unravel title Bar. The pages available to you are listed on the left. The page you are viewing is underlined and listed in the black bar. To the right there is a search box, Docs Button, possibly a support button, and a pull-down menu.

title: Common UI Features
body: If you are an end-user restricted by Role Based Access Control, you can only view a subset of the UI's pages and the pull-down menu only has About and Logout options.

title: Common UI Features
body: If you are an unrestricted end-user or an admin, all the pages are available with possible read/write restrictions. The pull-down menu has Manage, About and Logout available.

title: Common UI Features
body: If your admin has disabled Support there is no Support Button, for example,

title: Common UI Features
body: If you can configure the date range, time period, or cluster(s) these options will be available in the title bar. You set them using the pull down menus on the banner.

title: Common UI Features
body: When there are multiple tabs, click on the tab to display its contents.

title: Common UI Features
body: When detailed or further information is available open section () is in the upper right-hand corner; click on it for further information.

title: Common UI Features
body: To expand a section to full tile width, click ; click on to close it.

title: Common UI Features
body: Clicking on the application name/id/workflow usually bring ups information on the application, fragment etc, e.g., the Spark Application Manager, table information, etc.

title: Common UI Features
body: Hovering over an auto action alert () brings up the list auto actions the job has violated ().

title: Common UI Features
body: Can be sorted by a column, i.e., start time, in ascending or descending order. The sort column highlights the arrow indicating the sort order (). Click on the column name to use it for the sort.

title: Common UI Features
body: Clicking on a column being used reverses the sort order.

title: Common UI Features
body: If you can choose which columns to display a plus () is on the right end of the table header. Click on it to see the column headings; un/check the column heading to show/hide the column.

title: Common UI Features
body: When applicable, the application status is color coded: , , , , ,

title: Common UI Features
body: Clicking on the app name/id/workflow usually brings up the information on the app, i.e., the Spark Application Manager, table information, etc.

title: Common UI Features
body: When applicable, the Notifications column () notes if Unravel has tuning suggestions (), an Auto Action alert () or both ().

title: Common UI Features
body: When relevant there is an Auto Actions/Events column (). The number of auto actions/events (0-n) triggered is noted.

title: Common UI Features
body: When an application has a parent a link to it will appear in the GoTo column (), its title bar or a more info glyph (). Click on it to display the app's parent APM.

title: Common UI Features
body: A block glyph () allows you to open the row details in a block below the tile. Click on it open/close the block. Green indicates the block is currently being displayed; it's gray when the block is closed.

title: Common UI Features
body: Hovering over a line in a graph causes the information to be displayed in a text box ().

title: Common UI Features
body: "Applications running at mm/dd/yy hh:mm:ss" is displayed below the graph(s) with a list of relevant applications, if any, displayed. Clicking within the graph displays the relevant, if any, applications for that point in time.

title: Common UI Features
body: Clicking Show More () expands the chart to the full width of your browser. Click on the close window on the right side of title bar to return to the previous view.

title: Common UI Features
body: If the graph can be displayed based upon Group By, Tags, Metric, etc., a pull down box will be displayed () in the upper right-hand corner.

title: Common UI Features
body: Click to print or download the information in the graph in various forms, i.e., jpg, png, csv.

title: Common UI Features
body: If you can zoom in/out of a diagram/execution graph there are magnifiers (, ) in the upper right-hand corner. Click to return to the initial view.

title: The Operations Page
body: The Operations Page provides a synopsis of your cluster(s) and its activities. It has two tabs:

title: The Operations Page
body: By default, it opens showing Operations > Dashboard tab.

title: The Operations Page
body: See Common UI Features for general information about Unravel's UI.

title: Dashboard
body: To view the Dashboard, click Operations > Dashboard.

title: Dashboard
body: The Dashboard provides an overview of cluster activities with links to drill down into YARN applications, resource usage, application inefficiencies, and events/alerts. By default, it is configured to display all clusters hourly for the past 24 hours.

title: Finished YARN applications Tile
body: The line graphs display the successful, failed, and killed jobs for the time period, using the time increment and cluster(s) specified. It textually displays the total number over the time period.

title: Finished YARN applications Tile
body: Clicking on Open Section brings up the window Applications > Applications window listing all applications. See Finding Applications for more detail on this view.

title: Running YARN Application Tile
body: The line graphs display the running and pending jobs for the current time. It textually displays the total number at the current time period.

title: Running YARN Application Tile
body: Clicking on Open Section opens Operations > Usage Details > Jobs. See here for more information about this view.

title: Resources Tile
body: Displays the available and allocated Vcore and memory for the entire cluster.

title: Resources Tile
body: Clicking on Open Section opens Operations > Usage Details > Infrastructure. See below for an example of this view.

title: Inefficient Applications Tile
body: Its three sub-tabs, HIVE, MapReduce, and Spark, each list the inefficiencies that have occurred for that job type and the number of apps experiencing it. Click on the sub-tab to change the application type. Click on the Event Name to bring up the list of applications that experienced the event.

title: Inefficient Applications Tile
body: This Inefficient Applications list is equivalent to Applications > Applications except it only displays applications that have experienced the event. The event type is noted in the upper left-hand corner. See Finding Applications for more detail on this view.

title: Recent Events and Alerts Sidebar
body: The sidebar lists all events and alerts that have occurred organized by date and time. A separate entry appears for each time a particular Auto Action was triggered. In the image below, the same auto action triggered at 23:56 and 2:58. Clicking an event/alert brings up a Cluster Resource view (Operations > Usage Detail > Infrastructure) displaying a 10-minute time slice (±5 minutes of the event) and includes a list of applications running at that time. See Auto Actions Overview for more information. Click Add a New Auto Action creates a new action. Click Clear to clear the list.

title: Usage Details
body: One of the most difficult challenges in managing multi-tenant Hadoop clusters is understanding how resources are being used by the applications running in the clusters. Through Usage Details, Unravel Web UI provides a unique forensic view into each cluster's key performance indicators (KPIs) over time and how they relate to the applications running in the cluster.

title: Usage Details
body: For example, Unravel can pinpoint the applications causing a sudden a spike in the total VCores or memory MB usage. This allows you to easily you drill down into these applications to understand their behavior. Whenever possible, Unravel provides recommendations and insights to help improve the application(s) run.

title: Usage Details
body: All the charts and tables are automatically refreshed; however refreshing is disabled when you interact within a page to alter its display, e.g., change the date range, click on a point within in a graph. When disabled, a Refresh button is displayed in Usage Details title bar. Click on Refresh to resume automatic refreshes.

title: Usage Details
body: By default the Usage Details tab opens showing the Infrastructure tab.

title: Usage Details
body: For all charts, click on the menu bars (), for print and download options, e.g. csv, jpeg. Click Show more to expand it. For a particular point in time, hover over chart to see a popup with details. Click on the graph to see all applications running at that particular point. Once expanded, click on the to return to the initial view. To zoom in drag over a section of the graph; to return to the complete graph click Reset Graph. The examples below are showing the Vcores-Total graph from the Infrastructure Tab expanded. The first graph shows the selection of an area to zoom in on and the second result.

title: Infrastructure
body: The upper two list available and allocated Vcores and memory for the entire Cluster, and

title: Infrastructure
body: The bottom show the Vcores and memory used by specific view, e.g., Application Type, User, Queue.

title: Infrastructure
body: Clicking within a chart (1) displays the applications running for that point in time.

title: Infrastructure
body: You can choose how to display the bottom two graphs by clicking on the View By type (2). Once you have chosen your view, the first three (3) available values for that view are displayed in the Showing box (3), e.g., job types running, mapReduce, Spark. Above the box notes the number displayed of the total available values for the View type. Regardless the total available values by View By choice, you may only graph up to four (4). Click within the Showing box to see all available values; to remove a value click on the x next to its name (3). By default, Infrastructure opens displaying Application Type. In the example below only one application type is available, Mapreduce. In the example above Vcores-Total was expanded (show more) and then zoomed in on a section.

title: Infrastructure
body: To View by tags, use the Business Tags pull down menu, which will display all available tags. The tag you chose is displayed in blue and to left of the Business Tags. To add a tag, click in the Showing box to show all available tags, click on the tag to use it. You can only have up to four (4) tag values. Delete a particular value by clicking the x next to remove the value.

title: Jobs
body: Graphs the running and accepted jobs as applicable. You can Group by State, App Type, User, and Queue. By default, the chart uses State. You can change the display of an item via the Group By pull-down.

title: Nodes
body: This chart graphs the Total number of Nodes and the breakdown by node status, Active, Lost, Unhealthy, Decommissioned and Rebooted.

title: Nodes
body: Active: currently running and healthy nodes.

title: Nodes
body: Unhealthy: currently running and unhealthy nodes.

title: Nodes
body: You can toggle the display of an item by clicking on its name.

title: Impala Usage
body: Graphs memory MB consumption and Query Number. The # Queries graph can be displayed by Tags and Group By (User or Queue).

title: Kafka
body: Lists all the configured Kafka clusters. See Kafka Application Manager for more information. See Kafka Use Case for information on drilling down into a Cluster to locate lagging and stalled Topics/Partitions.

title: Kafka
body: Clicking the cluster name brings detailed information about the Kafka Cluster

title: HBase
body: Please see HBase Configuration for configuring Unravel UIX for HBase clusters.

title: Clusters View
body: Clusters page lists all the available HBase clusters

title: Clusters View
body: Click on a cluster name to bring up the cluster's information the HBase Cluster view.

title: Cluster View
body: This view is divided into four (4) sections. When a component's health is noted, hovering over its health glyph brings up details, .

title: Cluster View
body: A bar shows what cluster you are displaying with a pull-down which allows you to switch between clusters. Listed immediately below are the cluster metrics. You can choose to tab between clusters by choosing all cluster. Shown below is the tabbed view.

title: Cluster View
body: Lists the cluster regional services, with their KPI's and health. You can search on the region server by name. Click on the server's name to bring up its details.

title: Cluster View
body: Graphs the regional server metrics, the graphs are linked with the table list below them. Click within a graph to see the tables associated servers that point in time. Hover over a point to bring up a popup displaying the information for that point in time. Click Show More to expand the graph with the table list to full window width. Click to print or download the graph.

title: Cluster View
body: List all the tables associated with the cluster, their KPIs and the table's health. Click on the table name to bring up its information. You can search for a table by name; any table with a name matching or containing the string is displayed.

title: Region Server View
body: Server, Operational, and OS Metrics are displayed. Hover over the metric for its description. For more information on the metrics see here. You can change the date range to display using the date picker. The first four (4) regional server metrics are graphed using the daily view. Use the pull down menu to switch to the weekly view. Click to print or download the graph. The table list contains all the tables that accessed by this server. You can search the table list by name. Click on the table name to bring up its details.

title: Table View
body: Table has two tabs, Table and Region. It opens in the Table view, which displays the Table's KPIs. Three of the KPIs, regionCount, readRequestCount, and writeRequestCount are also graphed and linked with the application list below them. Click to print or download the graph. Hover over the graph to display the information for that point in time. Click within the graph to display the applications running at that point in time. Click on the application's name to open it in its application manager.

title: Table Regions
body: Lists all the regions with their KPIs and health.

title: The Applications Page
body: The Applications page is the main interface for locating your applications and analyzing their performance. Unravel supports both ad-hoc applications, and repeatedly running workflows or data pipelines.

title: The Applications Page
body: Ad-hoc applications are Hive queries, MapReduce jobs, Spark applications, Impala queries, and so on; these are generated by end user tools (such as BI tools like Tableau, Microstrategy, etc.) or submitted via CLI.

title: The Applications Page
body: Repeatedly running workflows or data pipelines are created using cron or schedulers like Oozie, AirFlow, or ETL tools like Informatica, Pentaho, and others.

title: The Applications Page
body: Unravel currently supports the following application frameworks:

title: The Applications Page
body: Your application's performance and reliability depends on several factors, such as quality of the code, types of joins used, configuration settings, data size, scheduler settings, contention with other applications, etc. It takes significant expertise and effort to get to the root cause(s) of an application's problems. Unravel's Intelligence Engine provides insights into your application's run to help resolve its problems/inefficiencies. These insights are called events. For more information about events, see the Events & Insights.

title: The Applications Page
body: The Applications Page has three tabs:

title: The Applications Page
body: See Common UI Features for general information about Unravel's UI.

title: The Applications Page
body: See Resource Metrics for the list of metrics that Unravel collects.

title: Applications Tab
body: Click here for common features used throughout Unravel's UI.

title: Applications Tab
body: By default this tab lists all applications for the past week. However, this view initially search results are ordered by the most recent start time. To reorder the results by another property, click the appropriate header in the results table.

title: Finding Applications
body: You can search for your application(s) in a variety of ways:

title: Finding Applications
body: The left sidebar allows you to filter your App Name, App type, Status, Tags (if any), Queue, User, Cluster, Duration (Min and Max duration), and Number of Events.

title: Finding Applications
body: By time period, including specifying custom range by dates and times, using the date picker or scroll by page (1).

title: Finding Applications
body: If the job is part of a Hive query, Pig script, or a Workflow, a link to it is noted in the job's Go To column (2). A Hive-on-Spark job links to the corresponding Spark app. Clicking on the application (3) takes you to the application's program manager (APM), i.e., MapReduce, Impala. Hovering over an auto action alert () brings up the list auto actions in the notification column () brings up a popup () listing the auto actions the job has violated. The fine-tuning glyph () notes when tuning suggestions are available for the job.

title: Finding Applications
body: Athena jobs are serverless and retrieved upon completion. Therefore, its Write, Cluster ID, Queue, and Go To columns are empty, and its status can only be success, failed, or killed.

title: Workflow Tab
body: The layout of this window mirrors the Applications tab. When there are no workflows tagged, the table is empty. You can use the date picker to select a date and time range. You can search for a workflow by name. Enter the string in the search box; any user or workflow name matching or containing the string is displayed. Click on the workflow name to bring it up in the Workflow Manager Application Manager.

title: Sessions Tab
body: Click here for common features used throughout Unravel's UI.

title: Sessions Tab
body: This Report does not work with PostgreSQL. You must be using MySQL and have the OnDemand package installed.

title: Sessions Tab
body: Sessions allows you to run your application expressly to tune its performance for either:

title: Sessions Tab
body: Speedup: decrease the application's time (end-to end duration) and resources (shortening duration is first priority).

title: Sessions Tab
body: Reliability: in attempting to reduce resources Unravel prioritizes memory allocation to ensure the application doesn't fail due to "out of memory" exceptions.

title: Sessions Tab
body: Why use sessions when Unravel already offers insights and recommendations on an application's run?

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can provide multiple runs of an application providing a larger data pool for Unravel to analyze.

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can have Unravel apply the recommendations for you and run the newly configured application.

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can see the effects, both positive and negative, the tuning has on an application's run.

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can compare the various runs' configurations.

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can repeatedly tune the application until Unravel has no more recommendations.

title: Sessions Tab
body: Your session is saved and can be run again, e.g., new runs added, cluster configuration changed.

title: Sessions Tab
body: Sessions can serve simply as a tool to compare two runs of the same application.

title: Sessions Tab
body: The Sessions tab opens displaying all current sessions sorted on Sessions Name in ascending order. The Start Time is the time of the latest application run. Number of Apps is the number of runs inside the Session. Some of these runs were added when the Session was created and some were created by Sessions when it applied it recommendations.

title: Sessions Tab
body: The four (4) KPI's Duration, IO, Vcore Seconds, and Memory Seconds are essentially what the fine-tuning hopes to minimize. The column contains a trend line which plots all the apps (vertices) contained in the Session. Beneath the trend line, the average and the best value is noted. For example, VCore9, has 3 apps, for Duration the average is 19 m 24 s and the best time was 38.31% better than this. You can not draw the conclusion that the same app performed best for each KPI. Last the Cluster ID is listed. You can sort the table on Session Name, Start Time and Cluster. Click on the edit button to edit the session.

title: Sessions Tab
body: You can search for a session by name. Enter the string in the search box; any session name matching or containing the string will be displayed.

title: Creating a Session
body: manually - you actively control the analysis and application of recommendations, or

title: Creating a Session
body: automatically - sessions performs the iterations without your intervention until it reaches the maximum allowed runs or finds no more recommendations

title: Manual Session
body: Click Create Session. You must name your session, it does not have to be unique, but we recommend you do so. Chose the Application Type and Tuning Goal from the pull-down menu and the tuning goal. Add the App IDs of the application(s) you want to tune you. Click +Add another App ID to add more apps. Click to delete an App ID. Click Add to create the session.

title: Manual Session
body: If you are tuning a Spark App you can optionally supply the JAR path, Class Name, Class Arguments, or Files.

title: Auto Tune Session
body: You have the additional option to specify the maximum number of runs. If not specified, it iterates for five (5) runs. When specified, the iteration stops at the maximum number or lack of recommendations, whichever comes first.

title: Via the Events Panel
body: If an application has events with recommendations you can create a session directly from the recommendations tab. You can create either a manual or auto tune session. Click the type of session you wish to create and session popup is filled out except for the session name.

title: Via the Spark Actions Box
body: Once a Spark Application has completed, you may select to Create a Session or Auto Tune Session from the Actions tab.

title: Session
body: The Session's APM layout is similar to all APMs. Instead of KPIs reflecting the Application, Session's KPIs are trend graphs showing the various runs' resource usages measured when tuning, duration, IO, and resources. The example below is a session view immediately after creation.

title: Session
body: The left tab, Applications is the list of runs; initially it is whatever was loaded when the session was created. As analysis and application of recommendations occur more runs are added.

title: Session
body: Progress Tab - Keeps a log of all the activity. See example above.

title: Session
body: Trends - Expanded graphs of Duration, IO, and Resources.

title: Session
body: Compare - Allows you to compare two of the runs.

title: The Reports Page
body: Unravel provides a variety of reports helping you manage your clusters. The page has four tabs.

title: The Reports Page
body: Operational Insights - provides the ability to generate a variety of reports, including chargebacks, cluster summaries, and cluster compares.

title: The Reports Page
body: Data Insights - provides data level insights including a snapshot of tables and partitions over the last 24 hours and reports on disk capacity forecasting and small files.

title: The Reports Page
body: Cloud Reports - helps you plan your migration to the cloud by analyzing your on-prem cluster, three migration methods and the costs associated each method.

title: The Reports Page
body: Report Archives - lists all reports and attempts to generate a report, whether the reports were scheduled or run on an ad hoc basis.

title: The Reports Page
body: Scheduled Reports - lists all scheduled reports.reports-page-scheduled

title: The Reports Page
body: Scheduling Reports - All user-generated reports can be run on a scheduled or ad hoc basis.

title: The Reports Page
body: The Reports page opens displaying Operational Insights.

title: The Reports Page
body: See Common UI Features for general information about Unravel's UI.

title: The Reports Page
body: See Resource Metrics for the list of metrics that Unravel collects.

title: Operational Insights
body: Chargeback Yarn - generates chargeback Yarn jobs.

title: Operational Insights
body: Chargeback Impala - generates chargeback reports for Impala jobs.

title: Operational Insights
body: Cluster Summary - generates summary reports for cluster usages.

title: Operational Insights
body: Cluster Compare - generates reports comparing cluster activity between two time periods.

title: Operational Insights
body: Cluster Optimization - analyzes the cluster performance and provides fine-tuning insights/recommendations.

title: Operational Insights
body: Queue Analysis - Generates a report of active queues for time frame. The report analyzes queue activity by apps, Vcores and memory.

title: Operational Insights
body: Cluster Workload - shows the aggregated workload for all clusters.

title: Operational Insights
body: When you specify a date range, a pull down menu appears on the right-hand side of the Operational Insights title bar. By default, Operational Insights opens showing Chargeback tab grouped by Application Type , for all clusters over the last 24 hours displayed hourly.

title: Operational Insights
body: Click here for common features used throughout Unravel's UI.

title: Chargeback
body: The Chargeback Yarn and Impala tabs are identical except that the reports are limited to Yarn and Impala jobs respectively.

title: Chargeback
body: You can generate ChargeBack reports for multi-tenant cluster usage costs associated by the Group By options: Application Type, User, Queue, and Tags. The default is Application Type; see above where only one (1) application type, Tez, was running. The window is divided into three (3) sections,

title: Chargeback
body: Donut graphs showing the top results for the Group by selection,

title: Chargeback
body: Chargeback report showing costs, sorted by the Group By choice(s), and

title: Generate Chargeback Report
body: You can set the date range and the cluster(s) to use for the report in the Operational Insights title bar. Use the Group By filters to generate/display the information in a categorical fashion. If two Group By options are selected, the sort priority is noted. In the example below the report is sorted on User than on the tag dept. Clicking on the Group By selection toggles it and might change the sort priority. Using the below example, if you deselect User, the tag dept becomes first sort with the selection becoming the second. You can specify the Vcore/Hour and Memory MB/Hour base costs (1) fractionally by entering them directly. Click Update Report (2) to generate the report. Click CSV to download the report as a csv file (3). Hover over the chart to see the information textually.

title: Generate Chargeback Report
body: A new chargeback report is generated each time you change the Group By filters. If you change the base costs, you must click Update Report to apply them to the report. The example below is of the Chargeback Yarn tab.

title: Cluster Summary
body: The Cluster Summary can be grouped by Applications, User or Queue. You can choose the date range in the Operational Insights title bar. Use the pull down menu in the upper right-hand corner to download the report in either csv or JSON format. By default, Cluster Summary opens displaying the User information.

title: Applications
body: You can sort applications on Vcore or memory seconds.

title: Cluster Compare
body: This tab opens displays the cluster group by User with the Time Range and Compare with Range both set to the Last 7 Days, i.e., no comparison is displayed.

title: Cluster Compare
body: Use Group By to generate the report by User or Queue. To specify the time ranges use the Time Range and Compare With Range pull-down menus (1).

title: Cluster Compare
body: Any deviation in metrics across the time ranges is highlighted (3). A green highlight with an upward arrow indicates am increase, while red with a down arrow denotes a decrease. If the Time or Compare With range is invalid for the Group By choice the range row is dashed (2).

title: Cluster Optimization
body: The OnDemand package must be installed to use this report.

title: Cluster Optimization
body: This report analyzes your cluster workload over a specified period. It provides insights and configuration recommendations to optimize your cluster throughput, resources, and performance. Currently, this feature only supports Hive on MapReduce.

title: Cluster Optimization
body: You can use these reports to:

title: Cluster Optimization
body: Fine tune your cluster to maximize its performance and minimize your costs, and

title: Cluster Optimization
body: Compare your cluster's performance between two (2) time periods.

title: Cluster Optimization
body: Reports are generated on an ad hoc or scheduled basis. All reports are archived and can be accessed via the Reports Archive tab. The tab opens displaying the last report, if any, generated.

title: Download or Generate a Report
body: Click Download JSON to download the displayed report in JSON. To download a prior report go to Reports Archive.

title: Download or Generate a Report
body: Click Generate New Report to create new report; enter the Date Range and click Run. Running replaces Run and countdown is displayed until Unravel starts collecting the data. Generate New Report then pulsates blue until the report is completed. If the report was successfully generated, a light green bar is displayed.

title: Download or Generate a Report
body: Click Schedule to run the report at some future date and time. You can schedule your report to run once or on a regular basis. All reports (successful or failed attempts) are in the Reports Archive.

title: Optimization Report
body: Header Contains the basic report information author, time run, and dates used to generate the report.

title: Optimization Report
body: Number of Jobs: per day average

title: Optimization Report
body: Number of Vcore Hours: per day average

title: Optimization Report
body: Amount of Memory from of MapReduce Containers

title: Optimization Report
body: The KPIs are a per-day average for the number of days in the report. In this case we generated a report for a two (2) day period. All the insights/recommendations are based upon the analysis of all jobs, in this case 113.

title: Optimization Report
body: This section contains a tab for each app type with the relevant properties under consideration for tuning. These are cluster wide properties, and they are the defaults for all applications. However, you can override these properties on an application by application basis.

title: Optimization Report
body: You can expand the insight tile to the full width of the window. Further, below we go into greater detail on two of the insights to explain the contents.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Tune the size of the map containers

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Each tile is entitled with the property being tuned. Below is the expanded view of the first tile.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Immediately below the title is the property name, in this case mapreduce.map.memory.mb. Click on the to bring up related properties.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Next (1) is the tuning suggestion (1460), the projected impact (High) and the effect on the current jobs. In this case the recommendation affects 51% of the total jobs. The final section has the analysis information. The default (2) is the current property value (8192) and the percent of the applications that are currently using that value (51%). Click on the to see the frequency map showing the job distribution by memory usage

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: As expected 51% of the jobs (58) used the default, while 33% (37) used 512 MB with the remaining jobs distributed across the remaining values.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: The graph shows Unravel's analysis of the property potential values. It shows each candidate (proposed value) and the effect it had on the % of memory saved for the input workload and the % of jobs from the workload that would still run with the candidate. In this case we want to maximize the ability to run jobs while minimizing the memory allocation.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: When there are tuning instructions it is noted above the graph (3). Click on to display the instructions explaining where and how to set the property and any additional information you should take into consideration. You'll notice that all the "related" properties and their relationship to what we're tuning are discussed here.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Tune the number of the map containers

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: Tune the number of reduce containers in Hive queries

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: This analysis has additional information in addition a tuning suggestion and instruction. Click on it to see further information.

title: Insight/Recommendations Tile Details
body: In this case, the information was simply informative. There can be cases where tuning suggestions for specific apps are offered.

title: Queue Analysis
body: The OnDemand package must be installed to use this report.

title: Queue Analysis
body: You can generate a report of active queues for all your clusters or a particular cluster. The report analyzes queue activity by applications, Vcores, memory., and disk. As with all reports, it can be generated on an ad hoc or scheduled basis. The tab opens displaying the last report, if any, generated. Reports are archived and can be accessed via the Reports Archive tab.

title: Generate a Report
body: Click New Report to create new report. Enter the Date Range, the default range is 1 week. Use the Cluster pull down menu to select from your available clusters. Click Run. Running replaces Run and countdown is displayed until Unravel starts collecting the data. A green banner bar is briefly displayed noting that "Queue Analysis Started" and New Report pulsates blue until the report is completed. If Unravel was unable to start the report or failed to produce one, a red banner bar is displayed noting report wasn't started along with any error messages. Note that new report generation may take longer depending on the time range selected and number of active queues on the cluster for which the report is generated.

title: Generate a Report
body: Click Schedule to run the report at some future date and time. You can schedule your report to run once or on a regular basis. All (successful or failed attempts) are stored in the Reports Archive.

title: Report
body: If the report was successfully generated a light green bar appears and a table listing all the queues existing during the time range is displayed. The table lists each queue with its KPIs average (Apps Running, Vcores, Memory, and Disk). You can sort the queues on any column; by default the queues are sorted by name in ascending order. Sorting the list by average KPIs allows you to identify the most or least active queue and focus on them instead of scrolling though the complete list of queues. Click in the Filter By box for the queue list and to select the queues to filter on. Click in a queue's row to download the report.

title: Report
body: Click in a queue's row to see three graphs displaying the queue's Applications, Vcore Usage, and Memory Usage. When monitoring a MapR Cluster a fourth graph, Disk Usage, is displayed. Click in the selection box to chose from the available metrics to graph. You can select up to two (2) metrics for each graph. Clicking within a graph brings up a cluster view Operations > Usage Details > Infrastructure for that point in time. Hovering over a point in graph brings up a pop-up in all graphs displaying metrics and values along with the averages for the metric for that point in time.

title: Report
body: Click t to expand the graphs to window width. The relationship between the graphs still exist, hovering over once, exposes the data for that point in time. The expanded graph has its metric legend beneath it. Hover over a metric to see its full definition and the current impact of the metric on the cluster. Below we have expanded the applications graph. Click to return the graph to its original size.

title: Cluster Workload
body: Displays your cluster(s) yarn applications' workload across a date range using the following views:

title: Cluster Workload
body: Hour - by hour regardless of date, e.g., 10.00 - 11.00.

title: Cluster Workload
body: Day - by weekday regardless of date, e.g., Tuesday.

title: Cluster Workload
body: Hour/Day - by hour for a given weekday, e.g.,10.00 -11.00 on Tuesday.

title: Cluster Workload
body: You can filter each view by App Count, Vcores Hour, and Memory Hour.

title: Cluster Workload
body: To measure the Vcores or Memory Hour usage is straightforward; at any given point the memory or Vcore is being used or not.

title: Cluster Workload
body: The App Count is not a count of unique app instances because apps can span boundaries, i.e., begin and end in different hours/days.

title: Cluster Workload
body: The App Count reflects the apps that were running within that interval up to and including the boundary, i.e., date, hour, day. Therefore, an app can be counted multiple times in time slice.

title: Cluster Workload
body: On multiple dates, e.g., on 11 & 12 October (2 days)

title: Cluster Workload
body: On multiple days, Thursday & Friday, and

title: Cluster Workload
body: This results in anomalies where the Sum(24 hours in Hour/Day App Count) > Sum(App Counts for dates representing the day). For instance, in the below example:

title: Cluster Workload
body: App Count for Wednesdays (10, 17 & 24 October) = 2492, and

title: Cluster Workload
body: App Count across Hour/Day intervals for Wednesday = 2526.

title: Cluster Workload
body: We point this out not because it necessarily has a significant impact in how you can use the data, but to inform you such variations exist.

title: Cluster Workload
body: By default the tab opens in the Month view filtered on App Count for the past 24 hours. Use the Date Range date picker to change the range. We suggest using a short range as the longer the range the more processing time consumed. Click App Count, Vcores Hour, and Memory Hour to change the display metric. The metric you select is used for all subsequent views until changed. Click on the View By buttons to change between views. Immediately above the graph it textually notes the metric being used for the time range. When the date range is greater than one day the Hour, Day, and Hour/Day views allow you to display the data by either as an Average or Sum.

title: Cluster Workload
body: See Drilling Down below for information on how to retrieve the detailed information within each view.

title: Month
body: Displays the jobs run on the particular date. The color indicates how the day's load compares with the other days within the date range. The day with the least jobs/hours is , while the days with the highest load are . Therefore, the color of any particular day varies in context to the other days being displayed, e.g., when only one day is displayed it is colored . Use Previous and Next in the month's title bar to navigate between months.

title: Hour, Day and Hour/Day
body: These graphs do not link jobs to any specific date at the graph level. For instance, the Hour graph shows that 856 jobs ran at 2 am (between 2am and 3am); the Day graph that 2,492 jobs ran on Wednesday, and the Hour/Day that 68 jobs ran at 2 am on a Wednesday. But none of these graphs directly indicate the date these jobs ran on. Only the Month view visually links job counts to a specific date; above we see 10 October had an app count of 822.

title: Hour, Day and Hour/Day
body: By default each view opens using the metric selected for the prior view. For instance, if Vcores Hour is used to display Month and you switch to Day it is filtered using Vcores Hour.

title: Hour, Day and Hour/Day
body: When the Date Range spans multiple days, you have the choice to display the data as either the:

title: Hour, Day and Hour/Day
body: Sum - aggregated sum of job count, Vcore or memory hour during the time range (default view).

title: Hour, Day and Hour/Day
body: Average - Sum / (# of Days in Date Range).

title: Hour
body: Breaks out information by hour. The interval label indicates the start, i.e., 2AM is 2-3AM. Hover over an interval for its details. Click on the interval to drill down into it.

title: Day
body: Displays the jobs run on a specific weekday. Hover over an interval for its details. Click on the interval to drill down into it.

title: Hour/Day
body: This view shows the intersection of Hour and Day graphs. The Hour graph showed 856 jobs ran between at 2-3 am while the Day graph (immediately above) that 2,492 jobs ran on Wednesday. Below we see that 68 of Wednesday's jobs (2.7%) were running between 2-3 am.

title: Drilling Down in a Workload View
body: Click on an interval to bring up its information. In our example, we selected 11 October in the Month view which was filtered on App Count (921 apps). A list breaking out the jobs by app type is displayed. Below we see all 921 were MR jobs.

title: Drilling Down in a Workload View
body: Click to display User and Queue details. By default, User is displayed, click Queue to see all the queues. In this case there are two users, HDFS (910 jobs) and ROOT (11 jobs). Click on (job details) to see the running applications for that row. When there are multiple choices show, Unravel notes which detail is displayed by highlighting the row. Below there are three options:

Click on an application to bring it up in its APM. When you change the metric (App Count, Vcores Hour and Memory Hour) the window reverts to displaying the graph.

title: Data Insights
body: The first two tabs provide data level insights including a snapshot of tables and partitions over the last 24 hours within a historical context.

The list is sorted on Total Users in descending order. You can also use the metrics Total Users, Total Apps, or Total Size to display the graph. The Total Apps metric (corresponding Apps column in the table) is the total number of Hive and Impala queries on the table.

All is selected below, so every table is shown. You can sort the list by the various metrics in ascending or descending order. By default, the list is sorted on Read IO in descending order. If you have selected a table, the More Info glyph is available. Click on it to display the Table Detail pane. Click on Configuration Policy (2) to edit the label rules or Download CSV to download the table (2).

title: Table Detail

Use the Metric (2) pull down menu to select Total Users, Total Apps, or Total Size as the metric to graph. The Application Detail lists the applications that accessed the table in the given time range. See the Application Tab section for detailed information on its format. Below the table shows both Hive and Impala queries.

The partition list can be sorted on Last Access date, Created date, Current Size, or Users. Hovering over the Users number brings up the list of user(s) who accessed the partition.

title: Forecasting (Disk Capacity)
body: The OnDemand package must be installed to use this report. See here for properties which control this report.

title: Forecasting (Disk Capacity)
body: It currently only works on Cloudera (CDH) and Hortonworks (HDP).

title: Forecasting (Disk Capacity)
body: This report helps you monitor HDFS disk capacity usage and plan for future needs. Unravel uses your historical usage to extrapolate capacity trends allowing you to more effectively plan for, and allocate your disk resources. The tab opens displaying the last forecasting report, if any, generated. The graph displays the trend from the historical range start date to the forecast range end date (x-axis). The trend line (in blue) shows the lower, middle, and upper bounds of Unravel's prediction. The y-axis is determined by your actual physical disk capacity. The report parameters are listed above the table headings.

title: Forecasting (Disk Capacity)
body: Click New Report to create a report. Enter the History (Date Range) to use, the default is the prior seven (7) days. Enter the Forecasting (number of days) you want to generate a forecast for. In the above example, a history of six (6) days was used to generate a five (5) day forecast. Click Run to generate the report or Schedule to generate the report on a regular basis. (See Scheduling Reports.)

title: Forecasting (Disk Capacity)
body: While Unravel prepares to generate the report Run is replaced with Running and a countdown appears above it. Once Unravel starts the generation the popup closes and the New Report button pulsates blue. A light green bar appears when the report was completed successfully and results are displayed. Upon failure the bar is light red and the New Report button becomes orange.

title: Small Files
body: The OnDemand package must be installed to be able to use this report. It requires hdfs privileges and currently only works on HDP/CDH. If you can't grant hdfs privileges, you must configure these properties.

title: Small Files
body: Each small file is accessed by a single mapper, therefore a large number of small files can lead to a large number of mappers. In turn, mappers are costly to run so applications using a large number of small files drive up your costs. This report helps you to identify users who create/use an excessive amount of small files.

title: Small Files
body: You can use this information to take corrective action such as:

title: Small Files
body: Combine multiple files into large files.

title: Small Files
body: Notify, limit, or block/ users who create/use an excessive amount.

title: Small Files
body: Correct and prevent future performance degradation.

title: Small Files
body: Lower your costs to run applications.

title: Small Files
body: The small file window by default opens with the last report that was generated, if any. The report parameters are listed above the table headings (1), and you can search the path list by string. The list is sorted in descending order of the total number of small files in the directory. Click Download CSV to download the report as a .csv file.

title: Small Files
body: Click New Report to generate a new report. The parameters are:

title: Small Files
body: Average File Size (bytes): the average small file size in a directory. Uncheck the box to its right to enter a small file size to use instead.

title: Small Files
body: Minimum # of Small Files: which are in the directory.

title: Small Files
body: # of Directories to Show: is the maximum number of directories to display.

title: Small Files
body: Min parent directory depth: minimum depth to start at, root + x descendants, i.e., 0=root, 1=root's children (/one), etc.

title: Small Files
body: Max parent directory depth: maximum depth to end at, root + x descendants, i.e., 1=root's children (/one), 2=root's grandchildren, (/one/two), etc.

title: Small Files
body: Drill down sub-directories: determines how/where the files are listed. Yes (default): lists the file in all its ancestor's list. No: list file in its directory list only.

title: Small Files
body: Click Run to generate the report and Schedule to generate the report on a regular basis. See Scheduling Reports below.

Once Unravel starts the generation the popup closes and the New Report button pulsates blue. A light green bar appears when the report was completed successfully and results are displayed. Upon failure the bar is light red and the New Report button becomes orange.

title: Top X
body: This report lists the top X Hive or Spark jobs which have consumed the most:

title: Top X
body: Click New Report to generate the report. Select your History (Date Range) and the number of apps (Top X) to include in the report. (Prior to initial report generation the default is a history of one (1) week and the Top X empty. After a report has been generated, its arguments are used.) Click Run; Running replaces Run and countdown is displayed until Unravel starts collecting the data. A dark green bar is briefly displayed at the top of the window noting that "Top X Started". New Report pulsates blue until the report is completed.

title: Top X
body: The report includes up to X apps (when available). If the report has been successfully completed a light green bar appears noting "Top X Completed Successfully". The report displays the Hive jobs by default and notes the reports parameters. Click the Filter By option to select that report type (Hive and Spark). You can download the report by clicking the Download JSON button. The report is unfiltered and contains the information for both Hive and Spark.

title: Top X
body: The display is composed of three (3) tiles:

title: Top X
body: The Applications tile lists the app total along with successful and failed app count. Three tables list the top X apps by consumption type: Most Duration, Most I/O, and Most Cluster Usage. Each table is sorted on the relevant column, e.g., Duration. The last column, App Parent, indicates when the app is a Hive-on-Tez app. Hover over the Query Snippet to display more of the query. Click on the app name to bring up the application in its APM.

title: Top X
body: Note: The applications in each table are not necessarily the same. The top X apps with the most duration are not necessarily the top X apps using the most I/O.

title: Top X
body: These tiles display the cumulative totals for the queries. The Data tile displays the total Read and Write I/O. The Resources tile varies by app type, but always has the top ten (10) Queues sorted by App Count. For Hive, the total query time by Map and Reduce time plus the total and successful app count for each is listed. The Total Spark Slot Time is displayed for Spark.

title: Overview
body: One of the more challenging aspects of optimizing the resources in your Hadoop cluster is determining how to migrate your on-prem cluster to the cloud to save money, reduce maintenance, and increase your agility. Cloud Reports helps you to understand your current cluster and plan your migration.

title: Overview
body: Cluster Discovery -analyzes your on-prem cluster usage, workload patterns, and your hosts' hardware specs.

title: Overview
body: Migration Analysis -estimates the cost of moving to the cloud. Unravel analyzes three migration strategies by cloud provider (Azure, EC2, and EMR).

title: Overview
body: Lift and Shift: one-to-one mapping of each existing host’s capacity (based on CPU, memory, and disk) to the closest fit on the cloud that meets or exceeds the host's hardware specs. This method provides an estimate of what your current on-prem cluster configuration would cost on the cloud. It does not consider workload or actual resource usage. You will most likely not realize the cost savings the cloud can provide; but you will minimize risks associated with migrating to the cloud

title: Overview
body: Cost Reduction: one-to-one mapping of each existing host’s actual usage (based on CPU, memory, and disk) to the closest fit on the cloud that meets or exceeds the host's usage requirements. While still a one-to-one mapping, this method is more cost effective as it minimizes over-provisioning (the under-utilization of your host's resources). It optimizes for cost but not necessarily peak-usage. If your on-prem hosts are underutilized this method will always be less expensive than lift and shift.

title: Overview
body: Workload Fit: unlike the other methods this is not a one-to-one mapping. Unravel analyzes your workload for the time period and bases it recommendations on that workload. Unravel provides multiple recommendations based on the resources needed to meet x% of your workloads. It determines the optimal assignment of VM types to meet the requirements while minimizing cost. This method is typically the most cost effective method.

title: Overview
body: Cloud Reports is generated base upon an analysis of your cluster workload over a specific date range. You can use it to:

title: Overview
body: Examine the costs of running your clusters on three cloud providers:

title: Limitations
body: Cloud reports has not been thoroughly tested for clusters running Kerberos.

title: Limitations
body: Your cluster must have at least seven days of metrics for Unravel to generate useful reports.

title: Limitations
body: The pricing in reports use a static list of VM Instance type specs.

title: Limitations
body: Clusters running MapR Control System are not supported.

title: Limitations
body: In order to use Cloud Reports you must have OnDemand installed, and set the cluster manager properties.

title: Cluster Discovery

A dark green bar is briefly displayed at the top of the window noting the report has started. New Report pulsates blue until the report is completed.

title: Cluster Discovery
body: These graph your cluster's CPU and memory. The average usage is listed on the right-hand side of the title bar. Hover over the parenthetical text next to the resource to see Unravel's analysis of your usage. Below we see the allocated CPU resource is "Very under-utilized and over-provisioned".
