Each time slot in the heat map represents how relatively hot that time slot was. Hover over a day/hour to see the capacity, usage, and score (percentile). You can filter the heatmap by CPU or memory. It opens in the CPU view.

title: Generating Reports for Cloud Mapping per Instance and per Host Tabs
body: The below example is for Cloud Mapping per Instance; Cloud Mapping per Host differences only in the title.

title: Generating Reports for Cloud Mapping per Instance and per Host Tabs
body: Click NEW REPORT to generate the report. Select cloud provider Azure HDInsight, Amazon EC2, or EMR. Click Advanced Option to select a specific cloud Instance VM Type from the pull down menu. Click RUN; RUNNING replaces RUN and countdown is displayed until Unravel starts collecting the data. A dark green bar is briefly displayed at the top of the window noting the report has started. NEW REPORT pulsates blue until the report has completed. Click DOWNLOAD JSON to download the report in the JSON.

title: Generating Reports for Cloud Mapping per Instance and per Host Tabs
body: In the examples below we are using a report generated for EMR, with no instance type picked.

title: Cloud Mapping per Instance
body: This window provides a summary of the reports in Cloud Mapping by Hosts. By default, the tab opens displaying the Lift and Shift table for the last report generated. The Total Hourly Cost for the migration is shown on the right-hand side above the table. This cost is the sum across all hosts. The table displays the recommended EMR instance to use and its specifications. You can see below that the Lift and Shift analysis was for an on-prem cluster with 20 hosts. Click Cost Reduction to see the summation of that analysis.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Unravel generates reports on the three migration strategies.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Lift and Shift is a one-to-one mapping of each on-prem host to the best possible fit on the cloud based on capacity.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Cost Reduction is a one-to-one mapping of each on-prem host to the best possible fit on the cloud based on average utilization.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Workload Fit is a mapping based upon meeting SLA percentiles.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: The tab opens displaying the Lift and Shift report for the last report generated. To change the report click on the Cost Reduction or Workload Fit.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Below we examine the three migration reports mapping the cluster to EMR with no specific instance picked. The Total Hourly Cost ranges from $113.88 to $29.27 for Lift and Shift and Workload Fit respectively.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Lift and Shift and Cost Reduction

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: The report layout are the same. The basis for the mapping recommendation is listed under the selection tabs, the hourly cost to map all hosts is aggregated and displayed in the upper right above the report table. The table has four columns:

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Instance - in this case the on-prem host,

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Actual Usage - the host's resources which were actually utilized,

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Capacity - the resources the host has available,

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Recommendation - the cloud instance Unravel recommends mapping the host to, and

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Lift and Shift is matching capacity, and therefore not attempting to minimize costs. You can see below the on-prem host is very underutilized. Since Unravel is matching capacity, the instance the on-prem host is mapped to will also be underutilized. This report mapped 20 hosts, only the first is shown. The hourly cost per instance is $5.69 for a Total Hourly Cost of $113.88. This report below resulted in the summation shown above.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: Cost Reduction is again mapping each host to an instance (1-1), this time based on actual usage not capacity. Again we are only showing the first mapping. The EMR instance Unravel recommends is c3.8xlarge instead of m5d.24xlarge recommended above. The cost savings is significant compared to Lift and Shift; the Total Hourly Cost is approximately 35% of the cost of Lift and Shift.

title: Cloud Mapping per Host
body: In this report, Unravel is not looking at individual host capacity/usage but finding the optimal allocations of VM to meet a percentage of the workloads, specifically 80 - 100% in 5 point increments. For specifics details click on SLA x% mapping scroll through the window on the left size or click directly on the percentage. Below we see to meet 100% SLA – Unravel recommends the same cloud server instance as in Lift and Shift, but instead of mapping to 1-1, it recommends using just six (6). The bar graph shows the SLA/hour costs at a glance. You quickly can see there are costs saving from 100% to 95% (5%) and 95% to 90% (11%) but further reducing the SLA percentile results little to no savings. When comparing the total hourly cost of 100% SLA Workload Fit to Lift and Shift, and Cost Reduction shows savings of 75% and 25% respectively.

title: Scheduling Reports
body: Instead of generating your report immediately you can schedule the report to run on an ongoing basis. For any given report, you enter the necessary parameters and then click Schedule. The scheduling example below is a capacity forecasting report.

title: Scheduling Reports
body: You can not alter the Report name which is automatically set to the report type, e.g., capacity forecasting. You schedule the report to run at a specified time on either a Daily or weekday basis; use the pull down menu to set the weekday. By default, reports are scheduled to run daily at the same time you create the schedule. You can send an email Notification to one or more recipients to notify them the report run has started. Click Save Schedule to schedule the report. Upon saving your report appears in the Scheduled Reports tabs. Click the in the upper right-hand corner to report to the initial report page, e.g., Disk Capacity.

title: Reports Archive and Scheduled Reports
body: Click here for common features used throughout Unravel's UI.

title: Reports Archive
body: Lists all reports and attempts to generate a report, whether scheduled or on ad hoc basis. The status of the report is color coded; in the example below, three reports succeeded while one failed. You can Filter By report type, e.g., Capacity Forecasting. You can Search by a string; any report containing the string in the Report ID, Report Type, or Created Date field is displayed.

title: Reports Archive
body: Successful reports can be viewed or downloaded. Click on the Report ID to view and to download it and to delete it. To delete more than one report select the check box for reports you wish to delete, click on the next to the search box. To delete all reports select the check box in the header bar. Once a report is deleted it, can not be recovered.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: See Common UI Features for general information about Unravel's UI.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: See Resource Metrics for the list of metrics that Unravel collects.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: A black title bar notes the application type, i.e., Spark, Impala, MapReduce, Fragment, etc. and the job ID. On the right side of the title bar are glyphs for adding a comment, and to minimize or close the tile if possible. If the jobs has a parent, i.e., Hive, Pig, there is an arrow with the parent's type. Clicking on it brings up its APM. If it is a running yarn job (MR, Tez, or Spark) there is an action box ()

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: Unravel's Intelligence Engine can provide insights into an application and may provide recommendations, suggestions and insights on how to improve the application's run. When there are insights a bar appears immediately below the title bar. If Unravel has recommendations the insight bar is orange, otherwise it's blue. For more information about events, see the Event Panel Example

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: The next section contains general job information and Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) (as applicable)

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: Event icon: notes the number of events the job had. No Events, instead of the box, is noted if there were none. This job has 2 events, clicking on the icon brings up a panel which contains one or more Tabs, as relevant, i.e., Recommendations, Efficiencies, Application Failure. See Event Panel & Insights.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: Job icon: notes the job type and status. The box is color coded to indicate as the application's status.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: Job Name: Next to the job name will be an auto actions glyph () if the job has violated any actions. Hover over it to see a list of the violated actions. A fine-tuning glyph () appears when Unravel has tuning suggestions for the job.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: Job Information: job number, owner, queue, cluster and start/stop time.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: KPIs: these vary by job type.

title: Typical Application Program Manager's Layout
body: The last section, typically divided into two, has specific information related to job. Each Application-Specific Manager Section goes into detail about this section. If the job is composed of tasks/jobs/stages they appear on the left under Navigation. Clicking a row brings up detailed information about it in a tile/panel below. The Auto Action/Event ( ) column notes the number of events associated with the job/stage.

title: Cascading and Pig Application Program Managers
body: The only difference between these two Application Program Managers is the job type name; otherwise they are the same. The example used below is the Pig APM.

title: Cascading and Pig Application Program Managers
body: By default the window opens displaying the Navigation and Task Attempts.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Yarn Apps: The number of apps that make up the workflow.

title: Left Tabs
body: Gantt Chart: Exceptions, errors, and warnings associated with this application.

title: Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts: Displays map and reduce task attempts by success, failed, and killed status. The data displayed is for the entire HIVE job. To see the details for a specific MapReduce task click on the job in the Navigation tab. The Pig APM above shows the Task Attempts.

title: Right Tabs
body: Attempts: Graphs the map and reduce task slot usage over the duration of the job. The wall clock time is noted in the upper left-hand corner. The computer slot usage is noted below the graph.

title: Hive Application Program Manager
body: The Hive Application Program Manager provides a detailed view into the behavior of Hive queries. Typical users are Hadoop DBAs or application owners (engineers, BI team, analysts). You can use this view to:

title: Hive Application Program Manager
body: Resolve inefficiencies, bottlenecks and reasons for failure within applications.

title: Hive Application Program Manager
body: By default the Hive APM opens displaying the Navigation and Query tabs.

title: Hive Application Program Manager
body: For Hive queries that do not run using a Tez, LLAP, MapReduce, or Spark app, the duration shown by Unravel may be inaccurate because Hive does not call the Hive pre and post hooks correctly for these queries.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the application to complete execution.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the application.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of YARN apps: The number of YARN apps making up the query.

title: Left Tabs
body: Navigation: List all the MapReduce jobs associate with the query. Click on the job name to bring up job in the MapReduce Application Manager tile.

title: Left Tabs
body: Execution Graph: Shows detailed information about the MapReduce jobs and their relationship to one another. This view helps identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies.

title: Left Tabs
body: The graph provides a quick and intuitive way to understand the MapReduce jobs. Upon opening the tab you immediately see the MR jobs (1) in relation to each other and limited job info: tables used, the job length in absolute and relative value to the whole.

title: Left Tabs
body: Clicking on the job brings up a box with more Table KPI's, forward path(s) for the Map and Reduce operations, and input paths (should you want to show them). Click on a table name to bring up its details. See Reports > Data Insights for description of the tables. Click Close (2) or scroll within the tab to close the box.

title: Left Tabs
body: Click on a path point (3) drill deeper. The resulting text box notes the operation type (i.e., MapJoin, ReduceSink, etc.), and various key information about the operation. The information displayed is specific to that operation at that time.

title: Left Tabs
body: Gantt Chart: Shows job sequencing using a gantt chart.

title: Left Tabs
body: Errors: Lists all errors associated with the job. Like job status, the errors are color coded and the total number of each type (fatal, errors, warnings) is noted. The top line lists the number of all jobs/task. The errors are grouped by tasks/jobs and then by severity. For each job/task the total and type of errors are noted. Time, keywords (if any) and a brief message is displayed for the error. Keywords extract important details from the errors messages/log data that can help developers/operators quickly "root cause" issues. "No errors found" is displayed when there are none.

title: Left Tabs
body: Tags: Lists the defined tag keys and associated values for the application. The example below has two tag keys, project and dept with each having one value, group11 and hr respectively.

title: Right Tabs
body: Query: Shows the Hive Query. See the Hive Application Manager window above for an example Query tab. Click on the Copy Query to copy it to the clipboard.

title: Right Tabs
body: Tables: A list of tables accessed by the application.

title: Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts: Displays MapReduce task attempts by success, failed, and killed status. The data displayed is for the entire HIVE job. To see the details for a specific MapReduce task click on the job in the Navigation tab.

title: Right Tabs
body: Attempts: Graphs the map and reduce task slot usage over the duration of the job. The wall clock time the job started is listed in the upper left hand corner. The total map and reduce slot duration times are listed below the graph.

title: Hive-on-Spark
body: For Hive-on-Spark jobs the Hive APM shows the details of the Spark app. Like the Spark APM, the running and completed Spark Jobs are listed in the Navigation tab. The progress of a running Job is displayed. In the example below, Job 2 is 75% complete. Clicking on the job brings up the Spark Job information in a new tile, and from there you can drill down into the Job's Stages. See the Spark APM for more information.

title: Impala Application Program Manager
body: The Impala Application Program Manager provides a detailed view into the behavior of Impala queries.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Fragments: Total number of query fragments.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Operators: Total number of operators in this query.

title: Left Tabs
body: Fragments: Displays a table with information about each fragment associated with this query. Click on More to expose the Fragments operators and Less to hide them. The coordinator fragment () is always the nth fragment.

title: Left Tabs
body: This window shows the Fragment and its KPIs. It defaults to the table of the Fragment's Operators with the associated KPIs for the operations. Clicking on the operator brings up the operator window. (See Operators below for more information.) You can view the Query Plan or the Instance View.

title: Left Tabs
body: Instance View: lists each instances with its KPI's.

title: Left Tabs
body: Operators: Displays a list of all operators for all fragments. You can search the operator's name. Click on the operator to display its details.

title: Left Tabs
body: Gannt Chart: Charts the fragments and the time spent on each operation. Hover over a section to see the operation and its KPI's.

title: Left Tabs
body: Query Plan: Shows the query plan in fragment or operator view. Both the fragment and operator view are shown below. Hover over the operator to get detailed information. Click on the button to switch views.

title: Left Tabs
body: Tags: Lists the defined tag keys and associated values for the application. The example below has two tag keys, project and dept with each having one value, group11 and hr respectively.

title: Right Tabs
body: Query: Shows the query plan code. Click on Query Copy to copy the query. See Impala APM image above for the Query Tab.

title: Right Tabs
body: Mem Usage: Graphs the Memory Usage by peak usage. Notes the maximum memory used on what host and the estimated memory per host.

title: Kafka Application Program Manager
body: The Kafka Application Program Manager provides Multi-Cluster support for monitoring:

title: Kafka Application Program Manager
body: See Kafka Insights for a Use Case example of drilling down into lagging or stalled Consumer Groups.

title: Kafka Application Program Manager
body: Operations > Usage Details > Kafka displays the list of Configured Kafka Clusters.

title: Kafka Application Program Manager
body: Click on the Cluster Name to bring up the Cluster View.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS: graphs the metrics for the data across the entire cluster.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER: graphs the metric for the data of the broker you select from the broker list.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC: graphs the metric data for a specific topic you select from the topic list.

title: Metrics
body: The METRICS and BROKER tab graphs all the metrics listed below. The TOPIC tab displays a subset of the metrics. In addition, subsets of these metrics are used in the TOPIC and CONSUMER Group pages.

title: Metrics
body: While the definition of the metric is the same throughout the breadth of the collected data is not. Therefore, the implication/interpretation of the metric varies by context. Below, for each metric, we explain:

title: Metrics
body: Whether it is used in TOPIC tab or the TOPIC and CONSUMER pages' Topic details tab.

title: Metrics
body: The data collected for the metric at each point.

title: Metrics
body: For some metrics, the implication or interpretation of data at the point of collection is explained; along with how you can use it to monitor your cluster or improve its performance.

title: Metrics
body: In addition to these metrics the TOPIC and CONSUMER pages Partition tab graphs the partition's Consumer lag and offset.

title: Metrics
body: The one minute rate of all the bytes flowing into the kafka network, specifically the Kafka Producers publishing messages. It indicates how much traffic the brokers are receiving from the Producer clients.

title: Metrics
body: This metric is also displayed in the TOPIC tab and the TOPIC and CONSUMER group views. For any given data point, for that point in time, the graph displays:

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the total amount of bytes flowing into the cluster across all topics and brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the amount of bytes flowing into the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC tab: the amount of bytes flowing into a particular topic across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC view: the same as the TOPIC tab, but each broker is represented by a trend line so you can see the data flowing into individual topics.

title: Metrics
body: CONSUMER group view: similar to the TOPIC page.

title: Metrics
body: The BROKERS tab can help you determine if you need to expand your cluster.

title: Metrics
body: It can help you identify a broker that is receiving more traffic than others which indicates there is a need for a partition rebalance.

title: Metrics
body: The one minute rate of all the bytes flowing out of the kafka network, specifically Kafka Consumers consuming messages from the topics. This metric scales differently than Bytes In Per Second, because of the great job Kafka does handling multiple consumers.

title: Metrics
body: It possible for the outgoing rate to be two to three times the incoming rate for topics bring consumed. Before Kafka 0.11.0.0, this metric included the internal replica traffic. Therefore it showed an outbound rate for a topic that was an actively producing client, even when no consumers were consuming from the same.

title: Metrics
body: This metric is also displayed in the TOPIC tab and the TOPIC and CONSUMER group pages.

title: Metrics
body: These graphs are exactly like Bytes In Per Second except they display the bytes out.

title: Metrics
body: The number of messages produced per second. While Bytes In Per Second displays the broker traffic in absolute terms of bytes, this is the number (count) of individual messages that flow in, regardless of their size.

title: Metrics
body: This metric is also displayed in the TOPIC tab and the TOPIC and CONSUMER group views. For any given data point, the graph displays, for that point in time:

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the total number of messages produced in the cluster across all topics and brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the number of messages being written into the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC tab: the number of messages flowing into the selected topic.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC view: the same as the TOPIC tab. Each topic, is represented by a trend line so you can see the number of message flowing into each broker.

title: Metrics
body: CONSUMER group view: similar to the TOPIC page.

title: Metrics
body: Useful for end users who are more interested in the message count rather than the network throughput.

title: Metrics
body: When used in conjunction with Bytes in Per Seconds you can estimate the size of a single message.

title: Metrics
body: Like Bytes in Per Seconds it can help identify broker imbalance so you can rebalance your partitions.

title: Metrics
body: The number of consumer fetch requests sent per second. Like Bytes Out Per Second this is an indicator of the rate consumers are uptaking/requesting messages from the Kafka cluster.

title: Metrics
body: This metric is also displayed in the TOPIC tab and the TOPIC view. For any given data point in the graph, for that point in time, it displays:

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the total number of fetch requests within the cluster across all topics and brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the number of fetch requests received by the selected broker across all topics.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC tab: the number of fetch requests received for a particular topic across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: TOPIC view: the total number of fetch requests received for that topic. Each topic, is represented by a trend line so you can see the number of fetch requests flowing into each broker.

title: Metrics
body: Care must be taken when interpreting this metric because the value also includes replica traffic, i.e., the fetch requests that get raised by the brokers to keep the topic partitions in sync.

title: Metrics
body: The count of under replicated partitions existing in a cluster.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line for under replicated partitions for the entire cluster.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line for under replicated partitions for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: This is the metric to monitor. It can provide insight into a number of problems on a Kafka cluster ranging from a broker being down to resource exhaustion.

title: Metrics
body: For example, a constant number of under replicated partitions for many brokers might indicate that one of the brokers is down. The count across the cluster is equal to the number of partitions on the faulty broker.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line indicates the presence of an active controller for the entire cluster.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line indicates the duration for which the selected broker was an active controller.

title: Metrics
body: On the cluster level the value for this metric should always be one (1), i.e., at all times only one broker should be the active controller. Any other value could indicate the cluster might be susceptible to administrative issues such as partition reassignment, etc.

title: Metrics
body: On a broker level, except for the active controller, the brokers should return zero (0).

title: Metrics
body: Request Handler Idle Ratio Average Per Minute

title: Metrics
body: The request handler idle ratio trend over a period of time. It indicates the percentage of the time the request handlers are not in use.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line is the metric value across the entire cluster averaged over all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line is the metric value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: Lower numbers indicate increased load on the broker. Anything under 0.2 (20 percent) is a cause for concern. Values under 0.1 (10 percent) usually indicate an active performance problem. Typically there are two reasons for high thread utilization:

title: Metrics
body: The threads are devoting some of their resources to overhead tasks and not servicing the client requests itself.

title: Metrics
body: The number of partitions. The count includes both leader and follower replica. It should be basically constant over time.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value across the entire cluster averaged over all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: Expect this to be basically constant over time. This count includes both leader and follower replica.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value across the entire cluster averaged over all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value for the selected broker. It represents the number of partitions for which the broker is currently a leader.

title: Metrics
body: Consider monitoring this metric because it gives you a qualitative distinction between the replicas on a broker in regards to leaders and followers. Even if the replicas are balanced in size or number across the cluster, there might be a broker who has an indiscriminately large/small number of leaders. This is an indication of imbalance.

title: Metrics
body: You can use this metric in conjunction with # Partition Count to calculate the percentage of partitions on broker for the partition the broker is a leader. In well balanced clusters this should be uniform. For example, if you have a replication factor of two (2) all brokers should be leaders of approximately 50% of their partitions.

title: Metrics
body: The number of offline partitions in the cluster, indicating the number of partitions in the cluster that have no leader.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value across the entire cluster averaged over all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the trend line indicates the metric's value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: Along with Under Replicated Partitions, this is a critical metric to monitor. Such partitions are inaccessible to clients because produce and fetch requests are sent only to leaders. This could result in issues like producer clients losing messages.

title: Metrics
body: One potential reason for the presence of offline partitions is the broker/brokers hosting the leader replicas are down.

title: Metrics
body: The 99th percentile of the total turnaround time (time from receiving the request to sending a response back) the broker spends processing the fetch request. 99% of all values in a group of fetch request timing are less than this metric's value.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: shows the time value for the entire cluster averaged across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: shows the time value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: You can gain insight into how an average request performs and what are the outliers by correlating this metric value with the average value of the metric.

title: Metrics
body: The 99th percentile of the total turnaround time (time from receiving the request to sending a response back) the broker spends processing the produce request. 99% of all values in a group of fetch request timing are less than this metric's value.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: shows the time value for the entire cluster averaged across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: shows the time value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: You can gain insight into how an average request performs and what are the outliers by correlating this metric value with the average value of the metric.

title: Metrics
body: You can use this to set a baseline of sorts. Much like Under Replicated Partitions, a spike in the 99 percentile for Produce requests can alert you to a wide range of performance issues.

title: Metrics
body: Displays the one minute rate for all the fetch requests being received and processed. Like Bytes Out Per Sec, it is an indicator of the rate at which consumers are uptaking/requesting messages from the Kafka cluster.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: shows the summation of the fetch requests being processed across all brokers per second.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: shows the fetch requests being processed by a specific broker per second.

title: Metrics
body: You must take care when interpreting this metric. In addition to the consumer client fetch request, the value also includes replica traffic, i.e., the fetch requests that get raised by the brokers to keep the topic partitions in sync.

title: Metrics
body: Displays the one minute rate of all the Produce Requests being received and processed. Like Bytes In Per Sec, it indicates how much traffic the brokers are receiving from the Producer clients.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: shows the summation of the produce requests being processed across all brokers per second.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: shows the produce requests being processed by a specific broker per second.

title: Metrics
body: This metric can be useful in deciding whether to expand your cluster.

title: Metrics
body: Additionally it can be helpful when tracked at the broker level. On a normal Kafka cluster the value across all brokers should be basically the same. It helps you identify a broker that is receiving more traffic than others indicating there is a need for a partition rebalance.

title: Metrics
body: The number of Produce requests sitting in the Producer Request Purgatory. It is a holding pen for requests waiting to be satisfied (Delayed). Of all Kafka request types, it is used only for Produce requests. It tracks the number of requests sitting in purgatory (including both watchers map and expiration queue).

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the count for the entire cluster averaged across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the count for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: You can use this metric as a rough gauge of memory usage.

title: Metrics
body: The number of Fetch requests sitting in the Fetch Request Purgatory. It is a holding pen for requests waiting to be satisfied (Delayed). Of all Kafka request types, it is used only for Fetch requests. It tracks the number of requests sitting in purgatory (including both watchers map and expiration

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the count for the entire cluster averaged across all brokers.

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the count for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: You can use this metric as a rough gauge of memory usage.

title: Metrics
body: The 99th percentile value of the latency incurred by a log flush, i.e., write to disk in milliseconds. 99% of all values in the group are less than the value of the metric.

title: Metrics
body: METRICS tab: the time value for the entire cluster averaged across all brokers

title: Metrics
body: BROKER tab: the time value for the selected broker.

title: Metrics
body: Log flushes are generally one of the most expensive operations, and can affect the durability, latency and throughput of the Kafka cluster. This trend line depicts what's the log latency like for the cluster and can help in configuring the log flush interval.

title: Kafka topics list consumed by a Consumer Group (CG) with relevant KPIs.
body: Kafka topics list consumed by a Consumer Group (CG) with relevant KPIs.

title: Kafka topics list consumed by a Consumer Group (CG) with relevant KPIs.
body: Click on the topic to bring up the TOPIC view and the consumer to bring up the Consumer group view. By default, it is sorted on Topic name, this table is sorted on Consumer Groups in order to see the active consumer groups. The Consumer Groups status is clearly indicated below it. See Kafka Insights for a Use Case example of locating of lagging or stalled Consumer Groups.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: The Topic list displays the KPIs; when details are available a more info icon is displayed. Click on it to bring up the Kafka view for the topic. Below the list are two tabs which display graphs of the Topic and Partition details. By default, the window opens with the Topic Detail graph displayed.

title: Partition Tab
body: You can choose both the Partition and the Metric for the display. By default, the 0th partition is displayed using the metric offset. The Partition Details' list is populated if the details are available.

title: Topic page
body: The Kafka View has two tabs, Topic Detail and Partition Detail. Each view has a Consumer Details' list which is populated if the details are available.

title: Topic page
body: By default, the Kafka Topic Detail opens in the Topic Detail view which graphs the KPIs. The KPIs in the title bar, present

title: Topic page
body: You can choose both the Partition and the Metric for the display. By default, the 0th partition will be displayed on using the metric offset.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Unravel provides auto-detection of lagging/stalled Consumer Groups. It allows you to drill down into your cluster and determine which consumers, topics, partitions are lagging or stalled. See Kafka Insights for a use case example of drilling down into lagging or stalled Consumer Groups.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Unravel determines Consumer status by evaluating the consumer's behavior over a sliding window. For example, we use average lag trend for 10 intervals (of 5 minutes duration each), covering a 50-minute period. Consumer Status is evaluated on several factors during the window for each partition it is consuming.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: For a topic partition Consumer status is:

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Stalled: if the Consumer commit offset for the topic partition is not increasing and lag is greater than zero.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Lagging: if the Consumer lag for the topic partition is increasing consistently, and an increase in lag from the start of the window to the last value is greater than lag threshold (e.g., 250).

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: The information is distilled down into a status for each partition, and then into a single status for the consumer. A consumer is either in one of the following states:

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: OK: the consumer is working and is current.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Warning: the consumer is working, but falling behind.

title: Unravel Insights for Kafka
body: Error: the consumer has stopped or stalled.

title: MapReduce Application Program Manager
body: The MapReduce Application Program Manager provides and easy way to understand the breakdown of the application. You can use this view to:

title: MapReduce Application Program Manager
body: Drill down into MapReduce jobs that make up the application, and

title: MapReduce Application Program Manager
body: Resolve inefficiencies, bottlenecks and reasons for failure within applications.

title: MapReduce Application Program Manager
body: It contains similar sections to the Hive Application Program Manager and additionally shows the timeline view of MapReduce job execution, logs and configuration.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the application to complete execution.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the application.

title: Tabs
body: By default, the MapReduce APM opens in the Graphs > Attempts view.

title: Tabs
body: Attempts: Number of task attempts are charted in "wall-clock" time. The aggregated time of all tasks running in on the Map/Reduce slot duration is noted below the graph.

title: Tabs
body: Containers, Vcores, and Memory: Graphs utilization of slot containers, vcores, and memory over time.

title: Tabs
body: When there is no data available for a graph, the tab is not shown. When a graph has less than four data points, the graph is converted from a line, shown above, to a bar graph.

title: Tabs
body: Timeline: Displays the details of each MapReduce job by showing the execution of each task on the machine it was executed on.

title: Tabs
body: The Timeline tab is divided into two sections:

title: Tabs
body: a Distribution chart (which displays either the Map or Reduce tasks)

title: Tabs
body: a bottom table which lists either the tasks by stages on servers or the list of tasks and their associated KPIs.

title: Tabs
body: The default displays the Map jobs and the timeline. You can change the Distribution Charts by selecting Map or Reduce (1). Whether to display the Timeline or Selected tasks (3). When displaying the timeline you can filter the display by Map, Reduce, Killed/Failed or All jobs (2). You can choose what timeline/tasks to display by dragging and highlighting a section of the distribution chart.

title: Tabs
body: Metrics: The metrics, their definitions and values.

title: Tabs
body: Logs: Lists the available logs by Map, Reduce and Application Master. Click on the tab to see the listing for that type (Map, Reduce, or Application Master). Click on an item to see the log.

title: Tabs
body: Configuration: The defined parameters and their values.

title: Tabs
body: Resource Usage: These graphs are useful for identifying critical resources that caused a performance degradation.

title: Tabs
body: Initially all the executors are displayed using the Metric systemCpuLoad. You can choose a different metric to display from the Metric pull down menu. Hover over an executor to bring up the Only option and click on it to display just the information for that executor. To graph all executors, hover above the list for the Show All option and click on it to display all.

title: Tabs
body: When no resource data is available the tab displays No metrics found. Metrics are displayed after Unravel has processed the application completely and Unravel's application sensors are enabled.

title: Tabs
body: Errors: Lists all errors associated with the job. Like job status, the errors are color coded and the total number of each type (fatal, errors, warnings) is noted. The top line lists the number of all jobs/task. The errors are grouped by tasks/jobs and then by severity. For each job/task the total and type of errors are noted. Time, keywords (if any) and a brief message is displayed for the error. Keywords extract important details from the errors messages/log data that can help developers/operators quickly "root cause" issues. "No errors found" is displayed when there are none.

title: Tabs
body: Tags: Lists the defined tag keys and associated values for the application. The example below has two tag keys, project and dept with each having one value, group11 and hr respectively.

title: Overview
body: A Spark Application consists of one or more Jobs, which in turn has one or more Stages.

title: Overview
body: Job: corresponds to a spark action, e.g., count, take, foreach.

title: Overview
body: The Spark Application Manager (APM) allows you to:

title: Overview
body: Quickly see which jobs and stages consumed the most resources.

title: Overview
body: View your application as a RDD execution graph.

title: Overview
body: Drill into the source code from the stage tile, spark stream batch tile, or the execution graph to locate the problems.

title: Overview
body: You can use the APM to analyze an application's behavior to:

title: Overview
body: Resolve inefficiencies, bottlenecks, and reasons for failure within applications.

title: Overview
body: Optimize resource allocation for Spark driver and executors.

title: Overview
body: Detect and fix inefficient and failed Spark apps.

title: Overview
body: Tune JVM settings for driver and executors.

title: Overview
body: Unravel provides insights into Spark applications and potentially tuning recommendations.

title: Overview
body: There are multiple Spark application types and the Spark APM's information can vary by the application type. Currently, Unravel distinguishes between:

title: Overview
body: Regardless of the application type and how they are submitted (e.g., from Notebooks, spark shells, or spark-submit), the Spark APMs are similar and there are common tabs/information across all types.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: A black title bar notes the type of tile (Spark, Job, Stage, etc). On the right side there are actions (), comment (), and minimize () glyph. For jobs and stages instead of actions there is a , click on it to see the job's or stage's parent.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: When the Spark application is a running streaming application, the title bar has an additional option to stop the auto refresh of the UI.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Unravel's Intelligence Engine provides insights into an application and may provide recommendations, suggestions, or insights into how to improve the application's run. When there are insights, a bar appears immediately below the title bar. If Unravel has recommendations, the insight bar is orange, otherwise it's blue. For more information about events, see Events and Insights.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: The next section contains the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and general application information.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Event icon: notes the number of events the Spark application had. If there were none, No Events is noted instead of the box. This Spark application has two (2) events, clicking on the icon brings up a panel which contains one or more sub-tabs, as relevant, e.g., Recommendations, Efficiencies, Application Failure. See the Event Panel examples for more information.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Application icon: notes the application's status and the window type (S-Spark, SJ-Spark Application and so on). The box is color coded based upon its status.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Job icon: notes the job type and status. The box is colored coded to indicate as the application's status.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Job Name: Next to the job name is an auto actions glyph () if the job has violated any actions. Hover over it to see a list of the violated actions. A fine-tuning glyph () appears when Unravel has tuning suggestions for the job.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: Job Information: job number, owner, queue, cluster and start/stop time.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: KPIs: these vary by job type.

title: The Spark Application Manager's Basic Layout
body: The last section, divided in half, has specific information related to the application. The sections for a specific Spark Application (e.g., Streaming) go into more detail. If the application is composed of tasks/jobs/stages they appear on the left side under Navigation or Stream. Clicking a row brings up detailed information about it in a separate tile/panel below. When there is an Auto Action column (), the number of events associated with the stage is listed. Clicking on block () toggles the display of the job tile.

title: Actions
body: Click on in the title bar to bring up the available actions.

title: Actions
body: When a yarn application is running you can kill or move it.

title: Actions
body: After the application has stopped, you can load logs and diagnostics. You can also create Session or an Auto Tune Session.

title: Actions
body: Clicking Load Diagnostics brings up a popup containing diagnostic information for the application. Load Logs refreshes the APM and populates/updates the Logs tab.

title: Common Tabs
body: Except for the Spark streaming application, the Application Manager view is split into two blocks and each block contains the following tabs.

title: Left Tabs
body: Errors - Lists all errors associated with the application. The errors are color coded (fatal, errors , warnings ) and the number for each type noted. The total number of errors is listed at the top. The errors are grouped by executors with the number and types of errors noted. Errors are categorized by severity, and include keywords and details associated with each. Keywords help to extract important details from the error messages/log data to help quickly root out the cause of a problem. If there are no errors, then "No errors found" is listed.

title: Left Tabs
body: Logs - Lists the critical logs that were collected for this Spark application. No Logs Found is displayed when Unravel is unable to load any log information.

title: Left Tabs
body: Click on the log name to see it, below is an excerpt of the executor-20 log.

title: Left Tabs
body: Conf - Lists the configuration parameters and their values. The tab opens listing all the properties, according to app/task/job. The number of properties displayed is noted above the list.

title: Left Tabs
body: You can narrow the list by choosing the configuration type to display; to see the Spark version select metadata. Metadata and driver are selected in the example below and the list narrowed from 1042 to two (2) properties. Some properties appear in multiple categories, e.g., spark.executor.extraJavaOptions is listed under Memory, Driver and Executor. You can search by name; searching on yarn displays every property containing the word yarn. Click Reset to display all properties.

title: Right Tabs
body: Program - Displays the program's source code if available. Both the Spark Stage and Execution graph link to tab and display code associated with each. Note: Unravel allows you to upload Spark programs, see Uploading Spark Programs.

title: Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts - Graphically and textually notes the number of tasks and their status. The donut graphs show the percentage of successful (green), failed (orange), and killed (red) tasks. The legend on the right lists the number of each. The graph on the left shows a job in which all tasks succeeded, while the graph on the right has all failed tasks. Frequently, the result is a combination. Hovering over the chart tells you the percentage of each.

title: Right Tabs
body: Graphs - There are three (3) types of graphs. Graphs use "wall clock time" as opposed to computer usage time.

title: Right Tabs
body: Running Containers: The number of running containers.

title: Right Tabs
body: When there is no data available for a graph, the tab is not shown. When a graph has less than four data points, the graph is converted from a line, shown above, to a bar graph.

title: Right Tabs
body: Resource - Graphs the resources the application/job/stage consumed.

title: Right Tabs
body: When no resource data is available the tab displays No metrics found. Metrics are displayed after Unravel has processed the application completely and Unravel's application sensors are enabled.

title: Right Tabs
body: By default the graph displays all executors using the metric availableMemory. Below the list notes the page, if more than one, that is being displayed. Click on the arrow to page down or up to display a page. Choose the metric for the graph using the pull-down menu. The metrics fall into one of the following categories: OS Memory, CPU, and Java Memory. Click on Get Data to see the resource information displayed in JSON. You can toggle whether a resource is displayed by clicking on it; it is greyed out when it's not displayed.

title: Right Tabs
body: You choose one or more series to display using the Select box. Clicking within the box brings up a list of all resources available. Click on the resource you want to display. You can choose to display from one to all resources. Only the chosen resources are listed below the box. Click on the X next to the resource to remove it from the list.

title: Right Tabs
body: Below is an example of the JSON when clicking on Get Data.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: Navigation - Lists the application's jobs with their relevant KPIs: Status, Start Time, Duration, Tasks, DFS Read, DFS Write, Stages. The jobs are sorted by Start Time in descending order.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: While the application is running, the Status column displays the job's completion percentage. The Tasks and Stages columns show the (current number completed)/(total). Below, Job ID 1 is 41% complete.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: This tab updates every 60 seconds. However, the live data Unravel receives is only updated upon:

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: The start of a Spark Job.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: The completion of a Spark Job or Stage.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: Unravel does not receive live data upon task completion, therefore when a stage is long running this tab will appear static, i.e., not refreshing.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: Once completed the total number of the Tasks and Stages are shown along with the number skipped. In the example below, 39,600 Tasks and 99 Stages were skipped.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: Clicking on a job row brings up its details in a Job Block. You can open the job even if it's running. The job block lists the KPIs Duration and # of Stages. It has three tabs, Stages, Gannt, and Metadata. The default view is the Stages tab. The stage table lists ID, Status, Start Time, Duration, Tasks (Complete/Total), Shuffle Read, Shuffle Write, Input (total data read by the application), and Output (total data written by the application). By default, the stages are sorted by Start Time in descending order. Clicking on a stage brings up its details in a tile below. See Spark Stage.

title: Scala, Java, PySpark, and SQL-Query Navigation Tab
body: This example is for Job 1 above, which is only 41% complete. Here the # of Stages lists 199, but only 82 completed jobs are listed in the table. As jobs are completed they are added to the table.

title: Spark Job
body: A job is created for every Spark action, e.g., count, take, foreach. A job consists one or more stages. The job below has three stages, two (2) keyby RDD's and one (1) count. You can see the source code associated with the job in the stage tile. The Stages table lists each stage's KPIs so you can quickly see which stage consumed the most time.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: The wall-clock time it took to complete the job.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: # of Stages: Number of stages to the job.

title: It has three tabs:
body: Stages - This tab is the default view. It lists the stages with their KPIs and is initially sorted on Start Time in ascending order.

title: It has three tabs:
body: Gannt Chart - This tab again shows all the stages, graphically displaying the time spent in each. The stages are initially displayed in order of execution, i.e., first, second, ..., nth.

title: It has three tabs:
body: Metadata - Lists all the attributes and values for the jobs.

title: Spark Stage
body: The Stage tile can help you pinpoint problems with the stage, i.e., skewing, and see the source code associated with the stage.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: The computer time it took to complete the job.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Date IO: Total input and output associated with the stage.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: It has two tabs, by default it opens in the graph tab displaying the task attempts.

title: Graph
body: Task Attempt - Displays the number of total tasks for the stage and number of total attempts made to run these tasks. The number of tasks is noted on the left side of the bar with the number of attempts on the right. The donut chart graphically displays the successful () and failed () attempts which are also listed in the legend to the right. Hover over a section of the chart to see the percentage of successful and failed task attempts. In the below example, all tasks attempts have succeeded.

title: Graph
body: Program Details - Displays the stage's program details. Unravel extracts Source file name and call line. Click on the source file or line number to see program code. The Description shows the stage's Stack trace. The first line is always a call to the Spark library. The source file name and line number are extracted from the second line.

title: Time Line Tab
body: The Time Line tab has two sections:

title: Time Line Tab
body: Three tabs below the chart: Time Line, Timeline Breakdown, and Selected Tasks.

title: Time Line Tab
body: By default, the Time Line tab opens with the Distribution Charts displaying the Map Tasks over ShuffleMap information. You can toggle the chart using the radio buttons (1) to show Disk Bytes Spilled, Memory Bytes Spilled, and Records Read.

title: Time Line Tab
body: The lower section opens displaying the Time Line tab, which initially lists all the stages regardless of status. You can choose to filter the stages (2) by Tasks or Killed/Failed. Hovering over a task brings up a text-box with that stage's details.

title: Time Line Tab
body: This is useful to identify bottlenecks. For each executor used in the current stage, multiple metrics are graphed: Scheduler Delay, Executor Deserialization Time, Fetch Wait Time, Executor Computing Time, JVM GC time, Result Serialization Time and Getting Result Time.

title: Time Line Tab
body: Using the ratio of Executor Computing Time to the total execution time you can determine where the executor spent most of its time:

title: Time Line Tab
body: Selected Tasks - A list of tasks, if any, for the stage.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: is the number, if any, of Unravel insights for the query. See the here for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: The "wall clock" time it took for the application to complete.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Stages: The number of stages in the query.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Navigation - Lists the application's jobs with their relevant KPIs: Status, Start Time, Duration, Partitions/Tasks (), DFS Read, DFS Write, # Stages. See above for more details.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Execution - The execution graph shows a RDD DAG of the application. The application's RDDs are represented by the vertices while the edges are the Operations to be applied. Any particular RDD can involve multiple stages so there is not a 1-1 mapping between a RDD and stages. The graph is "linked" to the Program tab. If the source code is available, clicking on a vertex brings up the source line associated with the RDD.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: If the program tab displays the code it is linked with the DAG. If you display the execution and program tab simultaneously, as shown below. Click on the vertex to highlight the relevant code. Below we see the corresponding code for vertex 18.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Below we expanded the above area, and vertices 15-19 are shown (the vertex number is noted in the circle). The vertex lists the type of RDD, partitions used, Spark call, and the number of stages which were involved. Below RDD represented by vertices 17-16 involved two (2) stages, while 15-16 had five (5). Hover over the vertex to bring up an information box, containing the RDD description and CallSite (source line) which called the RDD transformation.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: The execution graph is not displayed when there are more than 1000 RDDs in the generated DAG.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Displays the stages using a Gantt Chart. The table is sorted on Start Time in ascending order.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Errors, Log and Conf Tabs - For an explanation of these tabs see Errors, Logs, and Conf.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Program - When available it displays the program associated with the application. See above for an example of this tab and its relation to the Execution graph.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resources - For an explanation of these tabs see Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resource.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: is the number, if any, of Unravel insights for the query. See here for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: The "wall clock" time it took for the application to complete.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: # of Stages: The number of stages in the query.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Navigation - Lists the application's jobs with their relevant KPIs: Status, Start Time, Duration, Partitions/Tasks (), DFS Read, DFS Write, # Stages. See above for more details.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Execution - A execution graph of the query. There are times when the DAG is too large to display and it will be noted. See above for more details.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Gantt Chart - Displays the stages using a Gantt Chart. For more details see above.

title: Left Five Tabs
body: Errors, Log, and Conf Tabs For an explanation of these tabs see Errors, Logs, and Conf.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Program - This tab connects all the pieces of the SQL query. The table lists all queries with significant KPIs and the top five stages, i.e., the stages with the longest duration. The lower section contains two tabs, SQL and Program. The SQL tab displays the SQL query in either query or plan mode. The Program tab lists the query's corresponding Program. For a particular query, the SQL query text, Program, and stages are linked.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: The Query table is sorted on the query's duration in descending order. Similarly, the stages are sorted on duration in descending order left to right.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: The SQL tab is displayed using the query view. The query with the longest duration (first row) is shown.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Unravel loads whatever information is available, even if the information is incomplete.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Click on the Query ID to display its SQL and program. Click on the stage to display its Spark Stage Detail. See Spark Stage Details for further information on the stage view. To switch between SQL Query and Plan view, click on the plan/query button in the upper right-hand corner of the SQL window. To copy the SQL query to your clipboard click on the Copy button. You do not have to have the query view showing in order to copy it.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: The screenshot below is showing the default window, the SQL query for Query ID 4.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Scroll down to see the entire SQL Plan. Click on Query to return to the program.

title: Four Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resources - For an explanation of these tabs see Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resource.

title: Spark - Streaming
body: You have the option to stop the UI from refreshing for running streaming applications. This allows you to examine and drill down in the application without the refreshing interfering. Click the stop refresh on the right-hand side of the title bar.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: The KPIs refer to the entire Spark job composed of jobs which in turn have stages.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: is the number, if any, of Unravel insights for the query. See the here for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: the total time to process all stages. (The wall clock time can be calculated from the start and end times are on the left-hand side of the job bar.)

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Jobs: The number of jobs that make up the streaming.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Stages: The number of stages that make up the streaming.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Unlike other Spark Application Managers this has a Stream tab on the right. The manager opens displaying the Stream tab on the right and the Program on the right.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: Stream - Displays the core of a Streaming Application. From here you drill down into the batches, the main processing unit for Spark streaming. The graph displays the number of events/second (the bars) with a superimposed line graph of the chosen metric. By default, Scheduling Delay is used. You can change the date range to display or the metric used via the Metric pull-down menu (1). You can choose Scheduling Delay, Processing Time or Total Delay. In the example below, the graph is displaying Scheduling Delay Time.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: It has two sections; by default, they display the entire run over the last 7 days. You can zoom in on a section of graph by pulling the tabs left or right (2). The table lists the Completed Batches relevant to the time period selected. Each batch has its KPI's listed. In the view above, the entire stream time is displayed, therefore all Completed Batches are displayed and in this case there are seven (7) pages. In the example below, we have zoomed in on the last two minutes, the table now lists the batches completed in that time period. The tables now contains only one (1) page, versus the seven (7) above.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: The table lists only the first three batches, but you can page through the table (3). By default, the streams are sorted on start time in ascending order. When you sort the batches, they are sorted across all tables, i.e., if Start Time is switched to descending list, nth batch becomes the first, the n-1 the second, etc.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: Click on a batch to bring up the Spark Stream Batch tile. You can only open one batch job at a time. The batch window lists all the jobs associated with the batch and the batch's metadata. Its title bar notes it's a Spark Stream Batch view and that it's part of a Spark Streaming application. The KPI's, Duration, Processing Delay, Scheduling Delay, and Total Delay refer to this Batch job. It has two tabs, Output Operation and Input.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: The example below is of the batch in the first line of the table above. The Stream Batch has two calls and the first call has two (2) jobs. Since these jobs are run in parallel, the job with the longest time determines the duration of the batch. The description notes the RDD and the call line; clicking on the description displays the associated code in the program window. Click on the Job ID to see the Spark Job information.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: The Input Tab lists all the Topics consumed.

title: Left Four Tabs
body: Errors, Log, and Conf - For an explanation of these tabs see Errors, Logs, and Conf.

title: Right Four Tabs
body: Program - The program (if uploaded by the user) is shown in this tab.

title: Right Four Tabs
body: Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resources - For an explanation of these tabs see Task Attempts, Graphs, and Resource.

title: Tez Application Program Manager
body: The Tez Application Program Manager provides a detailed view into the behavior of Hive queries as a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph).

title: Tez Application Program Manager
body: To troubleshoot Tez data collection issues, check /usr/local/unravel/logs/unravel_ew_1.log.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: By default the Tez APM opens showing the Navigation and Program Tabs.

title: Left Tabs
body: Navigation: List the DAG jobs with KPIs, Duration and I/O. See the DAG Detail information below.

title: Left Tabs
body: Configuration: List the configuration parameters and their values.

title: Left Tabs
body: Tags: Lists the defined tag keys and associated values for the application. The example below has two tag keys, project and dept with each having one value, group11 and hr respectively.

title: Right Tabs
body: Containers, Vcores, and Memory: Graphs utilization of slot containers, Vcores, and memory over time.

title: Right Tabs
body: When there is no data available for a graph, the tab is not shown. When a graph has less than four data points, the graph is converted from a line, shown above, to a bar graph.

title: Right Tabs
body: Resources: Graphs the resources consumed. By default, the Resource tab displays the first ten (10) series using the systemCpuLoad metric. You can select one or more series to display in the Select Box. You can change the default number of series to show (1-n). Clicking on a series name causes the graph to display that series alone. You choose the Metric to graph from the pull down menu. Click Get Data to retrieve the data for that metric, it can be viewed in its Raw form, JSON, or headers.

title: Right Tabs
body: When no resource data is available the tab displays No metrics found. Metrics are displayed after Unravel has processed the application completely and Unravel's application sensors are enabled.

title: DAG Detail
body: The DAG detail has six tabs:

title: DAG Detail
body: Graph: Displays the vertices and their relationship to each other. Clicking on a node brings up the task details.

title: DAG Detail
body: Counter: Lists all the relevant counters for the Tez-DAG and their values.

title: DAG Detail
body: Vertex Timeline: Displays the timeline for all tasks. The task time can be displayed in both Wall Clock time and Total Run time as applicable. Hover over the task to display the information in text.

title: DAG Detail
body: All Vertices: List each vertex and their KPIs. The Vertices are searchable by Vertex Name; vertices containing the string will be displayed.

title: DAG Detail
body: All Task: List all tasks, their status (failed, success, etc.), vertex name and other relevant information. The tasks are searchable by Task ID and Vertex name; Tasks containing the string will be displayed.

title: DAG Detail
body: All Task Attempts: List all attempts, their status (failed, success, etc.), vertex name and other relevant information. The task attempts are searchable by Attempt ID, Task ID and Vertex name; Task attempts containing the string will be displayed.

title: DAG Detail
body: Changed Configuration: Lists all relevant parameters and their value.

title: Workflow Application Program Manager
body: The Workflow Application Program Manager provides a comprehensive view to understand workflows and their patterns of execution. It is used by Workflow (Pipelines) owners

title: Workflow Application Program Manager
body: to identify anomalies, inefficiencies and bottlenecks in workflow instances.

title: Workflow Application Program Manager
body: The Workflow Manager helps pipeline owners easily maintain SLAs. (Applications that have a Workflow parent will have a link to the workflow in the Goto column in Applications > Applications.)

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Events: The number, if any, of Unravel insights for this query. See Event Panel & Insights for more information.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Duration: Total time taken by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Data I/O: Total data read and written by the query.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: Number of Yarn Apps: The number of apps that make up the workflow.

title: Key Performance Indicators
body: The APM opens showing the Navigation and Compare tabs by default.

title: Left Tabs
body: Navigation: Provides an easy way to understand the breakdown of the workflow the applications which comprise the Workflow, e.g., Hive, Spark, MapReduce, Oozie. Click on More to display the jobs/apps which comprise the type.

title: Left Tabs
body: Below the second Oozienode is shown, it consists one MapReduce job and three Hive jobs. The Hive jobs comprise one or more tasks, so that too can be expanded. In the example below, the second Oozienode has been expanded along with the first Hive job within it. You can click on any job to see the application manager for it. In the example, below you can click on the expanded Hive job to bring up the Hive application manager. Similarly, you can click on the mapreduce job within the Hive job to go directly to it. Click on Less to close the list.

title: Left Tabs
body: Execution: Displays the execution graph of the workflow. Click to zoom in, and to zoom in. Click to return to the initial display. Hover over a node within the graph to see a text box which information about the node task.

title: Left Tabs
body: Errors: Lists all errors associated with the job. Like job status, the errors are color coded and the total number of each type (fatal, errors, warnings) is noted. The top line lists the number of all jobs/task. The errors are grouped by tasks/jobs and then by severity. For each job/task the total and type of errors are noted. Time, keywords (if any) and a brief message is displayed for the error. Keywords extract important details from the errors messages/log data that can help developers/operators quickly "root cause" issues. "No errors found" is displayed when there are none.

title: Left Tabs
body: Tags: Lists the defined tag keys and associated values for the application. The example below has two tag keys, project and dept with each having one value, group11 and hr respectively.

title: Right Tabs
body: Compare: Provides a quick way to understand how well a workflow run compares to its other runs. Hovering your pointer graph displays instances top KPIs such as duration, data I/O, resources, and the number of jobs in that instance. Clicking on the point in the chart brings up the Workflow APM for that instance. The graph Metrics choices are I/O, MR Jobs, Resource and Events. The Workflow APM above show an example of the compare tab.

title: Right Tabs
body: Task Attempts: Displays charts for Map Task, Reduce, and Spark Tasks, broken down by success, failed, and killed as appropriate.

title: Right Tabs
body: Attempts: Graphs the attempts over the time interval in Wall Clock time and list the Map and Reduce Slot Duration in total computing time below.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Unravel's auto actions automates the monitoring of your compute cluster by allowing you to define complex actionable rules on different cluster metrics. You can use an auto action to alert you to a situation needing manual intervention, e.g., resource contention or stuck jobs. Additionally, it can be set to automatically kill an application or move it to a different queue.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: The Unravel Server processes auto actions by:

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Collecting various metrics from the cluster(s).

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Aggregating the collected metrics according to user-defined rules.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Applying defined actions for each rule violation.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: A logical expression that is used to aggregate cluster metrics and to evaluate the rule. A rule has two conditions:

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Prerequisite conditions: The conditions which cause a violation, e.g., the number of jobs running, memory used.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Defining conditions: Who/what/when can cause the violation, e.g., user, applications.

title: Auto Actions Overview
body: Actions for Unravel Server to execute whenever it detects a rule violation.

title: Manage > Auto Actions
body: The auto actions tab provides a quick way to view auto actions and quickly see their status, along with its defined actions and scope. The tab displays all defined auto actions separated into an Active and Inactive list. You enable/disable by clicking the check box on the left. You can edit () or delete () an auto action regardless of its status. Click to copy the auto actions JSON code. At the top are buttons which allow you to define new auto actions.

title: Manage > Auto Actions
body: Hovering over the auto action's name gives you the description which was entered when defining the auto action. Hovering over action or scope glyph brings up its detail. For example, for the active auto action above:

title: Manage > Auto Actions
body: The Actions and Scope columns contains all available options. When an option has been set, i.e., no longer using the default setting, it is highlighted. It is possible to set an auto action which contains no actions, see quicktest below. Such an auto action simply has when it was triggered logs and retains the data. Every auto action must have a scope. When the auto action has an action or scope defined via an Expert Rule, that action or scope is not noted in the table. The auto action, quicktest below, does not note a scope; however one was specified via an Expert Rule. The History of Runs column lists the number of times, if any, the auto action was triggered. Click on the number to bring up its history.

title: Manage > Auto Actions
body: Click on the History of Runs for detailed information when the auto action was triggered. The history notes the time the action was triggered, contains a link a Cluster View (see below), and a link to the offending app. Hover over the app's link to see the app's type and click on it to bring the app's APM.

title: Manage > Auto Actions
body: Click the run's Link button to bring up the Cluster View (Operations > Usage Details > Infrastructure) for that particular run. The Cluster View shows a time slice, ±5 minutes from when the auto action was triggered and lists all the applications running during that period. This application table is similar to the application table shown under Applications > Applications. Not all the running applications will have triggered an auto action during the time slice. Click on a graph to show the applications running at that point in time. The Notifications column () notes if the application triggered the auto action (), has tuning suggestions (), or both (). In the example below, two applications were running at the time; both triggered the action but neither has tuning suggestions. Hovering over the brings up a pop-up listing the violations; in this example the first application violated two separate auto actions.

title: 'Snoozing' Auto Actions
body: The snooze function prevents automatic actions from repeating during a specified period, if and only if,

title: 'Snoozing' Auto Actions
body: See Snooze Feature for more information on snooze and an example of how it works.

title: 'Snoozing' Auto Actions
body: The time repeated violations are to be ignored for the violator, e.g., app, user. If the violation is still occurring when awakened the Auto Action executes the action(s) and the violator is once again snoozed. An auto action containing a kill or move action is never snoozed.

title: 'Snoozing' Auto Actions

title: 'Snoozing' Auto Actions
body: When you change the snooze time period, all applications currently snoozed are reset. Upon next violation the application is "snoozed" using new snooze value.

title: To change the snooze time
body: On Unravel Server open /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties with vi.

title: To change the snooze time
body: Search for com.unraveldata.auto.action.snooze.period.ms. Set the property to the new value and save the file. In the example below, snooze is set to two (2) hours.
