Running Duration versus Final Duration Inconsistency
body: Running Duration versus Final Duration Inconsistency

title: Running Duration versus Final Duration Inconsistency
body: Unravel calculates and publishes internally the current duration for applications of the following types in real-time, i.e., when in the running state. Upon the application completion Unravel receives the actual end time and performs the final duration calculation. This can lead to an inconsistency where the duration aggregated and published during the running state is greater than the duration published upon the application's completion.

title: Running Duration versus Final Duration Inconsistency
Missing Auto Action Violation Badge
body: The badge is not displayed for following application types. For example, in the cluster view above these applications do not display even when they have violated an auto action during the time period shown.

title: "Cloud" Type Setups are not Supported
body: Currently, auto actions are not triggered for applications on a “cloud” type setup (EMR, HDI, Qubole, etc.) of Unravel; therefore the Kill and Move to Queue actions are not available in "cloud" setup as well. You can define auto actions, but they will never trigger and will cause connection errors to be logged in the etl daemon log file.

title: Auto Action Template
body: Whether using Create from Template or Build Rule you have 5 sections. Expert Rule is simply a text box.

title: Name and Description
body: The name is mandatory and is used by the UI for all auto actions' displays; we recommend using a name which reflects the auto action's purpose.

title: Name and Description
body: The description is optional, but we recommend completing it with a succinct description of the action. When users hover over the action's name, the description is displayed.

title: Name and Description
body: This example is from Create from Template. The name is already filled with the same name as the template and is highlighted. You can change the name.

title: Ruleset
body: At least one rule type (User, Queue, Cluster, Apps, and Expert Rule ) must be defined. Each rule type allows you to define rules using pull down menus for a metric, type or state. The Expert Rule is available only in the Build Rule template.

title: Ruleset
body: See Supported Cluster Metrics for a list and definition of available metrics.

title: Ruleset
body: Value: any valid numeric value. The default value is 0; were you to leave it the auto action would constantly trigger.

title: Ruleset
body: mapreduce, yarn, tez, spark, impala, workflow and hive

title: Ruleset
body: new, new_saving, submitted, accepted, scheduled, allocated, allocatedSaving, launched, running, finishing, finished, killed, failed, undefined, newAny, allocatedAny, pending, and * (all).

title: Ruleset
body: Multiple rule types are evaluated in conjunction with each other using:

title: Ruleset
body: Or and And work as you would expect. See Same Logical Operator for the definition of Same and its implementation.

title: Using "Create From Template"
body: This template has the Ruleset defined as needed to fulfill the template type, e.g., Rogue Contention In Queues (allocated memory). The template highlights the fields you can or should change. You can not delete/add any of the rule types or add/delete rules. You can change the metric, comparison, type, and state if available by using the pull down menus. If you change the Metric, Type, or State the template will not perform the task you have selected, e.g., Rogue Contention In Queues (allocated memory). The default value for the metric comparison is 0. You must change the value otherwise the auto action constantly triggers. Multiple rules types are Same'd together. See Same Logical Operator for its definition and implementation

title: Using Build Rule
body: The Ruleset initially lists the type of rules available, User, Queue, Cluster, App, or Expert Rule. Click on the rule type you want to define. Below Add Queue is selected with the options to add rules for metric, type and state. These options and only these options, are available for every rule type except the Expert Rule template which is a text box. You must define at least one rule for each of the rule type selected.

title: Using Build Rule
body: In the example below, Metric and Type are selected for the Queue rule type. You use the pull-down menus to select metric, the comparison operator, type, or state. See above for further information. A second rule, Apps has been added. When multiple rules are selected, you must choose how they are evaluated in conjunction with each other. The default is the Same operator, but you may select Or or And. See Same Logical Operator for the definition of Same and its implementation. Or and And work as you would expect. You can choose up to two rules, e.g., user & user, expert rule & queue, etc.

title: Using Build Rule
body: Click Close to delete a rule type and click trash () to delete a specific rule. If you close the rule before saving the auto actions, your settings are lost.

title: Options
body: Define the scope (User, Queue, Cluster, and Application Name), the period in which the auto action acts on a violation (Time), and how long/short the violation must occur before the auto action takes action (Sustained).

title: Options
body: When you select an option its default is All, except Time which defaults to always and Sustained Violation which defaults to none.

title: Options
body: When using Create from Template the required option is already checked and uses the default. Any changes you make may cause the auto action to not perform as expected.

title: Options
body: As of 4.5.07 when using Create from Template the options sections lists only options that are available for the chosen template. For instance, the Rogue Impala templates only has Queue, Cluster, and Application Name options.

title: Options
body: Check the box next to the option's name to select it.

title: Options
body: You can narrow the scope of User, Queue, Cluster, and Application Name by using Only or Except. Only applies the rule to only those applications specified while Except applies them to all but those specified. Use the Transform to specify the names using a regular expression. The example below is using the Application Name in the Except mode with the application MyApp. You can add more applications by clicking Add Application. Since no regular expression is specified, this option applies to all applications except MyApp. Create from Template defaults to All.

title: Options
body: The Time sets the time range and time zone during which the auto action can be triggered. The auto action remains active but does not trigger outside of the specified time range. The default start and end time is when auto action is defined with the time zone set to America/Los Angeles. If you do not change the default time the auto action can be triggered for only one (1) minute a day. Enter the time directly or click on the clock () in the time box. Time is entered in 24 hour time. The end time must be later than the start time.

title: Options
body: Sustained violation specifies a length of time violation must occur before the auto action is triggered. This allows time for specified by the option to "self correct" and lowers the number of false positives The default is zero, i.e., all auto actions are immediately triggered upon violation and the specified action is carried out. You can select minimum or maximum mode. In both cases the auto action must be continually violated.

title: Options
body: Minimum sustained mode triggers the action(s) only if this violation was continuously detected for at least the specified period. This allows you to suppress triggering of violation actions for “on-offs” and metric spikes. These are normal in multi-tenant cluster environments can return to normal operation on their own. If a violation stops before the minimum time period, the clock is reset for that application. For instance, if the minimum time is one (1) hour and the application violates the auto action for 58 minutes and then returns to normal – no action is taken and the time period for that application resets to 0.

title: Options
body: Maximum sustained mode triggers the action(s) only if this violation is continuously detected for less than the specified period of time. This suppresses the triggering of violations for long-running applications and triggers on auto action rule scope on ad-hoc short-lived user applications.

title: Actions
body: Defines the actions to take when the auto action is triggered.

title: Actions
body: As of 4.5.07 when using Create from Template the actions section lists only options that are available for the chosen template. For instance, Impala and Workflow templates do not have the option to Move or Kill the application/workflow.

title: Actions
body: Build Rule and Create from Template, with the exception of Impala query, allow you to specify the following actions: Send an email, HTTP Post, Post to Slack, Move App to Queue,and Kill App. Build Rule allows you to enter an Expert Action. See Expert Mode for information on defining an action in JSON. See Auto Actions and Pagerduty for using Unravel's API to receive notifications via Pagerduty. You can not kill a Hive, Impala, or Workflow application.

title: Actions

title: Actions

title: Actions
body: Move App is a non-destructive action that should not affect the cluster performance and its availability to the user; however we suggest using it with caution.

title: Actions
body: Kill App is a destructive action. It can affect the cluster performance and its availability to the users. This option is primarily to kill rogue applications that are causing contention of a cluster resources.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: The tab displays all defined auto actions separated into an Active and Inactive list. You can enable/disable an auto action by clicking the check box on the right side of its row. You can edit or delete an auto action regardless of its status by clicking on edit () or delete () on the right side of the row.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: To create a new auto action, click either Create from Template, Build Rule, or Expert Rule.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Create from Template - provides a partially completed template designed for the task. The only ruleset options available are relevant to the task being defined. Fields which you need to fill in are highlighted.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Build Rule - provides an empty template, with all the options available.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Expert Rule - provides only a text box for defining your auto action using JSON.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: See Auto Actions Templates for descriptions and use of the template's sections.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Click on Create a Template. All the available templates are displayed. Click on the template you wish to use.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Resource contention in cluster - monitors overall memory or Vcore usage on a cluster and number of pending/running jobs in order to detect when the cluster is struggling to accommodate all submitted jobs and falls into a resource contention pitfall. Once detected, the specified auto action(s) are taken.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Resource contention in queue - monitors overall memory or Vcore usage in a queue and number of pending/running jobs in order to detect a state when the queue is struggling to accommodate all submitted jobs and falls into a resource contention pitfall. Once detected, the specified auto action(s) are taken.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Rogue user - identifies so-called “rogue” users on a cluster who can potentially affect other users and the cluster as a whole, i.e., users who are submitting jobs that are using too much of the cluster resources (memory or Vcores). Once the rogue user is detected, the specified auto action(s) are taken.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Rogue application - identifies so-called “rogue” applications on a cluster which can potentially affect other applications and the cluster as a whole, i.e., applications that are using too much of the cluster resources (memory or Vcores). Once the rogue application is detected, the specified auto action(s) are taken.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Rogue Impala query (HDFS Read/Write) - identifies so-called “rogue” impala queries on a cluster which can potentially affect other applications and the cluster as a whole, i.e., queries that are using too much of the cluster resources (memory or Vcores). Once the rogue application is detected, the specified auto action(s) are taken.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Long running YARN application - monitors elapsed time of a running YARN application, MapReduce, Spark, Hive, etc., and executes the action(s) if the job runs longer than desired.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Long running Hive query - tracks Hive jobs by monitoring the total elapsed time of a running Hive query and executes the action(s) if the job runs longer than desired.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Long running workflow - tracks workflow jobs by monitoring total elapsed time of a running workflow and executes the action(s) if the job runs longer than desired.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Long Impala query - tracks Impala jobs by monitoring total elapsed time of a running workflow and executes the action(s) if the job runs longer than desired.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Complete the template. Note: Changing the predefined ruleset can result in the action not behaving as anticipated.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Click on Build Rule and complete the template.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: The Auto Actions engine is capable of much more than is available through the templates. Expert Rule is a very powerful mode giving you total access Auto Actions engine complete capabilities. You can create complex rulesets to accommodate almost any cluster monitoring requirements. JSON is used to define the rules and actions.

title: Creating Auto Actions
body: Before using this mode, you should have clear understanding of auto actions concepts. See the Expert Rule section for a detailed explanation on how to define an auto action. See the Sample Auto Actions section for examples of rules and actions.

title: Creating Auto Actions

title: Overview
body: Expert Rule is a very powerful mode of operation which provides you with greater flexibility than is available through the templates. Using the Expert Rule you can create complex rulesets to accommodate almost any cluster monitoring requirements. Before using this mode, you should have clear understanding of auto actions concepts and capabilities, along with JSON, which is used to define the auto action.

title: Overview
body: This mode's flexibility and power makes it dangerous and capable of wreaking havoc. Consult with the Unravel team before attempting to use the Expert Rule.

title: Overview

title: Overview
body: Prerequisite conditions: boolean conditions that must be met for the Unravel Server to evaluate the Auto Action's defining conditions, e.g., Auto Action should run from 8.00 and 14.00.

title: Overview
body: Defining conditions: boolean conditions that must be met for the Unravel Server to execute the corresponding action, e.g., the application can't run more than 50 mapper tasks.

title: Overview
body: Actions: steps to be taken when the prerequisite and defining conditions evaluate to true, e.g., send an email to admin.

title: Actions can be Ignored When in Conflict
body: Below we specified two actions, move_to_queue and kill_app, correctly; but in conjunction they don't make sense. If we kill the app how can we then move it? Why bother moving the app if we are going to kill it? Effectively only one action can be executed. In this case Unravel gives precedence to kill_app and move_to_queue is ignored.

title: Actions can be Ignored When in Conflict

title: Action(s) Fail if the Required Information is Invalid or not Specified.
body: Below are two actions with invalid information. In send_mail the addresses are invalid and the owner is not to be notified. The http_post has an invalid URL. Unravel Auto Action's engine sends the email and tries to perform the HTTP post; however both actions will fail. Since only these two actions are specified, no action is effectively taken. However, the UI stills records the trigger and retains the information to populate for Operations > Dashboard Auto Actions tile, history of runs and the cluster view for each time the action was triggered. (See Auto Actions Overview.)

Unravel Auto Action's engine sends the email and tries to perform the http post; however both actions will fail. Since only these two actions are specified, no action is effectively taken. However, the UI stills records the trigger and retains the information to populate for Operations > Dashboard Auto Actions tile, history of runs and the cluster view for each time the action was triggered. title: Example Actions
body: You must take care when entering information. A specified action fails if you enter the incorrect information, e.g., bad email address/URL/channel, wrong or non-existent queue.

title: Send_email
body: Unlike when using Create from Template or Build Rule, the UI won't notify you when entering an invalid address on the face of it, e.g., myMailaddress&com. You can automatically send a email to the owner by setting to_owner to true; Unravel handles the rest. You can enter multiple email addresses using a comma separated list.

title: http_post
body: Just like send_email you won't be notified if you HTTPS is invalid on the face of it, e.g., userAtTheCompany. You can enter multiple URLs using a comma separated list.

title: post_in_slack
body: Verify that your token is correct, and the channels are entered correctly. You can enter multiple channels using a comma separated list.

title: move_to_queue
body: Be sure to enter an existing and correct queue. This is non-destructive but none-the-less may affect the cluster performance and its availability to the users.

title: kill_app
body: This is straight forward, but kill_app is a destructive action and may affect the cluster performance and its availability to the users.

title: Same Logical Operator
body: SAME: logically and's rules plus adding the further constraint that the rules must be violated within same scope in order to trigger an AutoAction.

title: Example - A Rule Designed to Alert on Rogue Users.
body: Example - A Rule Designed to Alert on Rogue Users.

title: Human-readable form
body: If any user is running more than 10 jobs on a cluster and the same user has more than 5 jobs pending then report the user as rogue.

title: More formally
body: (any user has > 10 running apps) SAME (any user has > 5 pending jobs)

title: Implementation
body: Internally the back-end uses a clustering technique to implement the SAME operator. AutoActions runs all metric aggregations simultaneously. When the metrics are received and aggregated it then evaluates all rules and expressions. It starts at the evaluation tree's leaf expressions and works its way up to the root expression.

title: Implementation
body: Assume the above rule, three users (A, B, and C), and the following conditions

title: Implementation
body: user A has 12 running and 3 pending apps

title: Implementation
body: user B has 7 running and 1 pending apps

title: Implementation
body: user C has 21 running and 11 pending apps

title: Implementation
body: First, the two simple rules are evaluated:

title: Implementation
body: does user have more than 10 apps running?

title: Implementation
body: does user have more than 5 apps pending?

title: Implementation
body: Second, it applies clustering by scope and for each cluster it counts the number rules triggered. In the back-end code this procedure is called “linking” of rules (see Ruleset.java).

title: Implementation
body: Third, all groups with less than the needed number of links (2 in this case) are discarded. If some of the rules were triggered, that rule is reset for the group.

title: Implementation
body: Cluster “User A” has a link count = 1 so it's reset and discarded.

title: Implementation
body: User A > 10 running apps? → TRUE reset to

title: Implementation
body: Cluster “User B”, link count = 0 so it's discarded.

title: Implementation
body: Finally, only the users that have triggered all rules remain.

title: Implementation
body: User C meets the criteria for the Rogue User AutoAction, therefore User C triggers the AutoAction and the alert is sent and/or the actions performed.

title: Comparison to AND
body: Both User A and User C would have triggered the above rule were AND used instead of SAME, i.e., (any user has > 10 running apps) AND (any user has > 5 pending jobs).

title: Comparison to AND
body: To achieve the same result as the above example using AND instead of SAME, you would need to create the following AutoAction rule for each and every user on the cluster:

title: Comparison to AND
body: (Username has > 10 running apps) AND (Username has > 5 pending apps)

title: Snooze Feature
body: The snooze function prevents automatic actions from being repeated during a specified period, if and only if,

title: Snooze Feature
body: it is the same violation context and the action adds no further information to the violation, i.e., essentially noise.

title: Snooze Feature
body: For example, alerts of user A violating rule Y are snoozed as the alert adds no new context the user A's violation. App is used below, but the auto action can be defined for user, queues, etc.

title: Snooze Feature
body: An auto action specifying a Kill App or Move App action can not be snoozed.

title: Snooze Feature
body: Snooze is set the first time the app violates the rule.

title: Snooze Feature
body: The auto action itself continues to run uninterrupted whether zero (0) or all apps currently covered by the auto action are snoozed.

title: Snooze Feature
body: The auto action takes action for any app not snoozing at the time of violation.

title: Snooze Feature
body: If an app is still violating upon awaking, the specified actions are performed and the application is snoozed once again.

title: Snooze Feature
body: See here for information on Auto Actions Limitations

title: Example
body: Rule/Action: if app uses memory > 1 GB send email

title: Example
body: A > 1 GB → email is sent + snooze set (snoozed until 20:30).

title: Example
body: B < 1 GB → application is not violating so nothing is done.

title: Example
body: A > 1 GB → snoozing, no action is taken.

body: B > 1 GB → email is sent + snooze set (snoozed until 20:40).

body: A > 1 GB → snoozing, no action is taken.

body: B > 1 GB → snoozing, no action is taken.

title: Example
body: A > 1G B → application wakes and is still in violation. An email is sent + snooze set (runs until 21.00).

title: Example
body: >B > 1 GB → snoozing, no action is taken.

title: Example
body: A > 1 GB → snoozing, no action is taken.

title: Example
body: >B < 1 GB → app wakes. app not violating so nothing is done.

body: Predefined templates cover a variety of jobs, yet they can lack the specificity or complexity you need for monitoring.

title: Auto Actions Rules, Predefined Templates v Expert Mode
body: For instance, you can use the Rogue Application template to determine if jobs are using to many memory or Vcore resources by alerting for jobs using more than 1 TB of memory. However, if you only want to know if only Map Reduce jobs are using > 1 TB, the template won't suffice. For such instances, you need to write your Auto Actions using the Expert Mode template with the rules and some actions written in JSON.

body: While applications in quarantine queue continue to run, the queue is preemptable and has a low resource allocation. If any other queue needs resources, it can preempt applications in the quarantine queue. Moving rogue applications to quarantine queue frees resources for other applications. Below we are alerting on Vcores; to alert on memory just substitute memory for Vcores in the following rules.

body: You should see all the auto action demos listed under Active Auto Actions. Each Auto Action is entitled AA-tag, e.g., AA-Spark-1c, Map-1b.

title: Executing the demos
body: Go to demo-path/demos directory. For each auto actions rules listed in Manage | Auto Actions there is a corresponding script in the demo's directory. Each script will trigger the corresponding auto action demo.

title: Executing the demos
body: For example, in the UI the auto action named AA-Spark-1c is listed. The corresponding triggering script file is demo-Spark-1c. You should see the following files in the demos directory.

title: Executing the demos
body:
# cd demo-path/setup 
# ls
demo-Hive-1a demo-MR-1a demo-MR-2b demo-Spark-1b
demo-Hive-2a demo-MR-1b demo-MR-3a demo-Spark-1c
demo-Hive-2b demo-MR-1c demo-MR-3b run-all-demos
demo-Hive-3a demo-MR-2a demo-Spark-1a scripts/

title: Executing the demos
body: Execute ./demo-tag script to trigger the corresponding AA-tag rule. Each script is designed to simulate violation conditions for the corresponding auto action on the target Hadoop cluster, e.g., to trigger AA-Spark-1c you run the demo-Spark-1c script.

title: Executing the demos
body: Some auto action's demo scripts trigger multiple auto actions. This side effect can happen when running your own defined auto actions due to auto actions having overlapping definitions.

title: Cleaning up demos
body: This will remove all the demo Auto-Actions from the Unravel Server. If you want to run the demos again, simply follow the procedure starting with extracting the files (step 3 above).

title: Supported cluster metrics
body: Auto Actions by default collect metrics from the YARN Resource Manager and MapReduce Application Master for all applications running (or submitted) on the target cluster. MapReduce Application Master (AM) also maintains various counters. Users can use these metrics and counters when defining an Auto Actions rule. Additionally, there are Hive/Workflow and Spark metrics which can used to define Auto Actions rules.

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: Rogue applications can affect cluster health and lead to missed SLAs. Therefore, it is best practice to identify and eliminate them. Symptoms of a cluster with rogue applications include jobs that take too long to run or applications that use too many vcores. Unravel Web UI makes identifying rogue apps easy:

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: In the Cluster VCores or Cluster MemoryMB graph, click on a spike.

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: Unravel Web UI displays the list of applications running or pending in the cluster at the spike's timestamp at the bottom of the page.

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: Click on the application which has allocated the highest number of vcores. In this example, there is a MapReduce application which has allocated 240 vcores of the cluster.

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: Check the event panel in the application's APM to see Unravel's recommendations for improving the efficiency of this MapReduce application. For example:

title: Identifying Rogue Applications
body: Set up an Auto Action to proactively alert if a rogue application is occupying the cluster.

title: Detecting Resource Contention in the Cluster
body: If your cluster has a lot of apps they will contend for resources in the cluster. Unravel Web UI assists you in detecting and resolving resource contention.

title: Detecting Resource Contention in the Cluster
Detecting Resource Contention in the Cluster
body: In the Cluster VCores or Cluster MemoryMB graph, click on a spike.

title: Detecting Resource Contention in the Cluster
body: Unravel Web UI displays the list of applications running or pending in the cluster at the spike's timestamp, at the bottom of the page. When you see many applications in the ACCEPTED state (not RUNNING), it means they are waiting for resources. For example, the screenshot below shows that only one Spark application is RUNNING (consuming resources) and four MR applications are ACCEPTED (waiting for resources). Now you can take steps to resolve the problem.

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: It can be difficult to understand what is happening in your Kafka cluster and to successfully root cause/troubleshoot problems. In order to help you do this, Unravel provides insights and visibility throughout all levels of your cluster. This includes the ability to drill down into applications acting as consumers processing data streams. Unravel's Kafka monitoring and insights are built-in; no configuration is required once you have connected Unravel to your Kafka cluster.,

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: Below are some of the best practices for using Unravel to monitor your Kafka environments. It is assumed you have basic knowledge of Kafka concepts and architecture.

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: Your starting point in Unravel is Operations > Usage Details > Kafka. It displays the overall health of the cluster and provides immediate access to your cluster's brokers and topics.

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: Unravel provides six (6) cluster wide KPIs to give you an immediate view of the Kafka cluster's overall health and IO. The first three KPIs provide information on your clusters' partitions and controllers. They are color coded so you can quickly ascertain their health.

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: The next three KPIs are data IO metrics and are always blue. Below the KPIs are three tabs, METRICS, BROKER, and TOPIC. The METRICS and BROKER tabs have the same graphs but contain different data, cluster wide and broker specific data respectively.

title: Best Practice in Kafka Monitoring
body: These KPIs and the data graphs help you root cause existing problems or identify potential issues. Immediate access to your cluster's brokers and topics allow you to quickly drill down and locate the problematic areas. Below we examine a few scenarios.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: A healthy cluster has no under replicated partitions. If this KPI is greater than zero (0), your replication is not occurring as fast as configured. This under replication:

title: Under replicated partitions
body: Adds latency as consumers don't receive their needed data until messages are replicated.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: Suggests you are more vulnerable to data loss if you have a master failure.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: If you have under replicated partitions, it typically points to a problem with one or more brokers. You should root cause the problem immediately to avoid any data loss.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: First, you need to understand how often the under replication is occurring. Scroll down in the METRICS tab to locate the Under Replicated Partitions graph to see the under replication over time across the cluster.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: When you see current or consistent under replication drill down into the brokers. Click on the BROKER tab for the list of brokers and their KPIs. Brokers having problems will have 1 or greater listed in Under Replicated Partitions column. Click each broker with under replicated partitions and scroll down to its Under Replicated Partitions graph.

title: Under replicated partitions
body: Once you have identified the problem brokers, examine each of their logs to determine the root cause.

title: Log Flush Latency
body: Log flush latency is important; it is also related to under replicated partitions.

title: Log Flush Latency
body: The longer it takes to flush the log to disk, the more the pipeline backs up and the worse the latency and throughput. When latency goes up, even as small an increment as 10ms, end-to-end latency balloons which can lead to under replicated partitions

title: Log Flush Latency
body: The Log Flush Latency, 99th Percentile graph allows you to keep track of the cluster's latency. At any given point in time 99% of the log latency is less than this value. Scroll down in the METRICS tab to see the cluster's log latency graph. If the latency is fluctuating dramatically, or is consistently high, you need to identify the broker(s) that are contributing to it.

title: Log Flush Latency
body: Click on the BROKER tab so you can examine individual brokers. Unlike under replicated partitions, the broker table does not include a log flush latency KPI. You must examine each broker individually. Click on each broker and then scroll down to its Log Flush Latency, 99th Percentile graph.

title: Log Flush Latency
body: Problematic brokers have latency graphs with dramatic fluctuations or consistently high latency. After identifying these brokers, examine their logs to gain insight into the problem. If your cluster can keep up with the amount of data coming in, consider adding more brokers. Another possibility is that the node is "bad", e.g., the hard drive is going bad; if that is the case you should swap the node out for a healthy one. Regularly monitoring this graph can help you see trends which could lead to problems.

title: Offline Partitions
body: This KPI is the total number of offline topic partitions. A healthy cluster doesn't have any offline partitions. Offline partitions can occur if:

title: Offline Partitions
body: The brokers with replicas are down.

title: Offline Partitions
body: Unclean leader election is disabled and the replicas are not in sync. In this case, none can be elected leader. (This may be desirable to ensure no messages are lost.)

title: Offline Partitions
body: When you have offline partitions you should immediately root cause the problem. Scroll down in the METRICS tab to locate the # Offline Partition Count graph and examine the offline partition number over time.

title: Offline Partitions
body: If you have currently have offline partitions, drill down into the brokers. Click on the BROKER, and check OFFLINE PARTITIONS COUNT for each broker. Click on each broker with offline partitions and examine its # Offline Partition Count graph. It graphs the number of offline partitions over time and you can see whether the partition(s) are currently offline, were briefly offline, or were offline for an extended period of time. After identifying the problem brokers, examine each broker's log to determine the cause of the problem.

title: Controller Health
body: The # Controller KPI can indicate potential problems with your cluster.

title: Controller Health
body: 0: There is no active controller. You want to avoid this since data can potentially be lost.

title: Controller Health
body: 1: There is one active controller. This is the preferred state. During a steady state there should be only one active controller per cluster.

title: Controller Health
body: Greater than 1: This is inconclusive and it's important to find out what is occurring. If this only persists for about a minute, it likely means the active controller switched from one broker to another. If this persists for longer, troubleshoot the cluster for "split brain".

title: Controller Health
body: The # Active Controller Trend graphs all brokers and their status as the active controller. You can swiftly see where your cluster has problems. When the number of active controllers is greater than one for longer a minute or so, you should investigate the brokers' logs. Hover over the graph to see what brokers were active controllers simultaneously. You can view this graph for each broker individually in the BROKER tab. When needed, examine the relevant brokers' logs for further insight. In the example below, there are three points where the controller number is greater than one. The first two incidents were for a brief period, while the third was the active controller being switched from one broker to another. You don't need to investigate the latter, but you might want to investigate the former.

title: Cluster Activity
body: The last three KPIs show cluster activity within the last 24 hours. They are always colored blue because they are counts and therefore neither healthy nor unhealthy. These KPIs are useful in gauging your cluster's activity for the last 24 hours. As with the other KPIs, you can view their information graphically.

title: Cluster Activity
body: These metrics can be useful in understanding cluster capacity, and to:

title: Cluster Activity
body: Determine if you need additional brokers to keep up with data velocity.

title: Cluster Activity
body: Evaluate the performance of topic architecture on your brokers.

title: Cluster Activity
body: Evaluate the performance of partition architecture for a topic.

title: Cluster Activity
body: These metrics are graphed over time and you can view them across the cluster, by broker, or by topic. Below, are the METRICS graphs for the KPIs. Click on the BROKER or TOPIC tabs to see the metrics across a specific broker or topic.

title: Topic Partition Strategy
body: This section provides best practices for using Unravel to evaluate your topic/broker performance.

title: Topic Partition Strategy
body: A common challenge is providing an architecture for the topics and partitions in your cluster which can, and will, support the data velocity coming from producers. Typically, adjustments have tended to be a "shot in the dark" because of a lack of relevant data. Unravel provides detailed information to shed light on how your architecture is performing, which, in turn, can help you to re-configure your architecture for better performance.

title: Producer architecture
body: It can be a challenge in deciding how to partition topics on the Kafka level. Producers can choose to send messages via key or use a round-robin strategy when no key has been defined for a message. Choosing the correct number of partitions for your data velocity is important to ensure you have a real-time architecture that is performant.

title: Producer architecture
body: You can use Unravel to get a better understanding on how your current architecture is performing. Then, use the insights to guide you in choosing the number of partitions.

title: Producer architecture
body: Click on the TOPIC tab and scroll down for the list of topics in your cluster. You can quickly identify topics with heavy traffic and where you should examine your partitions' performance.

title: Producer architecture
body: For topics that are experiencing heavy traffic or are in trouble, click on its consumer. You can then see the consumer's topic list and the health of each topic. Use this information to help you determine the correct number of partitions.

title: Consumer Group Architecture
body: You can make changes on the consumer group side to scale according to your topic/partition architecture. Unravel provides a convenient view for each topic's consumer groups so you can quickly see the health status of each consumer group in your cluster. When the consumer group is a Spark Streaming application Unravel can provide insights for it, thereby providing an end-to-end monitoring solution for your streaming applications.

title: Consumer Group Architecture
body: See for a use case on monitoring consumer groups, and lagging/stalled partitions or consumer groups.

body: For a complete description of all the Kafka metrics/graphs and how to interpret them see .

title: References

title: Overview
body: The Unravel Intelligence engine provides insights into a cluster's activities through the status of the Consumer Group's (CG). A CG's state is determined on a partition by partition basis, specifically by its commit offset relative to the producer's log commit offset for a particular partition. The states are:

title: Overview
body: OK: commit offset is in pace with the log end offset.

title: Overview
body: Lagging: the Consumer is lagging behind the Producer. Both the consumer's and log commit offsets are increasing, but the Producer’s is increasing faster. When graphed over time, the Producer's slope is increasing faster than the consumer's slope.

title: Overview
body: Stalled: the Consumer has essentially stopped while the Producer is still active. The consumer's offset is not increasing while the log commit offset is increasing. Graphically, the slope of the consumer is essentially zero.

title: Overview
body: A Topic's status is set to the lowest status among its Consumer Groups and the Consumer Group's status is set to the lowest status among its partitions. You must drill down from the Cluster in order to determine where Topic/Consumer Group is lagging or stalled.

title: Use Case Example
body: Go to Operation | Charts | Kafka to view your currently configured clusters. Click on a cluster name to bring up the Cluster View.

title: Use Case Example
body: Use the graph scroll-bar to view graphs of the cluster metrics. The Topic table lists all topics with their consumers and the topic's status. Click within a graph to see what topics were available at that point in time. Click the topic name to examine it. In this case, topic test2 is stalled and has two consumers, demo and test-consumer-group.

title: Use Case Example
body: Consumers with the same name are grouped together into one consumer group.

title: Use Case Example
body: Choosing all clusters from the pull down menu creates tabs for all your clusters so you can easily switch between them.

title: Use Case Example
body: The Topic view opens with Topic Detail tab displaying the brokers KPIs. The Consumer Details table lists active Consumers with its status for that point in time. The Consumer Group(s) KPI's are across all partitions. Click within the graph to see what Consumers were running at that point in time. Below test2 only has one stalled consumer demo; in turn, demo has one stalled and three lagging partitions.

title: Use Case Example
body: Click on the Partition Detail tab to view the Consumer(s) information per partition. The Consumer Details table now lists the KPIs and status for all consumer groups on the partition displayed. Click within the graph to see what Consumer(s) were running at that point in time on that partition. Partition 0 is initially displayed using the metric offset. As expected from the preceding graph the test-consumer-group is OK on this partition, while demo is lagging.

title: Use Case Example
body: Use the Partition and Metric pulldown menu to change partition to display and metric (Offset or Consumer Lag) to use. Click on more info glyph () in the Go To column to bring up the Consumer Group View. The example below shows Partition 1 graphed on the metric Consumer Lag. It's obvious this is a stalled partition both from the steep slope and the status icon. The test-consumer-group is basically a flat-line.

title: Use Case Example
body: The CG view lists the Topics which it is consuming and opens with graphs of its broker(s) KPI’s. Just as a Topic can have multiple consumers with varying states, a Consumer Group can be consuming multiple topics with varying degrees of success. In this case, there is only one Topic being consumed and the CG is stalled.

title: Use Case Example
body: Click on the Partition Detail tab to see partition(s). The Partition Details table lists the partitions with its KPIs and status. The window defaults to the graph of partition 0 using the offset metric. Below we see partition 1 is stalled, while 0, 2, 3 are lagging.

title: Use Case Example
body: Use the pull down menus to change Metric or Partition used for the graph. The eye () denotes the partition displayed. The graph below is displaying partition 1 graphed using consumer lag.

title: Event Panel & Insights
body: The Unravel intelligence engine helps you manage your applications more efficiently by providing insights into their run. The UI engine gives its insights and tuning suggesting via the Events Panel. Not all UI engine insights results in concrete recommendations, so to take full advantage you must read the efficiency panel. There is not a 1-1 correspondence between the event and recommendation number. A single event might lead to none or many recommendations.

title: Recommendations
body: Lists the parameters to change, shows their current and recommended value.

title: Efficiency
body: The efficiency list details the inefficiencies. The UI engine might:

title: Efficiency
body: Make a recommendation and note the expected result from such a change.

title: Efficiency
body: Suggest where to look to increase efficiency.

title: Efficiency
body: Below are two examples. Each type of job and instance of a job has events relevant to that particular job and instance.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The table below lists the resource metrics collected by Unravel. The availability of a particular metric is dependent on the underlying OS and JVM GC algorithm in use.

title: Resource Metrics
body: An estimate of memory available for launching new processes.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average interval between two subsequent full GCs. Might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average interval between two subsequent minor GCs. Might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Estimated percentage of CPU time spent in kernel blocking operations.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The committed virtual memory in the operating system.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Current thread CPU time elapsed since the start of the measurement. Might not be available on some operating systems.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Current thread user time elapsed since the start of the measurement. Might not be available on some operating systems.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Maximum memory usage in the eden space.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The free physical memory in the operating system.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Accumulated time spent in full GC.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average number of bytes moved from eden to survivor space. Might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Percentage of CPU time spent in GC.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average number of bytes alive in the old generation. Might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average number of bytes moved from survivor to old space. Might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average number of bytes alive in the young generation (eden + survivor spaces). It might not be available for particular GC algorithms.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The number of minor GC runs.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The accumulated time spent in minor GC.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The maximum memory usage in the old space.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average process CPU load for the last minute (all cores).

title: Resource Metrics
body: The time the metric was read.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The time when the collection process started.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Maximum memory usage in the survivor space.

title: Resource Metrics
body: Average system CPU load for the last minute (all cores).

title: Resource Metrics
body: The total physical memory in the operating system.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The resident set size of the complete process tree.

title: Resource Metrics
body: The resident set size of the process.

title: Uploading Spark Programs to Unravel
body: Unravel UI displays Spark programs you upload if they're submitted as Java, Scala or Python source code, not as JVM byte code.

title: Uploading Spark Programs to Unravel
body: You can upload Spark programs in either either by uploading individual source files or by uploading a .zip file.

title: Uploading Individual Source Files
body: Upload Spark source files and specify their location on the spark-submit command.

title: Uploading Individual Source Files
body: In yarn-client mode, upload the source files to any local directory accessible to the application's driver, and specify their path with --conf "spark.unravel.program.dir=$PROGRAM_DIR" on the spark-submit command:

title: Uploading Individual Source Files
body: The default value of spark.unravel.program.dir is the current directory (the application's home directory).

title: Uploading Individual Source Files
body: In yarn-cluster mode, upload the source files to the application's home directory, and specify their path with --files comma-separated-list-of-source-files on the spark-submit command:

title: Uploading a Zip Archive
body: Package all relevant source files into a zip archive. Keep the archive small by including only the relevant driver source files.

title: Uploading a Zip Archive
body: In yarn-client mode, upload the zip archive to any local directory accessible to the application's driver, and specify its path with --conf "spark.unravel.program.zip=$SRC_ZIP_PATH" on the spark-submit command:

title: Uploading a Zip Archive
body:
export PROGRAM_DIR=fully-qualified-zip-path
export SRC_ZIP_PATH=$PROGRAM_DIR/src-zip-name
export PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR=fully-qualified-jar-path

spark-submit \
 --class org.apache.spark.examples.sql.RDDRelation \
 --conf "spark.unravel.program.zip=$SRC_ZIP_PATH" \
 $PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR

title: Uploading a Zip Archive
body: In yarn-cluster mode, upload the zip archive to the application's home directory, and specify its path with --files $SRC_ZIP_PATH and its filename with --conf "spark.unravel.program.zip=src-zip-name" on the spark-submit command:

title: Uploading a Zip Archive
body:
export PROGRAM_DIR=fully-qualified-zip-path
export SRC_ZIP_PATH=$PROGRAM_DIR/src-zip-name
export PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR=fully-qualified-jar-path 

spark-submit \
 --class org.apache.spark.examples.sql.RDDRelation \
 --files $SRC_ZIP_PATH \
 --conf "spark.unravel.program.zip=src-zip-name" \
 $PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR

title: Introduction
body: This topic explains how to set up to profile specific Spark applications (in other words, per-application profiling, also called "dev mode"), rather than cluster-wide profiling. Spark applications must be submitted through spark-submit.

title: Introduction
body: The information here applies to Spark versions 1.3.x through 2.0.x.

title: Introduction
body: unravel-host must be a fully qualified DNS or IP address.

title: Introduction
body: The sensor is included in the Unravel Server RPM installation. After installing the Unravel Server RPM on unravel-host, obtain the sensor either from the filesystem on the Unravel Server host, or from http://unravel-host:3000/hh/unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip.

title: Introduction
body: To obtain Unravel Sensor from the filesystem on the Unravel Server host:

title: Introduction
body: Go to the /usr/local/unravel/webapps/ROOT/hh/ directory on the Unravel Server host.

title: Introduction
body: Run the sensor to intercept spark apps.

title: Introduction
body: Option A: If you run spark apps in YARN-cluster mode (default)

title: Introduction
body: Put the sensor on the host node(s) from which you will run spark-submit by first creating a destination directory that is readable by all users.

title: Introduction
body: If spark-submit is used from a single client node:

title: Introduction
body: If spark-submit is used from multiple client nodes, copy the sensor .zip file to HDFS instead of copying it to every client node, and set UNRAVEL_SENSOR_PATH accordingly. For example, copy it to hdfs:///tmp:

title: Introduction
body:
mkdir unravel-sensor-path
cd unravel-sensor-path
wget http://unravel-host:3000/hh/unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip
cd unravel-sensor-path
hdfs fs -copyFromLocal unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip /tmp
set UNRAVEL_SENSOR_PATH="hdfs:///tmp"

title: Introduction
body: Define spark.driver.extraJavaOptions and spark.executor.extraJavaOptions as part of your spark-submit command.

title: Introduction
body: unravel-sensor-path: Parent directory of the Unravel Sensor .zip file, unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip. If you put this file on HDFS, unravel-sensor-path is the parent directory on HDFS.

title: Introduction
body: unravel-host-ip-port: IP address and port of the unravel_lr service in the format ip:port. The default port is 4043. Sample value: 10.0.0.142:4043.

title: Introduction
body: spark-event-log-dir: Location of the event log directory on HDFS, S3, or local file system. If a remote address is used, include the name node IP address and port.

title: Introduction
body: spark-sample-jar-path: Absolute path to the jar file used in the spark-submit command.

title: Introduction
body: spark-version: Spark version to be instrumented. Valid options are 1.3 for Spark 1.3.x, 1.5 for Spark 1.5.x, 1.6 for Spark 1.6.x, and 2.0 for Spark 2.0.x.

title: Introduction
body:
export UNRAVEL_SENSOR_PATH=unravel-sensor-path
export UNRAVEL_SERVER_IP_PORT=unravel-host-ip-port
export SPARK_EVENT_LOG_DIR=spark-event-log-dir
export PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR=spark-sample-jar-path
export SPARK_VERSION=spark-version

export ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_DRIVER="spark.driver.extraJavaOptions=-javaagent:unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip/btrace-agent.jar=libs=spark-$SPARK_VERSION,config=driver"

export ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_EXECUTOR="spark.executor.extraJavaOptions=-javaagent:unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip/btrace-agent.jar=libs=spark-$SPARK_VERSION,config=executor"


spark-submit \
 --class org.apache.spark.examples.sql.RDDRelation \
 --master yarn-cluster \
 --archives $UNRAVEL_SENSOR_PATH/unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip \
 --conf "$ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_DRIVER" \
 --conf "$ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_EXECUTOR" \
 --conf "spark.unravel.server.hostport=$UNRAVEL_SERVER_IP_PORT" \
 --conf "spark.eventLog.dir=${SPARK_EVENT_LOG_DIR}" \
 --conf "spark.eventLog.enabled=true" \
 $PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body: unzipped-archive-dest: directory of the unzipped Unravel Sensor files.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body: unravel-host-ip-port: IP address and port of the unravel_lr service in the format ip:port. Port is 4043 by default. Sample value: 10.0.0.142:4043.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body: spark-event-log-dir: Location of the event log directory on HDFS, S3, or local file system. If a remote address is used, include the namenode IP address and port.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body: spark-sample-jar-path: Absolute path to the jar file used in the spark-submit command.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body: spark-version: Spark version to be instrumented. Valid options are 1.3 for Spark 1.3.x, 1.5 for Spark 1.5.x, 1.6 for Spark 1.6.x, and 2.0 for Spark 2.0.x.

title: Option B: If You Run Spark Apps in yarn-client Mode.
body:
export UNZIPPED_ARCHIVE_DEST=unzipped-archive-dest
export UNRAVEL_SERVER_IP_PORT=unravel-host-ip-port
export SPARK_EVENT_LOG_DIR=spark-event-log-dir
export PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR=spark-sample-jar-path
export SPARK_VERSION=spark-version

export ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_EXECUTOR="spark.executor.extraJavaOptions=-javaagent:unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip/btrace-agent.jar=libs=spark-$SPARK_VERSION,config=executor"

spark-submit \
 --class org.apache.spark.examples.sql.RDDRelation \
 --master yarn-client \
 --archives $UNZIPPED_ARCHIVE_DEST/unravel-agent-pack-bin.zip \
 --driver-java-options "-javaagent:/opt/cloudera/parcels/UNRAVEL_SENSOR/lib/java/btrace-agent.jar=config=driver,libs=spark-$SPARK_VERSION" \
 --conf "$ENABLED_SENSOR_FOR_EXECUTOR" \
 --conf "spark.unravel.server.hostport=$UNRAVEL_SERVER_IP_PORT" \
 --conf "spark.eventLog.dir=${SPARK_EVENT_LOG_DIR}" \
 --conf "spark.eventLog.enabled=true" \
 $PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR

These instructions don't require CM credentials. However, if the impalad web interface is secure as indicated in Cloudera's Securing the Impala Web User Interfacel and Impala Web User Interface for Debugging, then you need to use CM as the data source.

title: Informatica Big Data Management (Preview Only)
body: Informatica Big Data Management (BDM) is primarily a data ingest tool. It provides a graphical user interface for generating ETL mappings (jobs) and workflows for various executors, such as Spark, Hive on MapReduce, or Hive on Tez. You install BDM on an edge node in your Hadoop cluster, and use it to create jobs and workflows that ingest data into your cluster. The BDM interface allows you to construct jobs graphically, by connecting data sources to mappings to data destinations; BDM creates the Hive queries for you, which removes the need for you to know Hive or Spark programming. While a non-programmatic interface is convenient, the jobs it generates might need tweaking to improve their performance or to meet your SLAs. This is where Unravel comes in. The Unravel UI shows more information for each BDM job or workflow than YARN or your cluster manager does.

title: Informatica Big Data Management (Preview Only)
body: This topic explains how to connect Unravel to your BDM jobs and workflows, so that Unravel can provide operational insights, recommendations, and automation to maximize their performance.

title: Deploying Unravel on Security-Enhanced Linux
body: This topic explains how to deploy Unravel over Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux). SELinux allows you to set access control through SELinux policies.

title: SELinux Modes
body: Enforcing: The SELinux polices and rules are strictly enforced and applied over the subjects and object. All production systems have SELinux enabled in enforcing mode. The policies are enforced whenever any violations or errors are detected and the violations/errors are logged.

title: SELinux Modes
body: Permissive: The policies and rules of SELinux are applied over the subjects and objects but are not enforced. All violations and errors based on the SELinux policy are ignored and logged into the log files. If the SELinux policy prevents a specific service from accessing a specific folder, this mode allows access but logs a denial message. This mode provides enough debugging information to fine tune the SELinux Policy so it runs smoothly in enforcing mode.

title: SELinux Policies
body: Unravel currently only supports the targeted policy.

body: Enable SELinux on Unravel Node running Linux.

title: Installing Unravel Core RPMs on a Node with SELinux
body:
-----RPM installation log
+ setenforce Permissive
+ echo
+ tee_echo '[CREATE_B1: SECURITY: WARNING] Setting selinux to be temporarily Permissive; after a reboot it might revert to Enforced and Unravel functionality might be an issue.'
+ tee -a /tmp/rpm_upgrade.log
++ date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'
 + echo '[2019-01-28 06:33:17] [CREATE_B1: SECURITY: WARNING] Setting selinux to be temporarily Permissive; after a reboot it might revert to Enforced and Unravel functionality might be an issue.' 
+ echo
+ FILE_CACHE_HEADROOM_MB=2000
-----

title: Why Run Verification Tests or Benchmarks?
body: Verification tests highlight the value of Unravelâ€™s application performance management/analysis.

title: Why Run Verification Tests or Benchmarks?
body: Benchmarks verify that Unravel features are working correctly.

title: Running Verification Tests
body: Unravel provides verification tests for Spark jobs only. Please follow the instructions in the section that matches your deployment.

title: CDH
body: On your Unravel Server host, run the spark_test_via_parcel.sh script. This script runs a Spark app. Itâ€™s a good way to verify that Unravel Server captures the data (events) generated by the Spark app, after the sensor jars have been deployed to the cluster via the parcel, i.e., Installing the Unravel Parcel on CDH+CM. You should be able to see the data generated by this Spark app on Unravel Web UI. Substitute the host name or LAN IP address of Unravel Server for unravel-host

title: Backing-up, Disaster Recovery, and Rollbacks
body: It's best practice to create a snapshot (backup) of your Unravel Server and to test your snapshot on a failover server daily or at a minimum, weekly; in addition, it is absolutely essential to create a snapshot before any upgrade in case you need to revert to the previous Unravel version.

title: Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State
body: Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State

title: Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State
body: Creating a snapshot of your Unravel Server involves dumping its state and databases to a specified location. You create a snapshot by running the dump_unravel.sh script and specifying a destination directory dest on the command line:

title: Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State
Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State
body: The result is a subdirectory under destination-dir named unravel_yyyymmddthhmmZ that contains the saved data. The complete state is saved, and is suitable for a complete re-installation, if needed. For multi-GB data sizes, the dump could take 5 minutes per GB, depending on the speed of your disks. During this time, Unravel Server is unavailable.

title: Create a Snapshot of Unravel Serverâ€™s State
body: If you use an external database in production, that database is not dumped; you must replicate or back up the externally managed database separately.

title: Load a Saved State
body: You can load a saved state into Unravel Server by specifying a source directory, {SRC}, on the invocation of the load_unravel.sh script. This script replaces the current Unravel Server state with the state in the source directory.

title: Load a Saved State
body: This operation wipes out existing data in the installed Unravel Server on the current host. Data in an external database is unaffected.

title: Load a Saved State
body: The version of Unravel Server in the source directory should not be too different from the version of Unravel Sever currently running: major and minor versions must match. Consult Unravel Support for larger deltas.

title: Load a Saved State
body: The result is that the saved state in SRC replaces current state of the Unravel Server on the current host.

title: Recover from Disaster
body: For disaster recovery, you can prepare a cold failover or alternate server, and periodically update it with a snapshot. In this case, you would create a snapshot periodically on your normally live Unravel Server, and load that snapshot onto your alternate server. For a cold failover (to the alternate server), there is no need to start all the Unravel daemons until switching overâ€“in other words, after the disaster in the normal data center.

title: Revert to Prior Version
body: Best practice is to execute rolling upgrades of Unravel Server: first upgrade the normal server, then upgrade the alternate server. In this fashion you always have an easy way to completely revert an upgrade to the prior version. To revert, do the following steps.

title: Revert to Prior Version
body: If you use an external database in production, you cannot revert it with this procedure; you might need to revert it separately.

Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: This topic explains how to configure multiple hosts for Unravel Server. This is useful for performance or reliability requirements.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: When you complete the steps below, the expected result is

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: Multiple Unravel hosts work together in an ensemble.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: Each host has a unique role, and is identified by a daemon named unravel_xyz or unravel_xyz_n (where n is 1, 2, 3,...), which runs on exactly one host.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: Unravel Web UI (unravel_tc) runs on host1.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: If you do not use an external database (db), unravel_db runs on host1. However, unravel_db can also run harmlessly if an external db is used.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties is identical on all Unravel hosts in the ensemble.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: The file unravel.properties is never changed by an RPM upgrade because it contains site-specific information, but some one-time changes occur when setting up multiple hosts. It must be identical on all hosts, so if you are using data center automation like Puppet, Chef, Salt, Ansible, CloudFormation, Cfengine, and so on, you must maintain one "golden" unravel.properties per Unravel ensemble. After you modify it as described below, you must update the "golden" unravel.properties file for your site.

title: Configuring Multiple Hosts for Unravel Server
body: Daemons are enabled/disabled via chkconfig. chkconfig sets symbolic links which are persistent across Unravel Server RPM upgrades.

title: Prerequisites
body: If you use Kerberos, set that up first on host1.

title: Prerequisites
body: Install the same Unravel RPM on one or two additional hosts, hereafter referred to as host2 and host3. This distinction is important because certain instructions only apply to specific hosts.

title: Prerequisites
body: Each host is assigned unique roles identified by daemon names that start with unravel_.

title: Expected Result

title: Expected Result
body:
# scp /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties host2:/usr/local/unravel/etc/
# scp /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh host2:/usr/local/unravel/etc/
# scp /etc/unravel_ctl host2:/etc/

title: Expected Result
body: Verify that the ownership of unravel.properties and unravel.ext.sh is unravel:unravel. If /etc/unravel_ctl is used, it should be owned by root:root.

title: Expected Result
body: The scripts invoked below will make an identical change to the unravel.properties file on each machine.

title: Expected Result
body: Use these scripts to assign unique roles to the hosts. To reduce the chance of errors, the command line arguments are the same on each host, but notice that the script name is different. The arguments are the hostnames IP addresses of the hosts in the ensemble.

title: Expected Result
body: These scripts establish the roles each host plays in the ensemble. The main effect is to assign specific Unravel logical daemons to one host and only one host.

title: Expected Result
body: Note that some daemons have names like unravel_xyz_1 or unravel_xyz_2, and so on. The entire name with the instance numeric suffix is set to run on one host in the ensemble. In some cases, multiple xyz numeric instances run on one machine, but the overall name with suffix runs on one host only.

title: Expected Result
body: The switch_to_* scripts change unravel.properties in a coordinated fashion and also create a file, unravel.id.properties, to hold the integer property indicating which role the particular machine has (1, 2, or 3).

title: Expected Result
body: Kafka partition assignment (for 3 host installs) is done by evenly distributing a topic over the hosts that exist at topic create time. Topics must be created anew when a new host is added in order to have proper distribution.

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: You can configure an Apache2 web server (httpd) as a reverse proxy to provide HTTPS (SSL/TLS) security to Unravel Web UI. Follow the steps below to make this work.

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: Secure cookies are NOT supported when using this Apache2 reverse-proxy method. Follow the instructions in Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly to enable TLS directly in unravel_ngui, which listens on port 3000.

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: These steps were tested with httpd 2.4 and support listening on port 443.

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: There is no need to change the default /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf file.

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: Create /etc/httpd/conf.d/unravel_https.conf. Use the following as a model (replace unravelhost_FQDN and settings for <varname>SSLCertificate*</varname> with values appropriate for your installation).

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body:
<VirtualHost *:80> 
 ServerName unravelhost_FQDN 
 Redirect permanent / https://unravelhost_FQDN
 
</VirtualHost> <VirtualHost *:443>

 DocumentRoot /var/www/html
 ServerName unravelhost_FQDN
 # use this if http to https errors #RequestHeader set X-FORWARDED-PROTO 'https'

 SSLEngine on 
 <varname>SSLCertificateFile</varname> /etc/certs/wildcard_unravelhost_ssl_certificate.crt 
 <varname>SSLCertificateKeyFile</varname> /etc/certs/wildcard_unravelhost_RSA_private.key 
 <varname>SSLCertificateChainFile</varname> /etc/certs/IntermediateCA.crt

 # set this off for reverse proxy security 
 ProxyRequests Off 
 # might be helpful in logs 
 ProxyPreserveHost On 
 ProxyPass / http://localhost:3000/ connectiontimeout=180 timeout=180 
 ProxyPassReverse / http://localhost:3000/
 <Location /> 
 Order deny,allow 
 Deny from all 
 Allow from al
 
 </VirtualHost>

title: Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI
body: Adjust or add property in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties. (No trailing slash. :port is optional).

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body: Below we show how to directly enable TLS (SSL) to unravel_ngui which is listening on port 3000. Alternatively, see Adding SSL and TLS to Unravel Web UI to add an apache2 reverse proxy which supports listening on port 443, the usual HTTPS port.

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body: In this example, we stay on default port 3000 but change the protocol to HTTPS. We need SSL/TLS certificate files accessible from unravel host. For more information, see Defining a Custom Web UI Port.

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body: On Unravel Server, edit /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties as follows:

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body: Update or add the following properties. For example, to enable ssl with minimal configuration:

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body:
#ENABLE/DISABLE SSL 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.enabled=true 

#PATH TO CERT FILE 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.cert.file=/etc/certs/wildcard_unravelhost_ssl_certificate 

#PATH TO KEY FILE 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.key.file=/etc/certs /wildcard_unravelhost_RSA_private.key 

#OPTIONAL - COMMA SEPARATED LIST OF CA FILES 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.ca.files=/etc/certs/IntermediateCA1.crt,/etc/certs/IntermediateCA2.crt 

#OPTIONAL- PASSPHRASE IF NEEDED FOR KEY FILE 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.passphrase=testp

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body: Update or add the following properties. For example, to enable SSL with advance configuration, update/add these properties:

title: Enabling TLS to Unravel Web UI Directly
body:
#ENABLE/DISABLE SSL 
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.enabled=true 

#PROVIDE SSL CONFIG THROUGH JS FILE FOR ADVANCE CONFIG
com.unraveldata.ngui.ssl.advance.config=/usr/local/unrave/etc/advanced_unravel_ssl.js

body: This configuration uses sAMAccount name to match users. bindDN and password must to be configured in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties. title: What is the difference between the two group properties in LDAP configurations?

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: This topic explains how to set up and run Unravel's Cluster Wide Report.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Cluster Wide Report is a java App designed to help you fine tune your cluster wide parameters to maximize its efficiency based upon your cluster's typical workload.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Collects performance data of prior completed jobs.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Analyzes the jobs relative to the cluster's current configuration.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Predicts and quantifies the impact the changes will have on future runs of the jobs.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Most of the recommendations revolve around the parameters

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: You can chose to implement some or all of the recommended settings.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Download the report tar ball from the Unravel preview site.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Unpack and run the setup script to install app in /usr/local/unravel/install_bin.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
tar zxvf ClusterReportSetup.tar.gz
cd ClusterReportSetup
sudo ./setup.sh /usr/local/unravel/install_bin

title: Step-by-step guide
body: The app is now installed in /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/ClusterReport. cd to the installation directory.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
ls
dbin/ etc/ origJars/ 
dlib/ logs/ origJars.tar.gz

title: Step-by-step guide
body: cd to dbin and edit Input.txt.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Configure Input.txt for your cluster and report parameters.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
cluster_id =
queue =
start_date=2018-01-01
end_date=2018-03-28
mapreduce.map.memory.mb=2048
mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb=2048
hive.exec.reducers.bytes.per.reducer=268435456
mapreduce.input.fileinputformat.split.maxsize=256000000

title: Adding Read-only Admins to Unravel
body: A read-only admin has access to all the UI's page including the Manage page but is not able to write, e.g., create Auto Actions.

title: Adding Read-only Admins to Unravel
body: Search for com.unraveldata.login.admins.readonly. If you can not find the property add it. Using a comma separated list, add/append the users you wish to grant read-only admin status.

title: Adding Read-only Admins to Unravel
body: If you are using LDAP or SAML, you must configure the read-only admins using com.unraveldata.login.admins.readonly.MODE.groups (where MODE is the value of com.unraveldata.login.mode). Using a comma separated list, add/append the users you wish to grant read-only admin status. For more information, see Configure LDAP or SAML RBAC Properties.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Connect to your database (either MySQL or Postgres) CLI using one of the following methods. We use MySQL in this example.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Query for the user whose password you want to change and keep track of its "id" field.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Use the bcrypt library to generate a new encrypted password.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Navigate to https://www.dailycred.com/article/bcrypt-calculator. Enter your desired password and select at least 10 rounds of hashing. Save the hash.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Update the record in the database with the new hash. Replace your local value for {HASH}: hash value you generated, {USER} user whose password you are changing, and {ID}: the ID from the query in Step 3.

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: mysql> UPDATE users SET encrypted_password = '{HASH}' WHERE id = {ID} AND login = '{LOGIN}' LIMIT 1;

title: Changing Unravel Admin's Password
body: Navigate to the Unravel UI. Logout and then login with your new password.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: This guide is to configure an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Disk FreeStorageSpace Metrics as part of RDS monitoring.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Select on the left-hand corner tab for Alarms.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: On the right-hand section under RDS Metrics, click Per-Database Metrics.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Under the column DBInstanceIdentifier, select the database you wish to monitor for free storage space and click Next when you are done.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: In Alarm Threshold panel, specify the following:

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Name - for this Database Metrics (e.g. RDS_FreeStorageSpace_for_MySQL-A)

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Description - describe what the above database metrics name you entered (e.g. Disk space monitor of RDS MySQL-A)

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Add free storage of 20% left to alert contact under Whenever FreeStorageSpace is <= 20

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: I have suggested adding 20% of free storage space left, however, you can tune this to be lower.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Under Actions, add Send notifications to, which is your SNS topic.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: This SNS topic should already be set up before you add it.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: Click Create Alarm to create the alarm metrics for RDS monitoring on storage space.

title: Creating an AWS RDS CloudWatch Alarm for Free Storage Space
body: The UI displays the alarm you just created in Alarms but includes the error INSUFFICIENT DATA if the alarm hasn't been triggered yet. When it is triggered, an ALARM appears under Alarms tab and the system sends mail alerts will be distributed as defined in the SNS topic.

title: Connecting to a Hive Metastore
body: Connecting to a Hive metastore enables Unravel Server to collect instrumentation from it, which results in the population of the Data page in Unravel UI.

title: Connecting to a Hive Metastore
body: Unravel Server accesses the Hive metastore to analyze table usage in conjunction with Hive job instrumentation. It collects information using a Hive API that works very much like beeline connections which leverage the JDBC database connection protocol. As a quick-start approach, you can get the already-defined Hive user that is also used by HiveServer2, and set Unravel Server to use that. Alternatively, you can define a read-only Hive metastore user.

body: You may optionally configure the following properties to manage the Hive Metastore JDBC connection pooling. Unravel uses the c3p0 library to manage the pooling.

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore
body: Controls how many times c3p0 tries to obtain an connection from the database before giving up.

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore
body: Allows you to mark data source as broken and permanently be closed if a connection cannot be obtained from database.

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore
body: The maximum number of seconds any connections were forced to be released from the pool.

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore
body: The number of seconds that connections are permitted to remain idle in the pool before being released.

title: Configuring a Hive Metastore
body: If the default value (0) is used the connections will never be released.
