Kafka Security
body: You can improve the Kafka cluster security by having kafka authenticate connections to brokers from client using either SSL or SASL.

title: SSL + Kerberos for Kafka clients
body: Prerequisite: kafka brokers are configured with SSL and kerberos. Please refer to your hadoop providers documentation for configuring SSL and Kerberos for kafka brokers.

title: SSL + Kerberos for Kafka clients
body: SSL+kerberos is supported by new Kafka consumers and producers. The configuration is same for consumer and producer. Replace items in red with values specific/relevant to your environment.

title: For Single Kafka clients
body: Create a file named consumerConfig.properties. Add the following properties and copy/move the file /usr/local/unravel/etc. You can locate youSLL + Kerbero configuration.

title: For Single Kafka clients
body:
ssl.protocol = TLSv1
sasl.mechanism = GSSAPI security.protocol = SASL_SSL
sasl.kerberos.service.name = kafka
ssl.truststore.location = /usr/java/jdk1.7.0_67-cloudera/jre/lib/security/jssecacerts1 
ssl.truststore.password = changeit ssl.truststore.type = JKS
ssl.keystore.location = /opt/cloudera/security/jks/server.keystore.jks 
ssl.keystore.password = password
ssl.keystore.type = JKS
ssl.enabled.protocols = TLSv1.2,TLSv1.1,TLSv1
sasl.jaas.config = \
com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule required \
useKeyTab=true \
keyTab="/etc/keytabs/kafka.keytab" \
principal="kafka/edge-1.uddev.unraveldata.com@UDDEV.UNRAVELDATA.COM"

title: For Single Kafka clients
body:
sasl.mechanism = GSSAPI
security.protocol = SASL_PLAINTEXT 
sasl.kerberos.service.name = kafka
sasl.jaas.config = com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule required \
useKeyTab=true \
keyTab="/etc/keytabs/kafka.keytab" \
principal="kafka/edge-1.uddev.unraveldata.com@UDDEV.UNRAVELDATA.COM";

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Unravel's metBackup, is a utility for creating backups and archives for the metric database. Alternatively, you can use PostgreSQL pg_dump utility.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: The metBackup is run on demand, either periodically as a cron job or as needed. It creates a single tar file containing the data backup. When a table or a partition is backed-up or archived, a log entry noting the time of the backup is added to the part_log file. The backup is not validated.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: ,metBackup takes advantage of the fact that frozen partitions are immutableand need to be backed-up only once. Optionally, active partitions, i.e., not-yet-frozen, and the non-partitioned tables (node_desc, metric_desc, and part_log) can be backed-up.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: The metBackup utility is invoked through the script met_backup.sh.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: By default, regardless of data creation date, only frozen partitions are backed-up, if and only if, they were not previously backed-up.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Name of backup tar file. Default metBackup_currentTimeAsEpoch.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Backup only data created on or after this date.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Backup active partitions and the non-partitioned tables, node_desc, metric_desc, and part_log.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Backup frozen data, regardless of whether it was previously backed-up.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: The retire thread is responsible for removing partitions past their expiration date. The normal procedure to retire the partition is to detach it from the parent table and delete it.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: When archiving is enabled (see the doArchive configuration property):

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Archived partitions are detached and deleted.

title: Backup and Archive Metric Database
body: Non-archived partitions are detached. The part_log is then periodically checked to see if the partition has been archived. Once archived, the partition is deleted.

title: Creating Active Directory Kerberos Principals and Keytabs for Unravel
body: On AD server, logged in as AD Administrator, generate keytab files that Unravel Server will use to authenticate with Kerberos using the ktpass utility in Active Directory:

sudo chown hdfs:hdfs /etc/keytabs/hdfs.keytab

title: Effect
body: The effect of the switch_to_user.sh is:

title: Effect
body: /etc/unravel_ctl defines environment variables RUN_AS and USE_GROUP.

title: Effect
body: HDFS_KEYTAB_PATH and HDFS_KERBEROS_PRINCIPAL environment variables are removed from /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh.

title: Effect
body: /usr/local/unravel/ and /srv/unravel/* are recursively changed to ownership RUN_AS:USE_GROUP.

title: Effect
body: Log files in /srv/unravel/log_hdfs are moved to /usr/local/unravel/logs.

title: Effect
body: The umask of the run-as daemon can now be more restrictive than 022; it can be 007 or 077.

title: Effect
body: The permission (chmod) bits of /usr/local/unravel and /srv/unravel can remove Group and Other visibility, if desired.

body: To adjust the retention time (time horizon), you need to set/change three properties in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties.

title: Setting Retention Time in Unravel Server

title: Setting Retention Time in Unravel Server
body: com.unraveldata.history.maxSize.weeks: number of weeks retained for search results in Elastic Search.

title: Setting Retention Time in Unravel Server
body: When changing these settings, be aware that long retention requires significant disk space. As a rule of thumb, each map-reduce or Spark job requires about 1 MB of disk space; you can store approximately 1000 jobs per 1 GB of disk.

Triggering an import of FSImage
body: The etl_fsimage task imports the latest FSImage from Namenode and incorporates it into a Hive table (unravel_hdfs_fsimage_master_orc) used for Unravel's Small Files/File Reports feature, and it also generates four precomputed file reports. We recommend scheduling etl_fsimage for a daily run (which is the default configuration). The default configuration leads to triggering of etl_fsimage at 00:00 UTC every day.

title: Triggering an import of FSImage
body: However, there may be times when you want to import FSImage immediately, such as after Unravel Server is installed or upgraded. In this case, you have to start etl_fsimage manually by running the following script on the Unravel node:

title: Triggering an import of FSImage

title: Using a Private Certificate Authority with Unravel
body: A private certificate authority (CA) is often used for signing certificates of non-public machines. Unravel server contains a bundled JRE that has well-known, public CAs. In order for Unravel to make REST requests to collect cluster metadata from HTTPS endpoints, it needs to know about your private CA. Use one of the techniques below and restart all Unravel daemons with sudo /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh restart after making the change.

title: Using a Private Certificate Authority with Unravel
body: /path/to/jks_keystore is the path for your local settings

title: Externally Managed JKS Keystore
body: The bundled JRE will use an external keystore (jssecacerts) in preference over the built-in one (cacerts). Simply create a symlink as shown to your JKS keystore:

title: Externally Managed JKS Keystore
body: Substitute /path/to/jks_keystore and ensure that the target file is updated whenever your CA certificates are updated.

title: Externally Managed JRE or JDK with curated cacerts
body: An external JRE or JDK is often maintained for local use so that the cacerts or file it contains is up-to-date. If this is convenient, you can edit /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.ext.sh and change the line for JAVA_HOME. Java 1.8 is required. The environment variable should point to the directory that contains bin/java. If you are using unlimited encryption strength for your Hadoop services, be sure that the JRE/JDK you specify also has unlimited encryption strength. Substitute your local settings /usr/java/jdkl1.8.

title: Encrypting Passwords in Unravel Properties and Settings
Encrypting Passwords in Unravel Properties and Settings
body: This result, including the ENC() part, can be put into /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.propertiesinstead of the verbatim (unecrypted) raw password.

title: Encrypting Passwords in Unravel Properties and Settings
Encrypting Passwords in Unravel Properties and Settings
body: The file /usr/local/unravel/etc/entropy contains random text that is used to do encryption. This file is created only once during installation (or upgrade, if missing) using strong random numbers only available locally. If the entropy value is changed, stored encrypted passwords will become invalid. Salt is included so that if two passwords are identical, the encrypted texts are not in order to avoid inadvertently revealing clues.

title: Encrypting Passwords in Unravel Properties and Settings
body: Passwords are redacted from diagnostic or logs reports, but even if the encrypted form were accidentally transmitted or visible in an online meeting because the entropy file is never included, the encrypted value would be impossible to decrypt.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: Below is a sample script, spark-test.py, for Spark.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body:
from airflow import DAG
from airflow.operators.bash_operator import BashOperator
from airflow.operators import PythonOperator
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
import subprocess


default_args = {
 'owner': 'airflow',
 'depends_on_past': False,
 'start_date': datetime(2015, 6, 1),
 'email': ['airflow@airflow.com'],
 'email_on_failure': False,
 'email_on_retry': False,
 'retries': 1,
 'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=5),
 # 'queue': 'bash_queue',
 # 'pool': 'backfill',
 # 'priority_weight': 10,
 # 'end_date': datetime(2016, 1, 1),
}

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: In Airflow, workflows are represented by directed acyclic graphs (DAGs). For example,

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: This script below, example-hdp-client.sh, adds hooks for Unravel instrumentation by setting three Unravel-specific configuration parameters for Spark applications.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: We recommend setting these parameters on a per-application basis only when you want to monitor/profile certain applications, rather than all the applications running in the cluster. Alternatively, you can specify these parameters in spark-defaults.conf.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: This script can be invoked to submit an Airflow Spark application via spark-submit. It references the following variables, which need to be changed to values valid for your local environment.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body:
hdfs dfs -rmr pair.parquet
spark-submit \
--class org.apache.spark.examples.sql.RDDRelation \
--master yarn-cluster \
--conf "spark.driver.extraJavaOptions=-javaagent:/usr/local/unravel_client/btrace-agent.jar=unsafe=true,stdout=false,noServer=true,startupRetransform=false,bootClassPath=/usr/local/unravel_client/unravel-boot.jar,systemClassPath=/usr/local/unravel_client/unravel-sys.jar,scriptOutputFile=/dev/null,script=DriverProbe.class:SQLProbe.class -Dcom.sun.btrace.FileClient.flush=-1 -Dcom.unraveldata.spark.sensor.disableLiveUpdates=true" \
--conf "spark.executor.extraJavaOptions=-javaagent:/usr/local/unravel_client/btrace-agent.jar=unsafe=true,stdout=false,noServer=true,startupRetransform=false,bootClassPath=/usr/local/unravel_client/unravel-boot.jar,systemClassPath=/usr/local/unravel_client/unravel-sys.jar,scriptOutputFile=/dev/null,script=ExecutorProbe.class -Dcom.sun.btrace.FileClient.flush=-1" \
--conf "spark.unravel.server.hostport=$UNRAVEL_SERVER_IP_PORT" \
--conf "spark.eventLog.dir=$SPARK_EVENT_LOG_DIR" \
--conf "spark.eventLog.enabled=true" \
$PATH_TO_SPARK_EXAMPLE_JAR

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: Operators (also called tasks) determine execution order (dependencies). In the example below, t1 and t2 are operators created by BashOperator or PythonOperator. They invoke example-hdp-client.sh, that submits the workflow for execution.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body: Note: The path name of example-hdp-client.sh is relative to the current directory, not to ~/airflow/dags as in the Airflow operator above.

title: Enabling AirFlow
body:
t1 = BashOperator(
task_id='example-hdp-client',
bash_command="example-scripts/example-hdp-client.sh",
retries=3,
dag=dag)


def spark_callback(**kwargs):
sp
 = subprocess.Popen(['/bin/bash', 
'airflow/dags/example-scripts/example-hdp-client.sh'], 
stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
print sp.stdout.read()


t2 = PythonOperator(
task_id='example-python-call',
provide_context=True,
python_callable=spark_callback,
retries=1,
dag=dag)


t2.set_upstream(t1)

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: This topic explains how to set up and run Unravel's Cluster Wide Report.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Cluster Wide Report is a java App designed to help you fine tune your cluster wide parameters to maximize its efficiency based upon your cluster's typical workload.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Collects performance data of prior completed jobs.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Analyzes the jobs relative to the cluster's current configuration.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Predicts and quantifies the impact the changes will have on future runs of the jobs.

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: Most of the recommendations revolve around the parameters

title: Cluster Wide Report
body: You can chose to implement some or all of the recommended settings.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Download the report tar ball from the Unravel preview site.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Unpack and run the setup script to install app in /usr/local/unravel/install_bin.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
tar zxvf ClusterReportSetup.tar.gz
cd ClusterReportSetup
sudo ./setup.sh /usr/local/unravel/install_bin

title: Step-by-step guide
body: The app is now installed in /usr/local/unravel/install_bin/ClusterReport. cd to the installation directory.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
ls
dbin/ etc/ origJars/ 
dlib/ logs/ origJars.tar.gz

title: Step-by-step guide
body: cd to dbin and edit Input.txt.

title: Step-by-step guide
body: Configure Input.txt for your cluster and report parameters.

title: Step-by-step guide
body:
cluster_id =
queue =
start_date=2018-01-01
end_date=2018-03-28
mapreduce.map.memory.mb=2048
mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb=2048
hive.exec.reducers.bytes.per.reducer=268435456
mapreduce.input.fileinputformat.split.maxsize=256000000

title: Tagging
body: See What is Tagging? for an overview of what tagging is.

title: Tagging
body: Application and workflow tags allow you to:

title: Tagging
body: Limit users UI access and applications they can see via Role Based Access Control.

title: What is Tagging?
body: Tagging is a method to apply more context to your applications so you can view and organize them with more specificity based upon your requirements and needs.

title: What is Tagging?
body: There are two types of tags, application and workflow.

title: What is Tagging?
body: Application tags provide ways to filter applications.

title: What is Tagging?
body: Workflow tags logically group a set of applications.

title: Application Tagging
body: By the time your application reaches the cluster much of its context is lost, e.g., the dept which submitted it, what project it belongs to, etc.

title: Application Tagging
body: All applications have the following metadata. (See how the metadata fields are populated.)

title: Application Tagging
body: As an admin, you need to be able to organize/view the applications running on the cluster with more granularity than this limited set allows. You will want to “slice and dice" applications a myriad of ways for a variety of reasons.

title: Application Tagging
body: Unravel can not “magically” deduce which applications belong to what tenants, projects, teams, etc.; to gain such granularity you must provide Unravel with this information.

title: Application Tagging
body: Tagging an app is how you tell Unravel about its context.

title: What is a tag
body: At the basic level a tag is simply a <key, value> pair which is associated with an application.

title: What is a tag
body: A simple way to conceptualize tagging is to think of a spreadsheet. The key is the column header and the value an entry in the column. For each application you enter your value, if any, in the column. Below we have two keys, Tenant and Project, which can be used to filter applications. While an app can have multiple tags, it cannot have multiple values for a given key. In this example, an app cannot be tagged with proj1 and proj2,

title: What is a tag
body: See below for an explanation of how these tags were generated.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: Generate chargeback reports based upon specific criteria, e.g., project, dept, team, etc.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: Decide which apps a specific user can see, e.g., the marketing head can see all marketing apps while user2 can only see specific marketing project apps.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: In order to effectively use tags you need to understand your requirements for displaying or grouping your apps. You might want to consider, among other things

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: Do you need chargebacks reports for each tenant in a multi-tenant cluster? Then apps must be tagged with the tenant it belongs to.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: Do applications need to be billed back to departments and teams? Apps need department and team tags.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: Do you want to allow some users to see all projects and others just a subset of the projects (see Role Based Access Control)? Apps must have the project tags.

title: Effective Use of Tags
body: A specific tag can be used for different purposes. You can use the project tag to generate chargeback reports and filter views specific users.

title: Assigning Tags
body: You generate a tagging dictionary via a python script. Unravel then uses the dictionary to apply tags to the applications as you prescribe.

title: Assigning Tags
body: But like Unravel, the only information you have about the application running on the cluster is its metadata. So how can you develop a script to tag specific applications; how can you determine and generate your <key, value> pairs?

title: Workflow Tagging
body: Workflow tags are much simpler than application tags. You use preexisting Unravel tags to create workflows, specifically unravel.workflow.name and unravel.workflow.utctimestamp. See Tagging Workflows for more information on creating workflows.

title: Tagging Applications
body: You can define tags for groups of applications using a python script. Unravel retrieves the script from the property com.unraveldata.app.tagging.script.path so you must define all your application tags in that file. You can also use this script to set workflow tags.

title: Tagging Applications
body: You can think of the script as creating a database comprised of a list of keys, their associated values, and what applications are associated with a specific <key, value>.

title: Tagging Applications
body: You have three departments: finance, hr, and marketing.

title: Tagging Applications
body: You would then associate applications with one of more of <key, value> pairs.

title: Tagging Applications
body: One hive query might be associated with dept:marketing while another with dept:finance.

title: Tagging Applications
body: You can not associate an application with more than one value per key. Given the example above, an application cannot be associated with both dept:marketing and dept:finance.

title: Tagging Applications
body: See What is Tagging? for more information on tagging, its purpose and a more comprehensive description.

title: Tagging Applications
body: Your Python script must be idempotent, i.e., it must produce the same result over multiple invocations with different input (metadata) for the same application.

title: Tagging Applications
body: Application tags are immutable and once created they cannot be changed.

title: Writing a Python Script
body: You can add print/debugging statements to the script, but they are logged each time the script is run. Consequently, there are numerous/duplicated entries as the script is invoked multiple times during an application's run. You can also specify workflow tags in your script.

title: Format

title: Example Python Script
body: The below script creates seven (7) tag_keys for applications and then populates them, generating the tagging dictionary.

title: Example Python Script
body: The tagging properties are set to the script file and method name.

title: Example Python Script
body:
# filename: /usr/scripts/Tagging.py

from datetime import datetime

# get_tags is the method so com.unraveldata.app.tagging.script.method.name=get_tags 
def get_tags(app_obj):

 tags = {}

# MR apps get the hive_query_id tag
 if app_obj.getAppType() == "mr":
 tags["hive_query_id"] = app_obj.getAppConf("hive.query.id")

# every app gets a dept and team tag
 tags["dept"] = app_obj.getAppName() + "_" + app_obj.getQueue())
 tags["team"] = app_obj.getUsername()

# Only apps with username=admin get this tag
 if app_obj.getUsername() == "admin": 
 tags["auth"] = "admin"

# Every app gets a scope tag based upon queue they are in
 if app_obj.getQueue() == "engr":
 # All apps in the "engr" queue get this tag
 tags["scope"] = "engineering-application"
 elif app_obj.getQueue() == "qa":
 # All apps in the "qa" queue get this tag
 tags["scope"] = "qa-application"
 else:
 # All apps not in the"engr" or "qa" queues get this tag
 tags["scope"] = "daily-application"

# creates the workflow tags, these are Unravel tags and you should contact support@unraveldata.com before using them
 tags["unravel.workflow.name"] = "Workflow-" + tags["team"] 
 tags["unravel.workflow.utctimestamp"] = app_obj.getAppType() + "-" + str(datetime.utcnow())


 return tags

title: Running Scripts
body: The tags computed in the Python script feed into Unravel core ETL pipeline. The Python script is invoked in the ingestion pipeline and is set up to access application metadata to create tags on the fly. The first time an application is invoked and running it is not listed when applications are filtered by tags. Debug and print statements are logged multiple times as the script is invoked multiple times over a run.

title: About Unravel Workflow Tags
body: unravel.workflow.utctimestamp: a timestamp in yyyyMMddThhmmssZ format that represents the logical time of a run of the workflow in UTC/ISO format. In UNIX/LINUX bash. You can get a timestamp in UTC format by running the command "$(date -u '+%Y%m%dT%H%M%SZ')".

REST API
body: Unravel's REST API provides you the ability to query and collect data from your cluster, using either HTTP or HTTPS protocol. The API returns information similar to what you see in Unravel UI. All requests and responses are in JSON Format.

title: REST API
body: To test the REST API, navigate to the Manage | API tab in Unravel UI.

title: REST API
body: Authenticate from your command line. Your access level is determined by your role. Unravel Server returns a session token which you use for all subsequent requests.

title: Base URL
body: All endpoints are relative to the base URL, http://unravel-host:3000/api/v1 or https://unravel-host:3000/api/v1

title: Methods
body: The API adheres to the standard Create-Read-Update-Delete (CRUD) semantics, in which the request path defines the Unravel Server endpoint, and the method defines the action to perform on a resource.

title: Error Codes
body: Unravel Server returns these HTTP error codes:

title: Error Codes
body: Response temporarily unavailable; the caller should retry later

title: Monitors REST API
body: The monitoring API allows you to monitor various Unravel components such as Zookeeper, Kafka, ElasticSearch, database, and disk usage. Monitors are exposed by Jolokia.

title: Monitors REST API
body: There is value field in the JSON response. This field contains the monitor's data.

title: Monitors REST API
body: Set MONITOR_HOST to the Unravel Host node where you want monitoring service.

title: Monitors REST API
body: MONITOR_HOST points to node where monitoring service is running

title: Recent Data
body: Response value contains list of Zookeeper's data. Each item in the list corresponds to one Zookeeper server.

title: Historical Data
body: Response value contains list of Zookeeper's data. Each item in the list corresponds to historical data of one Zookeeper server (historical data are computed as average of last N values).

title: Historical Data
body: Response value contains list of last N values of Kafka data (last value if the list is identical to RecentData). How many values will be stored can be configured by com.unraveldata.monitoring.kafka.history.size property.

title: MBean Status
Historical Data
body: Response value contains list of last N values of ElasticSearch data (last value if the list is identical to RecentData). How many values will be stored can be configured by com.unraveldata.monitoring.elastic.history.size property.

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: This topics explains how to configure Pagerduty and your Unravel server in order to receive auto action notifications via Pagerduty.

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: The auto action's template provides the ability to send alerts via email to one or more recipients and/or create a HTTP endpoint allowing integration with a third party tool, e.g., Slack. These two options are specified when creating/editing an auto action. Once entered nothing further needs to be done for notifications to be sent.

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: Unravel has developed a third option allowing you to use Pagerduty to send notifications to one or more users through Unravel's auto actions API.

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: Currently, this action is initiated outside of Unravel's server. For the integration you need to complete two (2) setups:

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: Set up a service at Pagerduty and specify who should be notified and how (email, etc.), and

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: Run a python script on your local machine, specifying the Unravel server and Pagerduty information.

title: Use Case - Auto Actions and Pagerduty
body: The python script must be running with the correct parameters in order for pagerduty to receive and forward notifications.

title: Set up a Pagerduty service.
body: Login to your Pagerduty Account. Select the Configuration pulldown menu and chose Services. You can register at Pager Duty.

title: Set up a Pagerduty service.
body: Name the new service. Select Use our API directly and chose Events API v2 from the pull down menu.

title: Set up a Pagerduty service.
body: Use the defaults for the remaining options and click Add Service.

title: Set up a Pagerduty service.
body: Copy the Integration Key from the Service Details Integrations tab as you need it for Unravel's Auto Actions API.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Download the Unravel demo program to the directory of your choice on your local machine.

body: Run the python script to bring up the Unravel API Demo window

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Enter your Unravel Server's address in Unravel Autoactions API Address text box.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: The Autoactions API address has the form of http[s]://UNRAVEL_HOST_IP/api/v1/autocactions. Substitute a fully qualified DNS or IP address for UNRAVEL_HOST_IP. In the example below the server is https://playground.unraveldata.com.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Enter the pagerduty integration key in the Pagerduty API key text box. Be sure to enter in the integration key correctly ensure a connection with Pagerduty. An incorrect key, or spaces around the key will prevent connecting with Pagerduty.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Click Start to populate the window with the defined auto actions and their status. These are sorted on status first and then alphabetically in ascending order.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: To scroll within list, click within the Autoaction Name list and scroll.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Open your browser and login to the Unravel Server you entered above.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Navigate to the Auto Actions page (Manage | Auto Actions). See Creating Auto Actions if you don't know how to navigate to Auto Actions. The Unravel UI shows the same list of active and inactive Auto Actions listed in Unravel API window.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Both the Unravel API window and the Unravel UI shows the exact same list of Autoactions and their status. Toggle one of the autoactions to see the effect.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: In our example there were 2 active autoactions, Kill job hogging the cluster and Rogue App AA #1. We deactivated Kill job hogging the cluster.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: In the UI and Unravel API window, you will see the change.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
body: Kill job hogging the cluster was moved to the inactive status/list in both the Unravel UI and Unravel Autoactions API window.

title: Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.
Run the Unravel API python script on your local computer.

The shot on the right shows a failed connection with no notification made. The key was invalid because a space was added to the end of the string.

title: Unravel Properties
body: Properties, unless otherwise noted, are located in /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties. To locate the properties within a file, search on property name.

title: Unravel Properties
body: You may change property defaults, but you should be cautious, contact Unravel Support for help.

title: Unravel Properties
body: Do not put quotes around the values. this includes all strings, CSL, etc.

title: Unravel Properties
body: Properties which don't have defaults are set by you. The Set by User column denotes whether you must set the property.

title: Unravel Properties
body: The Set by User column is empty if there is a default value.

title: Unravel Properties
body: The Set by User column contains:

title: Unravel Properties
body: Required when there is no default and you must set a value.

title: Unravel Properties
body: Optional when there is no default but you don't need to set a value. These properties might become required depending on your environment. For instance, if you want to enable Forecasting and Migration Reports you need to set the cluster properties. The installation and configuration topics note when you need to set optional properties for specific functionality.

title: Unravel Properties
body: path: fully qualified directory path, e.g., /tmp/dir/lower

title: Unravel Properties
body: string: a string of characters, e.g., admin, yarn, password

title: Unravel Properties
body: URL: valid IP, or fully qualified domain name

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: URL for jdbc, determined by you database.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: ldap: uses ldap entries for login.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: open: users logs directly into Unravel UI.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Customer name. Used to identify your installation for reporting purposes.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Defines the Unravel Server URL for HTTP traffic.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Location where Unravel's temp file resides.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Number of weeks retained for search results in Elastic Search.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Number of days to keep the heaviest data (such as error logs and drill-down details) in the SQL Database.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Unravel elastic search cluster name, e.g., unravel21650.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: These properties are required when using Kerberos.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Name of the Kerberos principal for Unravel daemons to use, along with its host name, domain name, and realm.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: Path to keytab file, on Unravel Server, corresponding to the Kerberos principal for Unravel daemons to use.

title: Unravel Basic Properties
body: You can verify the principal in a keytab by using  klist -kt KETYAB_FILE. The keytab file should have chmod bits 500 and be owned by unravel local user (default) or by the user you want to use, as explained in Run Unravel Daemons with Custom User.

title: Executor Logs Properties
body: Running MR jobs are linked to corresponding Hive app if Hive-on-MR app.

title: Executor Logs Properties
body: Auto Action metrics for running hive queries will be sent to AA2 backend.

title: Executor Logs Properties
body: This is used to improve the Hive-MR pipeline by caching data so it can be retrieved from cache instead of external API. You should not have to change this value.

title: Executor Logs Properties

This search requires that all the possible suffixes for the event log files are known. Possible suffixes are specified by com.unraveldata.spark.hadoopFsMulti.eventlog.suffixes..

title: Unravel Server Reference
body: This reference covers both on-premises and cloud deployments. Some daemons and properties only apply to on-premises deployments.

title: Daemons
body: The Unravel service is composed of many daemons which are summarized in the next table. The single script /etc/init.d/unravel_all.sh can be used with a start or stop or restart argument to control all the daemons on a host, in the correct order. The suffix _N means 1, 2, 3, or 4 separate daemons.

title: Daemons
body: Job Collector Sensor YARN for EMR

title: Daemons
body: "Tidy Dir" cleans up and archives hdfs directories, db retention cleaner.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: The file /usr/local/unravel/etc/unravel.properties contains settings that can be preserved during an RPM upgrade. These properties are described in the following table:

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Do not set directly; set UNRAVEL_LOG_DIR in etc/unravel.ext.sh instead and this property will be derived from that.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Determines where daemons will put temporary files. Depending on the daemon role, up to 10GB might be used temporarily.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Number of seconds between checks for presence of hive queries and MR logs to load into Unravel for batch visibility; should be between 300 and 1800 (inclusive).

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Number of seconds between checks for presence of hive queries and MR logs to load into Unravel for interactive visibility; should be between 5 and 60 (inclusive).

title: Adjustable Properties
body: MySQL (embedded or external) username for db.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: MySQL (embedded or external) password for db.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: This is JDBC URL without username and password.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Number of days for the longest running Map Reduce job ever expected; should be between 2 and 7 (inclusive).

title: Adjustable Properties

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Max number of jobs to fetch during an interval.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: URL for accessing Oozie to track workflows.

title: Adjustable Properties
body: Embedded Zookeeper ensemble in form host1:port1,host2:port2.

title: Adjustable Environment Settings

title: Adjustable Root Environment Settings

title: Troubleshooting
body: If you can't reach Unravel Server, ping your LAN DNS.

title: Sending Diagnostics to Unravel Support
body: In the upper right corner of Unravel UI, click the pull-down menu, and select Manage.

title: Sending Diagnostics to Unravel Support
body: Wait for the page to fully load.

title: Sending Diagnostics to Unravel Support
body: Click Send Diagnostics to Unravel Support.

title: Sending Diagnostics to Unravel Support
body: This sends an email message with a diagnostics report to Unravel Support and also to the users listed in the com.unraveldata.login.admins property.

title: Sending Diagnostics to Unravel Support
body: If you don't have access to push the diagnostic bundle through the UI, create the bundle on the Unravel host with the following script, and send the bundle to Unravel Support.
